organization: Institute of the Industrial Ecology Problems of the North of Kola Science Center of the Russian Academy of Sciences.
importantCollectors: ['E. A. Borovichev', 'D. Denisov', 'N. Fokina', 'L. G. Isaeva', 'L.Ya. Kagan', 'Y. R. Khimich', 'M.V. Korneykova', 'V. A. Kostina', 'G. P. Urbanavichus', 'Yu.S. Mamontov', 'A.V. Razumovskaya']
notes:
Updated Apr 2017 (specialty, correspondent, important collections updated).

There are three collections in the herbarium. The main collection contains vascular plants (1500 specimens), fungi (1600 specimens), lichens (500 specimens) and bryophytes (1320 specimens)  from the Murmansk Region and other northern regions. Additionally, the Museum of Bacteria, Algae and Microfungi of the Kola Peninsula includes strains of bacteria (37), algae (200) and microfungi (395) isolated from soils (virgin and polluted by industrial emissions of the «Severonikel» and the «Pechenganikel» enterprises, of the aluminium plant, oil-contaminated), air and anthropogenically altered environment (apatite-nepheline ore, nepheline sands, circulating water of mining plant and others) of Kola Peninsula. Another special collection, Diatoms of the Euro-Arctic Region, includes specimens of diatom complexes from the sediments and biotopes from polytypic ancient and modern water bodies, periphyton and plankton of Euro-Arctic Region: Kola Peninsula (Imandra Lake, River Paz system, mountain lakes and rivers of Khibiny and Chuna-tundra massifs and others), Arkhangelsk region (River Pechora basin), lakes and streams of Novaya Zemlya Island, Svalbard archipelago, Barents, Norwegian, Greenland and Laptev’s Seas. This collection, founded in 1993, contains 150 different specimens (about 3700 slides).
First volume of the Fungi Exsiccates from Murmansk Region issued in 2016. The present fascicule includes labels of 15 species: Amylostereum chailletii, Asterodon ferruginosus, Ceraceomyces serpens, Cerioporus mollis, Ceriporiopsis mucida, Clavaria fragilis, Laurilia sulcata, Laxitextum bicolor, Ramariopsis subtilis, Oxyporus populinus, Phellinus laevigatus, Sistotrema confluens, Skeletocutis stellae, Veluticeps abietina, Xanthoporus syringae.

division: Division of Natural Sciences and Mathematics
geography: Philippines, especially the Cordillera Administrative Region
importantCollectors: ['I. E. Buot', 'C. C. Balangue', 'L. L. Co', 'T.D. Balangcod']
notes:
Updated April 2017 (general update). 

Wanted: Other Plants of the Cordillera Administrative Region (CAR), Luzon, Philippines
Available: Some Plants of the Cordillera Administrative Region (CAR), Luzon, Philippines

The UP Baguio herbarium started as a student herbarium. It used to be very small with few collections from students and faculty researchers. At present, the herbarium has grown and is focused on keeping representative collections of the flora of the Cordillera Administrative Region, Luzon, Philippines. It is presently the only herbarium in the Region hence many students and researchers use the facility for the identification and verification of their plants for their studies.

The herbarium is active in the collection of plants from various parts of the Cordillera. 

The herbarium will be transferred to a new building, the Biodiversity Center of the Cordillera, in the future when the building will have been constructed. There is also a plan for establishing a database of all the collections which will be shared on line. The main constraint of the herbarium is funding to develop and improve it further. There is no library yet and the meager books are the personal collections of the person in charge.

The herbarium is open for donations of taxonomic books and other related literature and materials.

notes: Updated Nov 2017. The POZ Herbarium is composed of various collections, mainly from Poland, but also from different regions of Europe – altogether, about 190,000 of specimens. Furthermore, the Herbarium includes some special collections, including the collections made by J. Paczoski (from the Balkan Peninsula – 9,000 sheets), G. A. Ritschl (from the Silesia and Western Poland – 5,000 sheets) and Walter (from North America – 1,200 sheets). The whole collection contains over 240 nomenclatural types of different ranks. The collected specimens can be used for taxonomic and comparative purposes, biometric and phytogeographical studies and as reference material for rare and protected species localities.

importantCollectors: ['J. Ward']
notes: Updated Nov 2017. The herbarium was presented to Stonyhurst College in 1898 by James Ward’s son, also James (educated at Stonyhurst from 1860 onwards). The notes relating to the gift state that James Ward began collecting for his British herbarium in 1825, and by 1871 had amassed 1,753 specimens. There is a second herbarium described as ‘Exotic’ which features specimens from Ireland and Switzerland, these last were collected in 1864. The Exotic Herbarium is described as being of the same size as the British. They are described using the Linnaean system. The collection is housed separately from the other Scientific collections, and is in the same folders and order as when it was donated in c1898. It has, to the best of my knowledge, never been examined by specialists and there is no catalogue or database of the Herbarium.

importantCollectors: ['A. Ducke', 'H. Scholz', 'B. Thayner', 'W.A. Egler']
notes: Updated Aug 2017 (large general update).  Implanted in the 70s under the coordination of Normélia Cláudia de Vasconcelos, the Herbarium of the Federal University of Pará (HF), originally belonging to the Department of Pharmacy, was transferred to the research building of the Institute of Biological Sciences (ICB) and later to the annex building of the ICB where it is currently.   It is mainly intended for didactic and pedagogical activities, mainly for undergraduate courses in Biological Sciences, but also receives material from collections of practical activities from other institutes. Teaching and extension projects, coordinated by UFPA botany teachers and with the participation of trainee students resulted in an increase in the number of exsicates, as well as the introduction of fruits, seeds (carpoteca) and flow! ers, deposited in alcohol for conservation. Currently, the herbarium has a collection of approximately 3,271 samples, belonging to 51 botanical orders and 151 families. As it has not yet been possible to catalog and update all the specimens (this procedure is being done with the help of students), we still do not know how many genera and species the herbarium has. At present, the curator of the Herbarium is the responsibility of  Dra. Roberta Macedo Cerqueira (Systematics and Plant Ecology Laboratory), who assumed this commitment at the end of August 2016. After changing the Herbarium curator, the order data, families and genera began to be updated for the classifications adopted by the Angiosperm Phylogeny Group (APG), which considers both molecular, morphological and anatomical data among others for the taxonomic classification of plants (the classification system previously adopted in the herbarium was the Engler System).

organization: Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County
notes: Updated Mar 2016. LAM no longer exists. LAM phanerogams transferred to RSA in 1986. LAM vascular cryptogams, including AHFH, SFV, and USC,  transferred to RSA in 2003. Contact Dr. Maire Nazaire (mnazaire@rsabg.org). LAM algae, bryophytes, and lichens, AHFH marine algae (55 000 specimens), USC cryptogams, RSA non-vascular cryptogams (2700 algae, 3000 bryophytes, 20 000 fungi), LA bryophytes (2000 specimens), and M. P. Harthill's bryophytes (22 000 specimens) transferred to UC in 2004.  LAM fungi, including C. J. Humphrey's Polyporaceae (including about 2000 type specimens) transferred to UC in 2006. Contact Andrew S. Doran, andrewdoran@berkeley.edu. Philippine myxomycetes cited in G. W. Martin and C. J. Alexopoulos (1969) and Reynold's Southeast Asian myxomycetes transferred to BPI. Contact Erin B. McCray, herbarium@nt.ars-grin.gov

NHM is located at the ENS (Teacher Training College). It has an area of 150 sq. m., with a computer equipment and a laboratory specialist responsible for the data base.

NHM collaborates at the regional level with  IFAN (Senegal) and   (Rabat, Morocco).  At the international level, it cooperates with the The National Museum of Natural History of Paris and the Montpellier University Herbarium.

NHM  is the first and the only herbarium in Mauritania. It is very young, and the inventory of plant species in the country is at its beginning and we have a lack of human .ressources and skills.   The flora of Mauritania represents a  transition between the tropical flora and Mediterranean flora, with many endemic  western saharan species.

notes:
Updated Jan 2018 (Correspondent, Notes update).  Please direct all curatorial enquiries to sheila.garson@orkney.gov.uk.  Details of Magnus Spence's Herbarium are now online: http://www.orkneycommunities.co.uk/STROMNESSMUSEUM/library.asp
A summary following a recent cataloguing exercise (which produced the herbarium list accessible at the above link) is:
Magnus Spence (1853-1919) assembled his herbarium collection in the late Nineteenth and very early Twentieth Centuries. The number of specimens in the herbarium is 918, comprising 556 species of vascular plants, seven algae and five bryophytes. The original total certainly included two further species of vascular plant, each represented by a single specimen.

Updated Jan 2018 (correspondent removed, notes augmented).  If you need assistance with the herbarium, pleasea contact Julie King (jking@catalinaconservancy.org, (310) 510-1299 ext. 230 or Tony Budrovich at tbudrovich@catalinaconservancy.org, (562) 437 8555 ext. 1242.  CATA is interested in developing active exchange programs with other herbaria specializing in the Southern California Floristic Province and/or Mediterranean floras worldwide. Please contact the curator for details.

Visits to the herbarium can be arranged through the Catalina Island Conservancy. Most visitors to the island travel via ferry (www.catalinaexpress.com), approximately an hour boat ride from Long Beach, CA. The herbarium is located at the Wrigley Memorial Botanical Garden. For details, contact the Conservancy or herbarium staff.

updated Jul 2012.  

Loans: Types not sent on loan.

History and specificity:

Initiated at the beginning of the 19th century, now with about 250 000 samples, this collection reflects: 1) the history of Marseille: port open to the world, especially to the former French overseas territories and 2) the competence and influence of the 19th century Provençal naturalists. Today this herbarium includes: currently active herbaria, historical collections of the 19th and the 20th century of the South-East of the France and various herbaria relating to France's colonial history.

Currently active herbaria: 1) a general world herbarium of vascular plants initiated by Louis Castagne in 1820, 2) a general herbarium of vascular plants of France, 3) a general herbarium of vascular plants of the French Mediterranean area, 4) a cytogenetic herbarium of plants mainly collected and studied by J. Contandriopoulos and R. Verlaque, 5) a general world herbarium of lichen and 6) a general world herbarium of bryophyte.
Historical and prestigious collections of the 19th and the 20th century of the South-East of the France, corresponding to the first "modern" flora : 1) Herbier Louis Castagne (Catalogue des plantes qui croissent naturellement dans le département des Bouches-du-Rhône), 2) Honoré Ardoino (Flore analytique du département des Alpes-maritimes), 3) Honoré Roux (Catalogue des plantes de Provence spontanées ou généralement cultivées)… Various herbaria relating to France's colonial history : 1) Herbier Père Antoine Duss des Antilles (Flore phanérogamique des Antilles françaises, Guadeloupe et Martinique), 2) Herbier Henri Jumelle and Henri Perrier de la Bathie for Madagascar (numerous publications among the Catalogue des plantes de Madagascar), 3) Herbier Eugène Jacob de Cordemoy for La Réunion (Flore de l'Ile de la Réunion), used for the " Flore des Mascareignes ", 4) Herbier Georg. Zenker (Cameroun), Herbier Boery (Mauritanie) for the " Afrique Orientale Française ", 5) Herbier Pennel and Metzger for the Nouvelle Calédonie.

Moreover, the botanical collections of the University include the Musée Colonial de Marseille founded in 1893 as a part of the Institut Colonial de Marseille. This collection contains plant samples from overseas selected and used for food (fruits, vegetables, cereals, oils, etc.), as condiments and spices, for pharmaceuticals and for industry (rubber, wood, fibres, etc.).

notes: Entered Aug 2017.  The Highlands Biological Station Herbarium houses a significant southern Appalachian collection including material from NC and TN from 1875-1902, the Wheeler collection from the defunct Biltmore herbarium of about 200 specimens (1897-1900), collections from the Great Smoky Mountains (1930), extensive regional collections by Radford et al. (1950-1965) during preparation of the manual 'The Vascular Plants of the Carolinas,' and local collections contributed by staff, researchers, and course instructors working at HBS from the 1960s to the present.

Entered Aug 2017.  The collection has >2,000 specimens, dating back to the 1960s. Specimens have been collected from approximately 30 states. We also have Cuban specimens of the late, great euphorb expert Grady Webster.

importantCollectors: ['E.B. Almeida Jr.', 'N. Figueiredo', 'G.P. Lima', 'I.F.F. Amorim', 'I. Gottsberger', 'G. Gottsberger', 'A.N.F. Silva', 'B.E.F. Correia']
notes: Entered Aug 2017. The Herbarium MAR has a recent foundation date, July 2013, but it has a collection of plants that have been collected since 1980 in the State of Maranhão. Although recently, the collection is increasing due to developing undergraduate and postgraduate studies. It has records of plants of dune and restinga areas, as well as ecotonal environments that are a particular characteristic of Maranhão State. A collection of the families Sapotaceae, Myrtaceae, Poaceae, Arecaceae, Solanaceae, Asteraceae, Rubiaceae, Convolvulaceae and Cactaceae; And a collection of the areas belonging to the Maranhão Amazon is beginning  to expand the records of the species of the Northeast of Brazil.
Updated Sep 2017 (address, specimen total, correspondent).  The herbarium cases were moved along with the rest of the institution to Beckley in the past year.  The collection is being catalogued.

Updated March 2017 (Status: Temporarily closed).  

Colchester Museums are currently undertaking a major collections project that will relocate our existing premises to our off-site store north of Colchester. This is a fantastic opportunity to combine our collections and enhance access to them in a new facility. 
 
This is a massive task, requiring the movement and documentation of tens of thousands of objects, and you will appreciate in the meantime we have suspended access to the collections. This suspension also includes all loans from the museum and all new donations or acquisition of objects. 
 
We hope to resume access in early 2018.

notes: Updated Dec 2017 (address, GPS coordinates).  The Herbarium of University of Science holds thousands of plant specimens since the finding of the University of Science, Vietnam. These specimens represent both historical documentationand invaluable records in the past and present for various fields ofbotanical researches. About 5,000 specimens were collected before 1975 byProfessor Pham Hoang Ho, author of the 3-volume Flora of Vietnam andhis colleagues, both locals and foreigners.

taxonomicCoverage: Vascular plants, mosses and lichens, mostly collected during the past two decades resulting from Masters and Ph.D. floristic projects
geography: Central and south part of Montenegro
notes: Created  Aug 2009.  Previously the flora of Montenegro was mainly investigated by foreign botanists (Italian, Dalmatian, German, Austrian, Czech, Serbian, Slovenian, etc.), so all collected material was deposited in their herbarium collections,  the most important one  being Rohlena's collection in Prague (PR).  The  TGU collection is accompanied by rich photo documentation and botanical library that includes almost all publications about the flora and vegetation of Montenegro, as well as significant number of publications about flora and vegetation of Balkan Peninsula and SE Europe.

importantCollectors: ['S. Adams', 'A. Berdine', 'K. Cieminski', 'D. Curtis', 'C.A. Davis', 'C. DiSalvo', 'A.M. Dupre', 'C. Fishtahler', 'M. Frias', 'C.T. Frye', 'D. Hammerschlag', 'D. Ingram', 'P. Larson', 'C. Lea', 'C.K.M.', 'K. Palmquist', 'E. Pecher', 'J. Race', 'D. Reiner', 'R. Renzi', 'L. Rubin', 'R.A.R.', 'M. Schening', 'B. Spinrad', 'L. Strickler', 'L. Taylor', 'S. Tessel', 'D. Thomson', 'E. Weaver', 'D. Wiegand', 'R.H. Wiegand']
notes: The herbarium of Chesapeake and Ohio Canal National Historical Park (CHOH) was formally established and organized in 2025. Collections include botanical surveys from researchers and collections from National Park Service personnel. All specimens from the herbarium were collected within the legislative boundary of C&O Canal NHP, an area of 184.5 miles along the Potomac River between Cumberland, MD and Washington DC. The focus of this herbarium is to demonstrate the diverse floral resources of the park to the public and with special emphasis on state rare, threatened, and endangered plant species. The CHOH Herbarium functions as a reference collection of herbarium specimens which supports taxonomic, systematic, biogeographic, ecological, and conservation biological research.

taxonomicCoverage: Angiosperms, Cryptogams specially Gymnosperms and Pteridophytes, Lichens, Fungi
geography: India, especially Uttarakhand State; Himalaya, including subtropical to alpine and snow-line zones
importantCollectors: ['R. A. Silas', 'M. P. Sharma', 'D. C. Nautiyal', 'D. S. Rawat', 'C. M. Sharma', 'M. K. Bist', 'P. Nautiyal', 'K. S. Negi', 'K. C. Bhatt', 'J. K. Semwal']
notes:
Department of Botany and Microbiology is the one of the oldest departments in the university. The department has a big herbarium, Garhwal University Herbarium. This herbarium is recognized internationally. The acronym GUH has been assigned to it which is registered in Index herbariorum at New York, U.S.A. The GUH contains about 20,000 plant specimens of various plant groups like Angiosperms, Gymnosperms, Pteridophytes, Lichens, and Fungi. 
The herbarium is a repository of our plant wealth and need day to day maintenance, and plant identification is a time-consuming process. This facility is used for taxonomical studies leading to writing the flora of a region or other floristic and ecological notes on the Himalayan plants. The structure or organization of Garhwal University Herbarium is based on Bentham and Hooker’s system of classification. The preserved specimens in this herbarium include a large number of medicinal, aromatic and other economic plants from Western Himalayan region is very well represented. Besides technical details, habit, habitat, flowering and fruiting time of every specimen has been recorded in this herbarium for making it a ready reference and for use by the herbal drug industry for authentication of plant material.

geography: North central and eastern plains of Montana
importantCollectors: ['L. Hagener', 'T. J. Hildebrand']
notes: Entered Feb 2016. The Montana State University Northern Herbarium represents a new repository for plants growing in the diverse habitats associated with this geographical area.  In addition to grass- and shrub lands, we house specimen vouchers from localized mountain areas that rise above the plains (e.g., Sweetgrass Hills, Bears Paw and Little Belt Mountains).  Plants collected from prairie potholes and limestone outcrops, as well as those from cottonwood dominated riparian areas and gumbo bluffs associated with the Missouri River Breaks, are included in the collection.  Voucher age ranges from the early 1900’s to the present and some of these represent plants collected from more well-known regions, e.g., Yellowstone, Rocky Mountain, and Glacier National Parks.

notes: Entered Apr 2017.  The primary goal of herbarium of the University of Antananarivo is the teaching of plant identification techniques at the academic level. Nearly all of the specimens stored at the herbarium have been collected by students preparing their degrees (from Master or PhD fieldwork) or by the research team of the DBEV (plant biology departement)during their fieldwork. These specimens come often from remote areas, as botanical studies carried out at this department are usually located in sites where the flora remains understudied. Many of the specimens stored at the DBEV herbarium are unique and rarely have duplicates at other herbaria around the world.

organization: Kamchatka Branch of Pacific Geographical Institute (KB PGI) FEB RAS
geography: Kamchatsky Kray (Kamchatka peninsula with adjacent regions and islands)
importantCollectors: ['O. A. Chernyagina', 'Y. N. Gerasimov', 'S. S. Kharkevich', 'V. E. Kirichenko', 'T. Mazur', 'V. Y. Neshataev', 'V. Y. Neshataeva', 'A. Rzhavsky', 'T. P. Vyatkina', 'V. V. Yakubov']
notes:
Entered Jul 2016.  The herbarium was established in 1987 with the foundation of the laboratory for plant resources of the Kamchatka Division of the Pacific Geographical Institute, FEB RAS (today, this laboratory is called: Laboratory for Plant Ecology of the Kamchatka Branch of the Pacific Geographical Institute). The herbarium contains collections of vascular plants, mosses, lichens, and fungi that have been compiled by members of the Kamchatka Division PGI FEB RAS as well as by scientists from associated organizations during floristic and geobotanical field studies on the Kamchatka peninsula and its adjacent regions and islands. As of today, 6100 specimens have been catalogued. The remaining 1640 specimens are the reference collection for the “Flora of the Russian Far East (Flora Exsicata) by Charkevich and Buch (1999). Digitizing and cataloging of the Flora Exsicata specimens is in progress.  
Institute of the Russian Academy of Sciences.

importantCollectors: ['J. Muir']
notes:
Entered Jun 2015 (research visitors by request only).  Specimens are part of the John Muir National Historic Site museum collection where they are stored and maintained according to National Park Service museum standards.  . In an effort to gain better intellectual and physical control over the specimens, we are beginning a partnership project with the University and Jepson Herbaria at the University of California, Berkeley, to have students and staff mount, digitize and catalog the Muir plant specimens.  As a result of this project, the catalog records will be made available for viewing by the public on-line via the CollectionSpace program on the University and Jepson Herbaria website.  Specimen images and catalog data will be available by UC/JEPS on public portal:
https://ucjeps.cspace.berkeley.edu/ucjeps_project/public/publicsearch/.  Research requests are by appointment only

organization: Department of Agricultural and Forest Sciences
notes:
Entered Jan 2014.As a result of University reform introduced by the Italian Government, faculties were transformed into mega-Departments. The Department of Agriculture and Forestry was thus established in January 2013 as a substitute for the Agricultural Faculty. The Department includes botanists (teaching systematics, physiology, forestry botany, geobotany), agronomist and other professors teaching silviculture whose research activities in the field provides for the collection and identification of numerous herbarium specimens. Besides in the subject “Forest Botany and Mycology” all students are required to submit for the final exam an herbarium of dried plants and fungi collected during the lessons in the field including at least 25 species. 
The new herbarium currently includes ca. 5000 specimens (plants, shrubs, fungi) but this number is expected to increase rapidly.

importantCollectors: ['F. D. Bujo', 'C. E. N. Ewango', 'R. E. Gereau', 'T. B. Hart', 'I. B. Liengola', 'J. K. Madidi', 'J. M. Mukinzi', 'A. D. Poulsen']
notes:
Entered May 2011.  This herbarium is based in the Ituri Forest. It has been developed to be a herbarium of reference for research in biodiversity and plant conservation, flora and tropical botany, forest ecology studies of DR Congo protected areas. 

The herbarium collection contains a number of endemic species and important collections of little-known areas of botanical diversity importance (Inselbergs and Edos (salines). 

It is the only herbarium devoted to the study of the DR Congo protected areas flora, and has been active in updating and providing recent collections from DR Congo during the last two decades. 

This herbarium is also active in developing a "National Strategic Plan for Plants Conservation" and working with IUCN for the Red Data Listing in DR Congo.

organization: Macquarie University Indigenous Bioresources Research Group (IBRG)
importantCollectors: ['D. H. Harrington']
notes:
Entered Jan 2016.  
This is a very small herbarium, managed and run only to provide a place to store specimens of ethnobotanical interest for a small scale research unit at Macquarie University. We have chosen to register an independent herbarium as publication for scholarly journals in this field requires unique records to be retained of all samples collected for testing. Consequently we have a lot of duplicate records, often from the same plant, many of which do not have floristic parts or other useful diagnostic features. These are not acceptable in other herbaria we have available to us.

notes:
Entered Mar 2016.  The Oman Botanic Garden, a unique project not only within Oman but the entire Arabian Peninsula, is currently under construction. It aims to present and showcase the native flora and habitats of the country to visitors and offers student, researchers and other botanic gardens (national and international) modern facilities and expertise in a state of the art research centre.    The OBG herbarium will be a major focus of the research centre. The herbarium is currently working closely with researchers from within Oman (e.g. Sultan Qaboos University) and international research institutions (e.g. Royal Botanic Gardens of Edinburgh). 

Oman’s native flora consists of approximately 1408 species, distributed within highly diverse habitats throughout the country. Remote and inaccessible areas of the country have yet to be studied. There is a relatively high possibility that new plant records will be discovered during the course of OBG’s field collecting trips.
 
Although we are at the beginning of a large task, the OBG herbarium collection is constantly growing and aims at increasing our specimen numbers vastly within the next two to three years.  On our many field trips throughout Oman, collecting herbarium vouchers is of critical importance. Of nearly all the species collected so far, multiple vouchers are available. The wide range of morphological variation within and between Oman’s diverse habitats is captured for many of the species. Vouchers of rare and endemic species are included in our collection as well.

In Oman, we are so far the only herbarium/institution that regularly undertakes scientific curation and physical curation inspections by trained staff and documents all procedures

importantCollectors: ['S. Anderson', 'C. Betten', 'M. C. Jensen', 'E. T. Lunn', 'J. Rahn', 'G. L. Roi', 'R. Runge', 'K. L. Weik']
notes:
Updated Apr 2014.  The Elizabeth Teter Lunn Herbarium is home to more than 5,000 plant specimens dating primarily from the turn of the twentieth century, with some being collected, purportedly, as early as 1848. Between the years 1895 and 1897. M.C. Jensen, a student and botanist, collected more than 80 specimens within the city of Lake Forest, IL, and added these to the College's collection.  At present, student Victoria Jones is in the process of writing a proposal for Lake Forest College to pay more attention to the collection and thus salvage this one-of-a-kind herbarium. This proposal reflects Victoria's senior-thesis topic and all of the tedious curatorial work she has committed to for the past three years. Victoria is currently working alongside Gerould Wilhelm, the foremost vascular plant botanist of the Chicago Region, to observe truth and beauty in each specimen of the ETL Herbarium. The outcome will be Gerould Wilhelm's & Laura Rericha's brand new book, "Flora of the Chicago Region." This book will update Swink & Wilhelm's "Plants of the Chicago Region" (1994).

The majority of the collection contains specimens from Illinois Beach State Park (IBSP) collected by Elizabeth Teter Lunn (professor at Lake Forest College) between the 1950s and mid-1970s. Lunn's interest in collecting from IBSP was based on an earlier study tallying the park's flora during the 1900s. The result was the publication of her guidebook, "Plants of the Illinois Dunesland," completed in 1982 and published by The Illinois Dunesland Preservation Society.

geography: Pakistan, especially northern and northwestern Pakistan (Punjab, North-West Frontier Province, Baluchistan, Northern areas, and Azad Kashmir), including Gilgit-Baltistan, Salt Range, Galliyat, Deserts, Sindh, Baluchistan, AJK and Northern Himalayan areas
importantCollectors: ['M.A. Khan', 'S. Sultana', 'W. Zaman', 'S.M. Shah']
notes:
Updated April 2017 (Contact information, staff, URL, important collectors, geography updated).
The herbarium contains specimens of 150 families of flowering plants along with collections of gymnosperms (conifers) and lower plants (non-seed producing plants) and all of these plant species are entirely indigenous in nature. The collection is currently being digitized, and the herbarium staff building an electronic Herbarium Catalogue containing images of the specimens and information taken from their collection labels.  The overall objective of digitization of the herbarium is to link this national wealth of the country with international research institutes and global web of knowledge.  The oldest specimens were collected some 50 years ago and 52 per cent of all flowering plant genera are represented in the collection.
 
The herbarium scientists are committed to making this important collection more accessible to botanists and others, wherever they may be, for use in their own projects: particularly in biodiversity, conservation and sustainable development. Currently ongoing projects linked to herbarium include taxonomic studies of wild vegetables, wild edible fruits, biodiesel plants based resources, medicinal plants and pollen flora of Northern Pakistan.

notes: Updated Dec 2013 (staffupdate).  The regional collection, traditionally called "Rheinisches Herbar," has been curated by BONN since 1973, but was separated as an independent herbarium in 1998. The owner of the collection is the "Naturhistorischer Verein der Rheinlande und Westfalens," Nussallee 15a, D-53115 Bonn, Germany. The non-Rheinanian part of the herbarium, called "Ausserrheinisches Herbar" (210 000 specimens), was transferred to Berlin-Dahlem in 1936 (but kept outside, thus surviving the 1943 fire), taken to Russia by the Soviet army after World War II, returned in due course to East Berlin (BHU), and eventually reintegrated into B in 1993.

The geography the herbarium samples covers all 43 administrative districts of the Rostov region which area is 100 thousand sq.km, and flora contains about 1900 species of vascular plants. The herbarium includes the departments: 1) vascular plants of the Rostov region; 2) introduced species from collections of the Botanical garden of SFU; 3) wild-growing flora of the Botanical garden of SFU; 4) vascular plants of the National natural biospheric park "Rostovsky". The computerized information system is used for searching of necessary data in the database. It contains data on 1931 species of local flora and 25614 herbarium samples.

organization: Universidad Pedogógica y Tecnológica de Colombia
geography: Colombia, especially Boyacá and Eastern upland
importantCollectors: ['L. A. Camargo', 'R. Castillo', 'G. L. Contreras', 'S. Díaz-Piedrahita', 'G. Lozano C.']
notes:
Updated Oct 2015..  The herbarium was created because of the need of professors and students of having an appropriate space for the investigation and of the study of flora in the state. In its start-up was directed by professor Rafael Guarin Montoya with the help of  his auxiliary Mardoqueo Villarreal. In 1984 the management was in charge of professor Rafael Castillo.In 1998 he dismissed and only  at the beginning of 1999 professor Maria  Eugenia Morales Puentes took over the direction  and she is still in charge of the herbarium UPTC. The UPTC herbarium is a collection of regional type, registered as a biological collection with scientific  purposes before the institute Alexander Von Humboldt (number 26 under initial UPTC-H),According to legislation established by the Ministry of Environment in resolution number 1115 of year 2000 ,and it is considered National Patrimony, besides of being place of important reference of fauna an d flora from Boyaca ,although  it includes areas from sates that share borders as Casanare and Santander. The herbarium has about 21,314 specimen and some vegetal collections among them  the Briofitos collection(Mosses,Hepatics,Antoceros y Lichens), from Ferns and Licofitas of angioespermas from fruits and seeds(carpoteca) and a collection that has being created  nowadays referred to vegetal fibers.The logo of the herbarium is represented through an illustration  od Diplostephium jenesanum,a specie founded in the Boyaca State and it is described by the actual director and Santiago Diaz Piedrahita, sample type of the UPTC-H herbarium .
Nowadays the herbarium is an active member of  a variety  of museums in Boyaca , its capital Tunja and of course  of the university, besides  it is member of Colombian association of herbariums(ACH) and has agreements with different public and private institutions in the country. The herbarium has a future projection as a unit where an important collection of plants from Boyaca and the Eastern Cordillera can be deposit, focused to services and problem solving, hypothesis, consulting, among others thesis, master degrees  and PhD, visits to institutions (schools, universities and people interested in the matter)service of determination, drying and assembly of vegetal material, also we have a documentation center ,microscopy  area, specialized software area (canopy l, leaves and seeds),cartographies, projection area, also we advise services related to Botany  which are available to all the students and researchers.

Pichi Sermolli', 'G. Raddi', 'E. Reboul', 'V. Ricasoli', 'H. Ruiz Lopez', 'G. B. Samaritani', 'G. H. W. Schimper', 'M. de Sessé y Lacasta', 'A. de Silvestri', 'J. F. Soleirol', 'C. P. S. Sommier', 'A. Vaccari', 'A. Vatova', 'S. Venzo', 'P. B. Webb (FI-W)']
notes:
(last update: May 2025)
FI includes a number of sub-collections, either open to further improvement, or closed (""historical herbaria""); each of them is listed as a separate entry in GRSciColl (https://scientific-collections.gbif.org/), where further details are provided. The largermost of these sub-collections are the General Herbarium (FI-GEN), which incorporated the Herbarium libycum (15,000 specimens), the Philip Barker Webb's herbarium (Herbarium webbianum, FI-W), the Odoardo Beccari's Malesian herbarium (Herbarium beccarianum, FI-HB), the Micheli-Targioni herbarium (Herbarium michelianum, FI-M), the Rodolfo Emilio Giuseppe Pichi Sermolli's herbarium (Herbarium pichianum, FI-PS) and the Odoardo Beccari's palms herbarium (Herbarium palmarum, FI-HP).  The Botanical collections also includes a number of important, historical herbaria, such as the Andrea Cesalpino's and the Tuscan anonymous' herbaria (FI-CES and FI-MER, respectively, both dating backs to 16th century), and several ancillary collections (seeds, fruits, wood samples etc.). Due to the historical significance and uniqueness of most collections, physical loan is only possible for a limited number of FI-GEN and the ancillary collections specimens. A large, comprehensive digitization project led by the Padova University, thanks to the National Biodiversity Future Center (NBFC) initiative and through the Next Generation EU and Italian National Resistance and Resilience Programme (PNRR) fundings,  has started in March 2024 into the herbarium rooms, aiming to the complete databasing and imaging of FI and other important Italian herbaria.

All correspondence relative to loans and exchanges should be with CAS. CI incorporated in DS. Specimens from CI, including vouchers of J. C. Clausen, D. D. Keck, W. M. Hiesey, and M. A. Nobs, should be cited as DS. DS algae transferred to UC. DS fungi transferred to BPI. DS arctic bryophytes (4580 specimens) transferred to NY in 1968. W. R. Dudley's New York state bryophytes transferred to NYS. Remainder of DS bryophytes transferred to UBC and CAS. Library owns private collection of Adolf Engler's reprints. Contact Debra Trock, dtrock@calacademy.org

organization: Dr. Charles F. and Wilhelmina Husser Clark Herbarium
importantCollectors: ['G. K. Helmkamp', 'E. C. Jaeger', 'J. C. Roos', 'C. Stocks']
notes: Updated Jan 2016 (staff update).  The Clark Herbarium serves as a reference library to the plant diversity and changes of Southern California.   With almost 10,000 specimens, the Clark Herbarium includes dry botanical mounts, most of which were collected from the Riverside region and surrounding counties by J. C. Roos and other botanists between 1920 and 1990. A small collection of lichens and fungi was assembled during the 1930s by Edmund C. Jaeger, and was later donated to the Museum during his tenure as Curator of Plants. All these materials now represent an important database describing the distribution of native plant species in the southwestern U.S., which is now a vastly altered environmental setting.

importantCollectors: ['D. Ware']
notes:
Updated Feb 2016. The Lee Park Herbarium was begun in 1937 as part of a WPA project to create a wildflower sanctuary. In addition to clearing land and planting native plants, the WPA workers were taught to collect and preserve specimens.  This part of the collection comprises 325 specimens; collection ended about 1940.  In the 1990s, Donna M.E. Ware, botanist at the College of William and Mary, began collecting in Lee Park anew.  Her goal was to determine if the original 325 species still grew there, and then expanded her project to collect other plants in the Park and watershed.  The Ware portion of the herbariam comprises 800 specimens and collection continues on this portion.

The herbarium collection includes 238 corresponding watercolors exquisitely painted by Bessie Neimeyer Marshall during the depression era in the 1930’s.  The botanical renderings are showcased in With Paintbrush and Shovel: Preserving Virginia’s Wildflowers.

geography: Rocky Mountain Western Slope, Gunnison Basin, Colorado
importantCollectors: ['H. G. Barclay', 'J. Barrell', 'P. Buck', 'G. Largent', 'R. Seagrist', 'K. Taylor', 'C. F. Williams']
notes:
Updated Feb 2017.  (general update).  The herbarium was established shortly after the founding of the Rocky Mountain Biological Laboratory (RMBL), in 1929 by Harriet G. Barclay from the University of Tulsa (TULS). It has served as a resource for plant identification and distribution information for students and researchers at the lab and contains vouchers from many research projects over the past 80 years. The collection is completely databased, imaged, and searchable online at: http://intermountainbiota.org.
The laboratory/field station, located at over 9500 ft.in the Elk Mountains of Western Colorado, is open and accessible seasonally from May-October.
The collection is curated by volunteers from other institutions who work at the lab each summer (currently C.F. Rick Williams, Curator, Ray J. Davis Herbarium [IDS], Idaho Museum of Natural History).

Jastrzebowski', 'K. Jelski', 'J. Kornas', 'J. Krupa', 'G. M. Martens', 'A. Medwecka-Kornas', 'M. Nobis', 'S. F. O. Nordstedt', 'M. Olech', 'A. Pacyna', 'B. Pawlowski', 'G. L. Rabenhorst', 'M. Raciborski', 'A. Rehman', 'J. Rohlena', 'J. Rostafinski', 'K. Rouppert', 'F. Sennen', 'A. Slendzinski', 'A. Starzenski', 'B. Szafran', 'P. V. Titius', 'L. J. Wahlstedt', 'A. Wróblewski', 'A. Zajac', 'M. Zajac', 'A. Zalewski', 'A. Zmuda']
notes: Updated Jul 2017 (geocoordinates updated).  30 000 bryophytes and lichens of KRA on permanent loan to KRAM. Private herbarium of Jan Kornas and Anna Medwecka-Kornas (40 000 specimens) stored at KRA.  There are preserved also two historical herbaria of 18th century. The first is a book of 27 sheets (24,5 x 40 cm) with 172 specimens of plants labelled with pre-Linnean latin names. It was made by an unknown author after 1700. The second herbarium consists of four unified folio volumes (32 x 44,5 cm). The volume 1 includes 104 sheets, vol. 2 - 98, vol. 3 - 100, vol. 4 - 104 sheets and the herbarium contains 383 species of plants. After the title page the owner of the herbarium was ANDRZEJ BADURSKI (1740-1789), lecturer of medicine at Cracow University, educated at the University of Bologna. The herbarium was probably made under the supervision of GAETANO LORENZO MONTI (1712-1797), professor of medical botany at Bologna University.  The Paleobotanical collection, of the  Paleobotanic Museum , has a rich collection of over 150 thousand specimens of fossil plants (including microscopic preparations of the anatomy of certain plants) from all geological periods of Earth's history, from the Devonian period of the Holocene. The oldest exhibits date from the late XIX century (M. RACIBORSKI). One of the most valuable is a collection of Devonian first land plants. In the collection, there are several types of plants from the Devonian and Carboniferous period

department: Department of Botany and Plant Physiology
importantCollectors: ['Collectors of the historical h']
notes:
Herbarium consists of two sections:
1. Herbarium of Karelian flora 
2. The General herbarium, which includes plants from different regions (USSR, Russian Federation, Turkmenia, Italy, Chine, etc.)
In the section of the Karelian Herbarium specimens are systematically arranged. Section contains specimens of vascular plants from the territory of Karelia only. This is a unique collection of Karelian flora, both historically and scientifically, documenting the composition of the flora of the Region and the history of its research.
In section of the General Herbarium specimens arranged according to the geographical area.
The herbarium has been replenished with collections of students, postgraduates, teachers and staff of the Department of Botany and Plant Physiology

organization: Las Cruces Biological Station, Organization for Tropical Studies
importantCollectors: ['B. Boyle', 'R. Moran']
notes: Updated Mar 2011.  The Luis Diego Gomez Herbarium is located at the Las Cruces Biological Station (8° 47' 7'' N, 82° 57' 32'' W), one of three field stations owned and operated by the Organization for Tropical Studies (OTS; www.ots.ac.cr) in Costa Rica.  This is a nascent herbarium (inaugurated 2006) but a comprehensive collection of the regional flora of southern Costa Rica is well underway, and all specimens are scanned and uploaded to the herbarium website. The collecting is only ~1,400 km2 but spans an elevational gradient of 300 - 3200 m and a rainfall range from 1.5 - 5 m (see website for a map of collecting range). The herbarium is expanding at a rate of ~600-700 specimens per year.

importantCollectors: ['W. S. Hong']
notes: Updated Oct 2017 (staff).  Although housed at the University of Great Falls, the Tu-Hi Hong and Pum-Hi Hong Herbarium is currently managed and curated by the late Dr. Won Shic Hong’s family. The collection consists almost exclusively of bryophytes. The majority of the collection is composed of Dr. Hong’s collections from the Northwest region of the North American continent and a significant collection from the Korean Peninsula. Also includes contributions from other collectors in the United States and Canada.   As the University is not currently involved with operations of the herbarium please directly contact Yoon-Hee Hong at hongherbarium@gmail.com for any assistance.

notes: Updated Jul 2017 (herbarium name, staff, notes updated).  The herbarium is located on the third floor of the Pharmacy Faculty, in the University City, just to the south of Plaza Venezuela.  Due to the actual social and political situation, the herbarium cannot receive visitors, for reasons of personal security, until further notice.  Please do not send MYF any material until further notice.  MYF is not being notified of mail received by Customs nor does Customs respond to requests from MYF, and shipments are being returned at the sender's cost.  Favor no enviar material hasta próxima noticia, ya que Aduana no notifica a MYF de la Illegada de bultos, ni responde a solicitud, y devuelve los bultos a costo del remitente. Loans: A computerized list of specimens, with basic data, will be sent initially for selection, to reduce shipping costs.  It is possible that we can send packages  Préstamos: Una lista computarizada de muestras, con datos básicos, se enviará inicialmente para selección, para reducir los gastos de envío. Es posible que podamos enviar bultos.

incorporatedHerbaria: ['Cathedra geobotanica of Leningrad University', 'the highest female courses (courses of Bestuzhev) in 1919']
importantCollectors: ['V. I. Aggeenko', 'A. A. Antonov', 'H. G. Bongard', 'N. A. Busch', 'G. S. Karelin', 'I. F. Schmalhausen', 'A. P. Sokolovskaya', 'C. L. Willdenow', 'P. S. Pallas', 'I. Boeber']
notes:
Updated Oct 2017. 
Herbarium of the Botany Department of the Saint Petersburg State University (LECB) is one of the largest University Herbarium of Russia. Its funds contain at least 800,000 herbarium sheets of higher plants. Now Herbarium collection is unique in the structure of the University, both in historical and in scientific terms by geographical coverage and systematic collection of funds, the existing type specimens (more than 3,500 types in the present, as we found). The type collection includes quite a significant amount of rare and original authentic specimens collected by various botanists such as E. Boissier (1810–1885), V. Borbas (1844–1905), H. Cuming (1791–1865), A.P. Decandolle (1778–1841), J. Forster (1754–1794), W. Hooker (1785–1865), G. Schimper (1804–1878), V. Tineo (1791–1856), W. Besser (1784–1842), А. Bunge (1803–1890), R. Hohenacker (1798–1872), G. Karelin (1801–1872), I. Kirilov(1822–1842), St. Krasheninnikov (1711–1755), C. Ledebour (1785–1851), R. Maack (1825–1886), K. Meinshausen (1819–1899), C. Meyer (1795–1855), А. Nordmann (1803–1866), P. Pallas (1741–1811), Ch. Steven (1781–1863), N. Turzaninov (1793–1863), А. Shrenk (1816–1876) etc. 

This Herbarium is probably one of the oldest as Russia storage facilities. The oldest herbarium specimens kept in LECB, belong to the middle of XVII century, or even the end of XVI century. Prelinnean specimens found by us in G. Bongard (1786–1839) and E. Lindemann (1825–1901) collections. Thus, according to Lindemann, in his collection during his lifetime were kept for more than 60 specimens collected by prelinnean F. Ambrosi (2 sheets), J. Breyn (1637–1697) (36), C. Bauhin (1) (1560–1624), A. Clegero (1) (he collected Juniperus japonica from Japan in 1688), J. Gerard (1545–1612) (1), J. Gmelin (1709–1755) (20). Many specimens found in Bongard’s herbarium, but how many relics it contains is difficult to say, since Bongard did not kept accounting herbarium revenues. Currently LECB, revealed more than 60 prelinnean specimens. The most of them were found in herbaria Bongard – specimens belonged to J. Commelin (1629–1692), C. Commelin (1668–1731), Breyn, P. Hermann (1646–1695), G. Steller (1709–1746), Gmelin etc., as well as in the herbarium Lindemann to Bauhin, Clegero, Breyn, Gmelin, etc. Currently, the oldest specimen found in LECB, is a specimen of C. Bauhin (1560–1624) – Jucca gloriosa L., without an exact date on the label, but, undoubtedly, belonged to Bauhin. Some of the old specimens have only historical interest, other are syntypes for species of C. Linnaeus (1707–1778), P. Pallas (1741–1811), J. Lamarck (1744–1829) and others, which is why value these specimens is particularly large. Examples of these types: Melanthium sibiricum L., Anthericum calyculatum L., Convolvolus ammannii Desr., Convolvulus lineatus L., Yucca gloriosa L., Andromeda stelleriana Pall., Claytonia arctica Adam, Claytonia sibirica L., Alyssum hyperboreum L., Phlox sibirica L. Thus, LECB is the third in Russia after Moscow State University Herbarium (MW) and Komarov Botanical Institute RAS (LE), which revealed prelinnean specimens, and some of which refers to syntypes of Linnean taxa. 

Private herbaria of H. G. Bongard (25 000 specimens) and E. E. Lindemann (200 000 specimens) housed at LECB.

Two contributors to Bongard’s collection deserve special mention: Johann Jacob Boeber (1746-1820) and Carl Ludwig Willdenow (1765-1812). 

It was Boeber’s personal herbarium the first collection to have been acquired in 1823 by the Department of Botany and added to Bongard’s own collection, comprising at the time 6,783 species. According to Bongard, Boeber’s collection of 7,000 specimens, representing 6,000 vascular plants and 1,000 cryptogams, was for the most part “badly pressed, or damaged by use”. Subsequently, and for reasons unknown, most of its specimens had been transferred to the Botanical Museum and are presently kept at the Herbarium of the Komarov Botanical Institute of the Russian Academy of Sciences (LE). 

That Bongard’s collection at LECB includes some of Willdenow’s original specimens is not a widely known fact, either in Russia, or in the West. Our research indicates that there are 1,089 Willdenow’s specimens at LECB, with 104 of them authenticated by labels in his hand. This alone makes Bongard’s collection at LECB quite unique, both as a historic and scientific record. The only other Willdenow herbarium sheets in Russia, with labels in his hand, are found at LE (limited to algae), and at MW, the Moscow University Herbarium (about 50 sheets). 
Our preliminary study of Bongard’s collection at LECB identified around 1,450 type specimens (mostly syntypes and isotypes) that are currently kept in the Herbarium’s type collection of about 3,500 specimens. Among them, 42 type specimens of the Restionaceae, with 33 of them described by K.S. Kunth (1788-1850). Kunth, along with several other taxonomists, studied specimens collected by J.F. Drége (1794-1881) at the Cape of Good Hope and in other districts of the Cape Province in South Africa. There are also Bongard’s own type specimens, such as Соrallorhiza mertensiana Bong., collected by K.H. Mertens at Sitka, Alaska, with labels both in Bongard’s and Mertens’s hand. However, most of the types described by Bongard are kept at LE. The LECB specimens seem to be duplicates of those, with more detailed labels, found at LE. 

Literature about Herbarium (LECB)
http://www.rasl.ru/e_resours/Gerbary_bin/uchrezhdeniya/spbgu.html

notes:
Updated Mar 2017 (general update). 
Average accession rates are about 1,000 specimens per year. PPI exchanges duplicates with some academic institutions around the world and focuses on acquiring plants from East Asia (especially mainland China and Japan). In addition to various domestic universities and botanical research institutions, current targets for such exchanges also encompass major universities, herbaria, museums and botanical gardens in Asian countries. PPI has Southern Taiwan vascular plants available for exchange. PPI specimens are made with the utmost care, and each specimen label contains a complete set of information. PPI preserves 21 new species, 2 new record family, 21 new record genus, 73 new record species, 4 new combination, 31 corrections. Especially, there are 23 Holotypes preserved in PPI.

Entered Sep 2009.  Specimens are stored in acid free herbarium paper and are kept in metal storage cabinets, while corresponding samples of selected taxa are conserved in 96% ethanol / glycerol (50:50) and/or silicagel dried.
The herbarium is equipped with cabinet drier.
The herbarium data is completely digitalized (database in FileMaker Pro 9), all herbarium sheets are photographed while (for the moment) web browsing is available for about half of the specimens. Internet access to all the data will be possible by the end of 2009.

organization: University of California-Berkeley, Sagehen Creek Field Station
importantCollectors: ['J. Ammirati', 'J. Brooks', 'E. Davidson', 'M. Fleschner', 'L. Loeblich', 'W. Savage', 'R. Schmid', 'B. Trowbridge']
notes:
Entered Dec 2011. Sagehen Creek Field Station is approximately 8000 acres, and encompasses a diverse cross section of the Sierra Nevada from the Pacific Crest (el. 8000 ft) to the eastern slope (el. 6400 ft). Habitats include yellow pine, mixed conifer, and red fir forests, as well as brushfields, scattered mountain meadows, and fens. 
The Sagehen Herbarium is comprised of two related collections: "Herbarium of the Sagehen Creek Field Station" and "Flora of California."  The Sagehen Creek collection is fairly comprehensive of plants found on the reserve. The "Flora of California" collection draws from a broader area, but is still focused on Sierra Nevada specimens.

In Carl Studniczka’s herbarium the majority of the herbal plants was collected in Europe (Croatia, Austria, Italy, Montenegro, France, Poland, Czech Republic). Most of the samples of herbarium plants were collected by Studniczka himself. Besides Studniczka, over then 240 collectors or botanists also have been registered. The oldest herbarium sheet dates from 1836, where as the newest ones date from 1904. The vast majority of herbarium sheets was collected during the period from 1871 to 1880.

organization: Bryce Canyon National Park, Cedar Breaks National Monument, and Zion National Park
importantCollectors: ['W. S. Boyle', 'J. L. Crawford', 'P. M. Patraw', 'A. M. Woodbury']
notes: Entered Apr 2016.   Zion National Park manages a herbarium of over 3500 herbarium specimens.  Zion also manages the herbaria from Cedar Breaks National Monument, over 900 specimens, and Bryce Canon National Monument, over 1800 specimens.  These specimens provide baseline information about the natural environment of the three parks.  These collections display the remarkable diversity at the convergence of three ecological provinces: the Colorado Plateau, the Great Basin, and the Mojave Desert.  Zion’s collection represents over 95% of the confirmed 982 plant taxa in the park.  The earliest specimens in the herbaria were collected in the 1920s with additions to the collection continuing today. Most of the specimens were collected from 1950s to 1980s.

notes:
Entered Jul 2013. The ontogenetic herbarium is herbarium of plants of different stages of individual development. Ontogenetic states were revealed with the use of the concept of discrete description of ontogenesis taking into account morphological features-markers (table). The goal is to document every species in the Ontogenetic Herbariumwith specimens in different ontogenetic states from plantules to the senile plants (complete ontogenesis). Our Ontogenetic herbarium has duplicates of some species that we are ready to interchange, and we can also take herbarium of ontogenesis of any types of plants on storage. Exhibits in herbarium are arranged in alphabetical order of latin names of families and species inside these families. Systematic catalogue renovates constantly, the ontogenetic states of species, places of collections and main collectors are indicated in it.
The Ontogenetic herbarium in an accessible form for use, and  includes 5330 mounted sheets of  607 species of plants from 369 genera and 86 families, and also 1 lichen and 2 types of gymnospermous and higher cryptogams plants. It is used both in scientific and pedagogical aims.  The Ontogenetic Herbarium allows users to get skills of determination of ontogenetic states of plants of different biomorphes and to apply them for study and maintenance of population biodiversity. Today the Ontogenetic Herbarium is included in the department "Population-Ontogenetic Museum."

notes: Entered May 2017.  Plant diversity collections of Indian arid zones are available for researchers interested in desert flora. This herbarium works as a knowledge repository aiming to share information to all possible stakeholders not only for awareness generation about arid zones flora but also to sensitize about biodiversity conservation by inculcating the philosophy and necessity for public engagement for focused environmental stewardship.

organization: The Everhart Museum of Natural History, Science & Art
importantCollectors: ['Stanley Glowenke', 'Alfred Twining']
notes: Entered Oct 2010.  The Alfred Twining Herbarium is housed in two metal cabinets in the basement of the Everhart Museum.  The specimens are mounted on herbarium sheets or are loose in folders which are enclosed in additional folders and are arranged in a family sequence used by Alfred Twining in his <Flora of Northeastern Pennsylvania> (1917).  Most of the specimens were collected by Twining in the early twentieth centure prior to the publication of the flora.  EMNH is the major repository for Twining specimens -- few are duplicated at PH.   However, most, if not all, of the Glowenke specimens (from the 1930s) are duplicated in PH (summarized from an assessment of the herbarium by A. Schuyler).  Supercedes EVMU.

organization: Craveri Civic Museum of Natural History
importantCollectors: ['F. E. Rota', 'F. Craveri', 'G. Abbà', 'A. Morisi']
notes:
Entered Jan 2017.  The herbarium was established by  Bra native Federico Craven, co-founder of the museum, who between 1859 and 1880 collected and determined 622 species of vascular plants (862 specimens)   mainly coming from the immediate surroundings of his town. To it were added other collections of which the most important are as follows: F. Rota (1950 specimens.), and G. Abba (450 specimens). This material is kept in special drawers and periodically subjected to fumigation. Much of the herbarium is being cataloged, to  allow  for rapid on-line consultation of specific data collection and determination of each artifact.
The herbarium contains 300 specimens  of lichens,  552 specimens of  wood, a  spermatoteca collection of 350, and 300 succulent plants.

currentStatus: Ochrophyta, Charophyta, Chlorophyta, Rhodophyta, Cyanobacteria and Euglenozoa
taxonomicCoverage: Argentina, Chile, Uruguay, Bolivia, Antarctica, Southern Atlantic Ocean
geography:
The phycological herbarium is housed at the División Ficología “Dr. Sebastián A. Guarrera”. It holds about 17,000 specimens/samples, mostly microalgae, both marine and freshwater, inventoried since 1969. The herbarium includes the type materials of 506 taxa.
Besides recent and contemporary microalgae collections, the herbarium is house of historical diatom collections. Of them, the collection gathered by Frenguelli, pioneer of diatom studies in South America, is the most relevant. The Frenguelli Diatom Collection (FDC) constitutes a primary reference for worldwide diatomists since it allows access to information on diatom biodiversity extending back up to 100 years ago. The FDC represents the biodiversity existing in the past as it gathers samples from South America (Argentina, Chile, Uruguay, Bolivia and Peru) and Antarctica. Additional gatherings from Italy, Egypt and Somalia also make up the collection.
Frenguelli ́s legacy also includes two worldwide known reference diatom collections: 
-“Collection Tempère et Peragallo (Diatomées du Monde Entier, 2e. Édition)” consists of a set of 1000 slides containing diatom assemblages from c. 900 localities, fossil or recent, freshwater and marine, from different parts of the world. Complete sets of slides are rare, housed in a few research institutions in Europe and USA. Presently, an almost complete set (995 of 1000 slides) of this collection is curated at the Herbarium LPC
-“Möller Collection” consists of 117 slides with strews of mixed diatom species, 5 slides of “Diatomaceen Typen-Platte” and 2 slides of “Diatomaceen Probe-Platte”. Both Typen- and  Probe-Platten are accompanied by an explanatory brochure. 
The Herbarium also houses more recent collections gathered by the following collectors:
- S.A. Guarrera: freshwater microalgae from different areas of Argentina, mainly from Patagonia and Pampasic regions.
-M.E. Ferrario: marine phytoplankton from Antarctica and Southwestern Atlantic Ocean.
-A. Boltovskoy: freshwater phytoplankton, mainly dinoflagellates, from different regions of Argentina.
-S. Cabrera: macroalgae from coastal Buenos Aires province and Patagonia.

Entered Apr 2017.

importantCollectors: ['M. Nisar', 'N. Nazim']
notes: Entered Jul 2016.  The foci of the University of Malakand Botanic Garden and Herbarium are 1) conservation of the local flora both in- and ex-situ; 2) development of a herbarium emphasizing local species; 3) monographic study of local species, particularly those of high value medicinal plants; 4) DNA/Protein genotyping with an emphasis on local species; 5) tissue culture of rare local species to support their conservation and multiplication. The herbarium currently has about 2000 dry specimens from different localities in the Malakand division, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Pakistan. More than 60% of the plants are endemic to Malakand division and acclimated to the environmental conditions of the botanic garden.

importantCollectors: ['S. Yu. Bolshakov', 'N. V. Borodin', 'G. G. Chugunov', 'O.  Ya. Czinger', 'L. V. Dolmatova', 'G. A. Grishutkina', 'A. V. Ivoilov', 'A. A. Khapugin', 'N.I. Kuzneczov', 'T. L. Nikolaeva', 'L.  V. Sanaeva (Tereshkina)', 'I.  S. Tereshkin', 'E. V. Vargot']
notes: Entered Jan 2012.  The Herbarium of Mordovian State Nature Reserve was  initially all  stored in one plywood cabinet. The fungi, lichens and mosses were stored in thick paper bags in a special plywood box. Today the herbarium collections of vascular plants Mordovian State Nature Reserve has 3216 herbarium sheets in 7 wooden cabinets, each of which is divided into 10 chambers, arranged in two columns.  The specimens are  arranged in the Englerian system.  Most of the herbarium collections were made within the reserve and in adjacent territories. The herbarium reflects  the species diversity of flora in the west of Mordovia, with  756 species belonging to 377 genera and 99 families.  The macrofungus herbarium has about 1500 specimens and includes about 400 species. It is stored in plastic ziplock bags enclosed in kraft paper bags and is located on the system, adopted in  the 9th edition of "Ainsworth and Bisbsy's Dictionary of the fungi". There are about  100 specimens of mosses, and about 700 specimens of lichens stored in cardboard boxes.

importantCollectors: ['G. Arbeláez Serna', 'M. C. Vélez Nauer', 'C. A. Agudleo Henao']
notes:
HUQ HISTORY:  
FOUNDERS: Germán Arbeláez Serna and María Cristina Vélez Nauer, professors of the Degree Program in Biology at the University of Quindío. This process was supported directly by SANTIAGO DIAZ PIEDRAHITA of the Herbarium COL.
HUQ INVESTIGATORS: Carlos Alberto Agudelo H., María del Pilar Sepúlveda, Germán Darío Gómez M., Andrés Felipe Orozco C., Ana Lucía López G., Rocío Stella Suárez, Ricardo Elías Vega, Carlos Alberto López R., Paula Andrea Viveros , Johan Carvajal, Larri Álvarez, Juan Fernando Restrepo, Carlos Alonso Maya, Rigoberto Villa, Rodolfo López, Nodier Augusto Botero, Jaime Uribe Meléndez, Neyver Rivera, Martha Chacón, among others. Among the administrative staff stands out Edier Flórez Henao.
PUBLICATIONS: HUQ researchers have published numerous publications (approximately 100) in journals such as Flora de Colombia (Asteraceae and Amaranthaceae), Caldasia (Amaranthaceae), Biological News, Novon, Catalogs (Flora de Antioquia and Flora de Venezuela), abstract books of scientific events, among others. Books on taxonomy of mosses, Euphorbiaceae, wax palm, flórulas of some localities, four volumes of the magazine Flora Andina, etc. There are also online publications such as the Amaranthaceae in Neotropical Flowering Plants at https://www.kew.org/science/tropamerica/neotropikey.htm.
YOUNG RESEARCHERS: At least 10 young Colombians, biologists and graduates in Biology, funded by COLCIENCIAS have passed through HUQ and have developed studies on flora, palynology, taxonomy, ecology, among others.
INTERNATIONAL TRAINERS: Several interns from Croatia, Slovenia, Portugal, Brazil and Austria have conducted training and learning about the Andean flora in HUQ.
INTERNATIONAL NETWORKS: The HUQ belongs to the Latin American Association of Botany - ALB, through Carlos A. Agudelo has participated as a member of the Superior Council of the ALB between 2010 and 2018, is also part of the Colombian Herbarium Association - ACH, of which he was President between 1998 and 1999 with Carlos A. Agudelo and is linked to the Global Initiative project of plants to type the world types in JSTOR through Felipe Orozco. We also work in a network with researchers from the University of Luján and La Matanza, Argentina through a binational agreement. With Venezuelan researchers participated in the elaboration of the New Catalog of the Flora of Venezuela, through Carlos A. Agudelo Amaranthaceae was reviewed for that country.
MASTERY IN SCIENCES VEGETABLE BIOLOGY: the HUQ collection, its literature and researchers were fundamental to propose the creation of the Master in 2002 before the Ministry of National Education of Colombia. Through this program 28 botanists have graduated and by 2018 there are 25 more active.
SCIENTIFIC EVENTS: The HUQ staff has carried out numerous local, regional, national and international scientific events (symposiums, congresses), courses, workshops, forums, diplomas (Organic Agriculture, protected areas and medicinal plants (the latter led by Orozco C., being very successful), botanical expeditions, have participated in the Latin American congresses of Botany of the ALB such as Cartagena in Colombia 2002, Santo Domingo in Dominican Republic 2006, La Serena in Chile 2010 and Salvador de Bahia in Brazil in 2014. The same They prepare to attend the XII Congress of Quito, Ecuador in 2018. They are part of the organizers of the biology regional symposiums held biannually among teachers from UTP, U. de Caldas, UNISARC and UniQuindío.

This herbarium has been developed based on research collaborations with other herbaria such as KEW and RB.  HERBAM participates in Brazilian projects about biodiversity studies such as BIONORTE (Biodiversity of the North of the Brazil), PPBIO (Biodiversity Brazilian Programm) ; REFLORA (repatriation of specimens KEW and Paris Museum); National Brazilian Forestry Inventory/IFN/SFB; Teles Pires river basin Dams.
The herbarium staff  consists of post graduate students and scholarship holder and specialist volunteers  who have  been contribuited  species identifications, such as William Milliken, Daniela Zappi and others. Duplicates are sent to RB and KEW.

importantCollectors: ['K. Kawakita', 'M. B. Romagnolo', 'Ma. C. Souza', 'C.E.B. Fernandes']
notes: Nupélia herbarium currently has researchers as well as graduate students (UEM) and  PIBIC fellows  through CNPq and Araucaria Foundation,  and  volunteers and interns. The main objective of the collection is documenting  the riparian flora, including surveys, taxonomic identification and dissemination for both  the scientific and general communities, and to generate subsidies for ecological studies, conservation of biodiversity, land reclamation and sustainable development, particularly riparian areas of the Upper Paraná River floodplain. It is the database of various theses and dissertations related to floristic and phytosociological surveys and Phanerogams taxonomy. Functionally and structurally the herbarium  is linked to Nupélia. It is in computerization phase and available online by the Biological Collections Network of Paraná-Taxonline State and splink the CRIA. The herbarium is located in Block G-80 and open for consultation by experts appointment with coordination.

importantCollectors: ['M. Badura', 'M. Buliński', 'W. Chojnacki', 'W. Fałtynowicz', 'B. Hajek', 'M. Herbich', 'J. Herbich', 'M. Kukwa', 'M. Latałowa', 'R. Markowski', 'H. Piotrowska', 'J. Stasiak', 'T. Sulma', 'D. L. Szlachetko', 'W. Żukowski']
notes:
The UGDA Herbarium has the following collections:
- UGDA-Plants - collection of vascular plants
- UGDA-L - lichen collection
- UGDA-B - bryophyte collection
- UGDA-Orchid - Orchid plant collection
- UGDA-LQ - wet and preparation collection (mainly plants of the family Orchidaceae)
- UGDA-Figure - collection of Figures (Orchidaceae family)
- CRefColl-UGDA - carpological and palynoligical collection

We are a member of National Biodiversity Information Network (Krajowa Sieć Informacji o Bioróżnorodności). 
Species occurrence data based on our collections can be found in the Global Biodiversity Information Facility - GBIF.
Part of our herbarium collection is available on the Herbarium Pomeranicum website - https://herbariumpomeranicum.pl/.

organization: Embrapa Recursos Genéticos e Biotecnologia - Embrapa Cenargen
taxonomicCoverage: The Herbarium CEN collection is rich in specimens of the Cerrado flora, and collections from the Caatinga and Amazon have also grown. The  collection is considered one of the most representative in groups such as Arachis, Capsicum, Cuphea, Cyrtopodium, Diplusodon, Habenaria, Manihot, Mimosa, Paspalum and Stylosanthes. particularly rich in families such as Arecaceae, Asteraceae, Euphorbiaceae, Leguminosae, Lythraceae, Orchidaceae and Poaceae. Also noteworthy are economic plants and wild relatives of food, ornamental, medicinal, forest species, grasses and forage legumes.
importantCollectors: ['A. Amaral-Santos', 'A. C. Allem', 'A. C. Sevilha', 'A. O. Scariot', 'B. M. T. Walter', 'G. Pereira-Silva', 'M. S. Fragomeni', 'T. B. Cavalcanti.']
notes:
The CEN Herbarium is fully informatized and has all the collection available online (see herbarium homepage above). All specimen images from the collection are available on Specieslink database.
Since 2010, all the collections carried out by the staff of the Herbarium CEN are also accompanied by samples of leaves in silica gel that are sent when requested.

organization: Botanical Garden Dr. B.M. Kozo-Polyansky, Voronezh State University
taxonomicCoverage: Regional and world flora as well as the introduced flora of the Botanical Garden
importantCollectors: ['M. A. Klevsova', 'B. I. Kuznetsov', 'L. A. Lepeshkina', 'V. I. Serikova']
notes: Entered Dec 2013.   The specimens are used in the compilation of regional floras, for identification, as well as in the study of geography, ecology, biology, physiology of different species of plants. Thus, the herbarium materials are used in the refinement of the conservation status and geography of rare plant species as recommended in the Red Data Book of the Voronezh region. New specimens are being accessioned from the  little-studied areas of the Central Black Soil and adjacent territories. Other areas of collection development include protected species, medicinal, food, and essential oil plants, as well as decorative plants.  A database of the herbarium is in development.

importantCollectors: ['H. T. Binh', 'N. D. Chinh', 'L. B. Dung', 'L. V. Dung', 'L. V. Ngoc', 'N. V. Ngoc', 'T. B. Nguyen', 'T. V. Tien', 'N. V. Tiep']
notes: Entered Feb 2014.  The Herbarium of Da Lat University (DLU) is one of the largest herbaria in Plateau of Vietnam, with over 6.000 sheets of vascular plants from around Vietnam. And emphasis is on plants from Plateau. Graduate and undergraduate students use herbarium material to identify plants and determine plant locations. Tours are conducted for numerous school groups, and other organizations. In addition, the collection grows steadily through local field work and donated material; and students at DLU, especially those involved with floristic work, deposit their voucher sets for their projects at the Herbarium.

taxonomicCoverage: Briophytes; Marchantiophyta; Aquatic Araceae; Aquatic Salvinales; Algae; Cyanobacteria
importantCollectors: ['N. Bondoc', 'J. H. Jung', 'A. Zafaver']
notes: Entered Feb 2025.  Brock's Microphyte Collection at Brock University aims to maintain a living collection (fresh cultures, agar plates or cryopreserved) of microscopic phototrophs of the Niagara region (Southern Ontario). Our interest include algae (uni- and multicellular), cyanobacteria, certain types of protists, Briophytes; Marchantiophytes and some minute aquatic plants  (e.g., Araceae or  Salvinales). We aim to provide specimens for teaching purposes, outreach, basic and applied research.   We also host fix specimens in microscope slides and we are in the process of sequencing isolated monocultures.
As of 2017, this record has not been updated in over 15 years.

organization: Marine Science Institute, University of the Philippines
taxonomicCoverage: 500 genera of marine plants (about 96 % are marine benthic algae and 4% are seagrasses). The herbarium also contains PACSEA  (Pacific Seaboard Collection)
geography: Collected from 70 countries; 93% are Philippine species
importantCollectors: ['T. Trono', 'G. T. Velasquez']
notes: Entered Aug 2011.  It was through the efforts of Dr. Gavino C. Trono Jr. that this marine plants herbarium was established in the early 1970's.  The Marine Science Institute (then the Marine Sciences Center) provided the seed money.  The late Dr. Velasquez donated all his algal collections to this herbarium, thus it carried his name in acknowledgment of his generous contribution. The seagrass collection of Dr. Miguel D. Fortes was later added to the herbarium. It was Dr. Edna G. Fortes who computerized the herbarium starting in 1987 with funds from the International Development Research Centre of Canada.

Puff', 'J. Bosser', 'H. Humbert', 'M. Keraudren-Aymonin', 'B. C. Stone', 'R. Decary', 'G. W. Reynolds', 'J. M. H. A. Perrier de la Bâthie', 'L. J. Dorr', 'J. D. Leandri', 'W. Rauh', 'H.-J. E. Schlieben', 'G. Cours', 'L. C. Barnett']
notes:
The main activities at TAN Herbarium are the following
- Conservation of herbarium 350 000 mounted specimens divided into 280 families, 1 885 genera and 8 745 species (2019)
- Inventory and collection of herbarium specimens
- Receipt of collected botanical samples from plant collectors
- Mandated by the Malagasy Government to receive the duplicate of specimens collected by foreign and national researchers before any specimens exportation.
- Digitizing and data-basing by using Botanical Research And Herbarium Management System (BRAHMS) software.
- Support tools for foreign and national researchers and high school students. 
- Assessment, review of conservation status of malagasy plants.
- Partnership with national institutions (Herbier TEF, DBEV and ENS) and international organizations (MBG, RBG Kew, CAS, HBV and IRD).
- Supervision of trainee students from public and private universities (on average 60 per year).

notes: The Herbarium of Iran's National Museum of Natural History was first formed in the 1970’s with the proposal of Professor Karl Heinz Rechinger, famous Austrian botanist . This Herbarium has been created in the Department of Environment of  Iran with the aim of gathering and maintaining the plant diversity of areas managed by the Department of Environment of  Iran and specific habitats.  It is to be hoped that in the near future, we will see the development and promotion of this valuable collection by increasing the space and facilities provided, including cabinet rails and assistance of other botanist researchers at the national level.

division: Lab of Systematic Botany and Phytogeography
importantCollectors: ['T. von Heldreich', 'T. G. Orphanides', 'V. Tuntas', 'J. Sartori', 'D. Zaganiaris', 'K. Ganiatsas', 'G. Lavrendiades', 'E. Drossos', 'D. Babalonas', 'V. Karagiannakidou']
notes:
The accurate number of TAU specimens is not known, but it is estimated to c. 70,000. Each year at least 1,000 specimens are added. Most of the specimens come from Greece, but there are also several specimens from European countries and a few from other continents. The collections are divided in two sections: the new and the historical. 
The new collections include specimens of previous and current members of the Lab, as well as specimens of postgraduate students and doctoral candidates. Among them there are collections from: 
•	several mountainous areas and wetlands, mainly from Epirus, Macedonia and Thrace, including many areas of the NATURA 2000 network,
•	urban and rural areas,
•	a particularly rich collection of Lamiaceae plants

The historical collections of TAU hold more than 6,000 specimens, dating back from the early 19th century up to the late 30’s. Most come from the collections of Theodor von Heldreich, Theodore Orphanides, Joseph Sartori, Vasileios Tountas and Dimitrios Zaganiaris, as well as of many others.  There are at least 44 nomenclatural types, as well as many endemic and range restricted taxa. Perhaps the most valuable of the historical collections are those of Dimitrios Zaganiaris, which include more than 3,000 specimens and are kept, to the best of our knowledge, only in TAU.

division: School of Biosciences and Veterinary Medicine
department: Plant Biodiversity and Ecosystems Management unit
importantCollectors: ['S. Ballelli', 'C. Cortini Pedrotti', 'V. Marchesoni']
notes:
The herbarium consists of about 250,000 samples of vascular species and about 15,000 Bryophyte.
The part dedicated to the vascular flora is organized in distinct sections for geographical areas and includes exsiccata coming mainly from Marche, Umbria, Trentino Alto-Adige and Abruzzo.
A part of the Herbarium is dedicated to the “Montagna di Torricchio” National Reserve, owned by the University of Camerino since 1970, managed by researchers of the “Plant Biodiversity and Ecosystem Management” unit in the School of Biosciences and Veterinary Medicine, University of Camerino.
A small section is due to the monitoring of the plant diversity of forests (CONECOFOR) in the framework of the international cooperation program ""ICP Forests"".
The Herbarium is available for consultation by the national and international scientific community and for the exchange of samples with other Italian and foreign Universities.
In 2018 the Herbarium also joined the ""CoRIMBo"" project (Coordination of the Italian Network of Botanical Museums) of the Italian Botanical Society [updated Dec 2019]

Founded in the 1960’s by biology professor William F. Penfound, the herbarium at Warren Wilson College houses approximately 7200 specimens of vascular plants, as well as small collections of non-vascular plants and lichens.  The herbarium is used regularly by faculty as a teaching resource, by students as a reference for study and research, and by the farm, garden, forestry, and landscaping crews as an identification tool.
