taxonomicCoverage: Vascular plants (90%), lichen and moss species
geography: North America, particularly the Midwest (58%) / Great Lakes Region
importantCollectors: ['E. E. Atwater', 'H. H. Babcock', 'W. W. Calkins', 'M. A. Chase', 'V. H. Chase', 'W. K. Higley', 'E. J. Hill', 'A. P. Kummer', 'W. S. Moffatt', 'H. S. Pepoon', 'F. A. Swink', 'L. M. Umbach']
notes: The Academy’s herbarium contains over 15,900 catalogued specimens, largely collected in the Midwest (58%), with a large proportion (60%) collected prior to 1900.  This portion of the herbarium contains mainly vascular plants, as well as some fungi (7%), bryophytes (1.5%), and algae (1.5%). Critically, the collection houses 19th century vouchers for six federally threatened and endangered species, including the sand dune thistle (Cirsium pitcheri) and the leafy prairie clover (Dalea foliosa), which are native to Great Lakes sand dune and Illinois prairie habitats. Just over 2,000 specimens from the Midwest have been digitally scanned and jpegs are available for research. The herbarium also contains a backlog of approximately 6,000 uncatalogued 19th century pressed plants. Nearly 90% of the backlog specimens are vascular plants collected in the Midwest and Great Lakes region.

taxonomicCoverage: Especially vascular plants of two large families, Asteraceae (<Artemisia>) and Amaryllidaceae (<Allium>)
importantCollectors: ['Y. Ajani', 'E. Aryakia', 'A. Dolatyari', 'H. Moazzeni', 'H. Ramezani', 'A. Talebi', 'K. Hazrati', 'S. Abdollahi']
notes:
Although only several years passed from the establishment of our Herbarium, we have actively tried to collect and document Iranian plant specimens over the past decade, especially vascular plants of the two large families, Asteraceae (genus Artemisia) and Amaryllidaceae (genus Allium). What is remarkable about our activities is that beside each Herbarium voucher we tried to collect also seed or living materials. Currently all these materials are preserved under optimal conditions in herbarium cabinets (dried sheets), refrigerators and/or freezers (usually seeds) or under cultivation in our living collections (bulbous or rhizomatous plants). We devoted an extra code (IBRC code) than herbarium numbers to each specimen to link easily different types of collected materials.     

Hitherto, our team had more than 300 working days mission our country wide to collect both herbarium and living material of special Iranian flora. In parallel to our Center policy, we are going to raise continuously our collections inventories. 

Recently, we decided to gradually digitize our determined and labeled sheets and put them available via internet. Interested researchers can see so far prepared specimens online via this internet address: http://ibrc.ir/index.aspx?fkeyid=&siteid=1&pageid=466&siteid=1

department: Department of Biological and Environmental Sciences
taxonomicCoverage: Bryophytes, Lichens, Pterophytes, Gymnosperms and Angiosperms
importantCollectors: ['E. F. Andrews', 'A. W. Chapman']
notes:
The Troy University Herbarium (TROY) was established in 1954 as a teaching herbarium by Dr. Robert Dietz, who served as curator.  In 1961, the herbarium was moved from its original location in the basement of Bibb Graves Hall into the new science building, McCall Hall.  This 528 ft2 room served both as the herbarium and a paleobotany laboratory.  It remained in this location until 1988 when Dietz retired.  At that time, the herbarium was closed and all of the specimens were destroyed.  In 1997, the TROY Herbarium was reestablished by Dr. Alvin Diamond and Dr. Michael Woods.  In 1999, the collection had grown to approximately 3500 mounted specimens and the herbarium was moved to rooms 125 and 127 of the Math Science Complex (MSCX) (formally McCall Hall).  The two rooms totaled 443 ft2, which resulted in a 16% reduction in floor space from the previous location.  At the end of 2005, with 19 herbarium cabinets and a collection of approximately 19,000 mounted specimens, the herbarium had outgrown its space.  The Curators wrote a five-year plan for the herbarium and submitted it to the Troy University Administration.  With support of the Department Chair, Dean, Assistant Provost, and Provost, the herbarium was moved during 2006 to its current location, MSCX 216, which consists of 1058 ft2.  Since moving to its current location, the collection has grown to over 44,000 specimens with an average annual growth of over 2,000.  This makes TROY one of the fastest-growing herbarium in the southeastern United States.  Currently, 100 percent of all vascular plant specimens deposited in the TROY Herbarium have been databased and imaged.  Additionally, nonvascular plants have been databased. 

In 2017, the Dean of the College of Arts and Sciences (CAS) approved an additional 220 square foot room (MSCX 223) immediately across the hallway from the herbarium (MSCX 216).  This will allow us to relocate the plant dryer, freezer, mounting table, shelving for storage, filing cabinet for records pertaining to loans and exchanges, two data basing computers and imaging equipment to MSCX 223.  This will increase the safety of the collection by keeping all specimens outside of the herbarium until they have been processed and frozen.  
  All Alabama specimens are available on the Alabama Plant Atlas http://floraofalabama.org/

The Herbarium Generale holds the plant and fungi material from around the world, excluding Lower Silesia, Poland (about 375,000 specimens, including about 75,000 spore-bearing organisms). The Herbarium 1Lauterbachi keeps plants from New Guinea and Melanesia (about 50,000 sheets), and the Herbarium Silesiacum – plants from Lower Silesia, Poland (about 90,000 specimens). According to the website, many early collections were damaged by WWII.  WRSL same as BRSL. Use WRSL.

notes: Updated Nov 2016 (Notes update). GH is fully integrated with A and AMES in the Harvard University Herbaria, but specimens from Gray Herbarium should be cited as GH. The 1 943 000 specimens in GH are included in the total given for the Harvard University Herbaria (listed under GH). The previously separate Harvard herbaria (A, AMES, ECON, FH, GH) were fully integrated in the 1980s and are now administered as a single unit. Although loans of vascular plants from the Harvard University Herbaria will include appropriate specimens from A, AMES, ECON, and GH, and also material from the New England Botanical Club Herbarium (NEBC), specimens cited in publications should use the standard abbreviations for each of those herbaria. Correspondence regarding specimens should not be sent to the separate institutions, but to huh-requests@oeb.harvard.edu. Work space can be provided for both long- and short-term visitors; written requests, especially for long-term visitors, should be sent to Michaela Schmull (mschmull@oeb.harvard.edu). Also available for study are 50 000 paleobotanical specimens, 33 000 specimens of wood, 38 000 microscope slides of wood, 15 000 slides of other plant parts in the Bailey-Wetmore Wood Collection (Aw), and 11 000 pollen slides.

notes: Entered Jun 2016.  The collection of algae is related to the Biological Collection of the Universidad Católica Norte at Coquimbo (http://www.redbiodiversidad.cl/ ) which is associated to the Chilean Biodiversity network, related to several universities, to the Minister of the Environment and to the National Natural History Museum (SGO). The collection includes about 1150 specimens. This is material in sheet form, algae fundamentally from the Chilean coast, Mediterranean coast, the US and the Caribbean. The information is computerized and continues to grow. The Herbarium is deposited at the Faculty of Marine Sciences. The collection is part of the Marine Botany Laboratory, and it constitutes an element of support for research and teaching in the university. This service is intended to provide scientific and technical support for research groups, public institutions and private companies.

PLEASE NOTE that in general DAV is no longer accepting unsolicited exchange, however, we are interested in new weeds of the U.S., rare plants of California, and other species that would help complete our collections. notes:
The Herbario Amazónico del Ecuador, ECUAMZ, is part of the Universidad Estatal Amazónica (UEA), a public university, the main campus of which is in Puyo, the capital of Pastaza province.  The herbarium is located  at the university`s research center, ""Centro de Investigación, Postgrado y Conservación Amazónica, known by the acronym CIPCA, 44 km  north of Puyo along the road to Tena (Ecuador highway 45, kilometer 319).  The CIPCA center is 3 km north of the town of Santa Clara, Pastaza, and 10 km south of the town of Carlos Julio Arosemena Tola, Napo province.  The CIPCA property includes 2848 hectares of which about 2000 hectares are primary forest at 600-1100 m elevation near the base of the Andes, and frontage along the Anzu and Piatua rivers.   The herbarium includes collections made in Ecuador since 1985, as well  as recent collections since 2012 by herbarium staff and collaborators.

The ECUAMZ herbarium is normally open to visitor Monday-Friday, 8:30 to 16:30, but is closed at present due to the virus pandemic (June 2020)



on the outskirts of Puyo, Pastaza.  In mid-2013, the herbarium will move to permanent quarters at the University`s research station, the ""Centro de Investigación Postgrado y Conservación Amazónica"

Welcome to Stephen F. Austin Herbarium (ASTC), which contains nearly 80,000 specimens and is the 4th largest collection in Texas. The collection's Director is Dr. James Van Kley, Curator Imani Harris, and long-time employee Macauley Parker. Although the collection includes specimens from throughout North America, its focus is on the East Texas Pineywoods, where it represents nearly all the native and naturalized species found in the region. The herbarium plays a vital role in teaching and provides crucial plant identification support to our research in vegetation science. We also entertain loan requests and facilitate specimen exchanges with other herbaria.

notes: NGCPR works in flowering plant taxonomy, mainly on endemics of the northern Western Ghats. The Centre has undertaken digitisation work in August 2020, till date more than 700 specimens have been databased and 117 (Commelinaceae) are imaged. We represents the collections from lateritic plateaus, hilltops from the peninsular India, as well as occasional collection from Deccan Plateaus, eastern Karnataka, Eastern Ghats and Andaman and Nicobar Islands. The material for the treatment of the following genera in India viz. Grewia, Salacia, and Ledebouria are in process of incorporation. Similarly, NGCPR has an important endemic plant collection made under Dalzell's Plant species programme.

DSUM has been transferred to BHSC.   The Dakota State University Herbarium  was originally housed in a small rural university in south central South Dakota.  The collection  focused on plants collected regionally in the glacial prairie-pothole lake region of transition tall grass-short grass prairie of the Northern Great Plains  In addition to serving as a resource for teaching, the herbarium was a temporal and spatial repository of plants collected periodically during the rapid conversion of native prairie to cropland during the 20th Century.  This conversion accelerated during the century and continues today.  A very small diminishing fraction of native prairie remains.  Because of the regional emphasis of the collections, the  herbarium served as a resource to allow research on species composition and distribution regionally as affected by global warming and global climate change.

notes:
San Juan College Herbarium is curated by founder and Professor Emeritus of Biology, Kenneth D. Heil. Heil is the author of numerous publications, along with the Flora of the Four Corners Region. Currently Heil is working on the New Mexico Flora, publishing the book with Missouri Botanical Garden Press.
San Juan College has the largest herbarium collection of the Four Corners Region. Along with collections from the following Tribal Lands and United States Government Agencies: Navajo Nation, Jicarilla Apache, Southern Ute Tribe, Ute Mountain Ute Indian Reservations, San Juan National Forest, Carson National Forest, Aztec Ruins National Monument, Natural Bridges National Monument, Capitol Reef National Monument, Arches National Park, Mesa Verde National Park, and Canyonlands National Park.

division: City of Portland, Portland Parks and Recreation
taxonomicCoverage: Broad taxonomic coverage with focus on Hoyt Arboretum’s living tree collection, especially Magnolia, Acer and temperate gymnosperms.
geography: Worldwide temperate tree species. Some local Pacific Northwest natives and invasive non-natives, street trees, Portland Heritage trees.
importantCollectors: ['E. Riggs', 'M. Tu']
notes:
The Hoyt Arboretum Herbarium’s primary focus is to document and verify the arboretum’s internationally-renowned living tree collection, which currently has over 2,500 species. We aim to voucher every species in our living collection, adding approximately 300 to 500 herbarium sheets per year. Additionally, HAH functions as a reference library for City of Portland staff and partners, especially in the identification of regionally significant invasive weeds and street trees. 
 
Herbarium specimens and our living tree collection can be remotely accessed through  our online plant inventory (https://hoytarboretum.gardenexplorer.org/) and we are working to get our specimen data and images available online through the regional Consortium of Pacific Northwest Herbaria (https://www.pnwherbaria.org/).

The merger of all collections from the University of Missouri Dunn-Palmer Herbarium (UMO) into the Missouri Botanical Garden Herbarium (MO) is now complete, with the exception of the lichen specimens, which were deposited at KANU..  All information regarding the former UMO specimens should be directed to MO or KANU.  Approximately 125,000 UMO records were already extant on MO’s TROPICOS database, and the rest will be added as time and staff at MO permits.

notes: In Uzbekistan, rich herbarium collections of extant plants as well as a valuable palaeobotanical collection have been gathered since the first herbarium of this region was founded in 1920. Prior to 1988, these collections were housed at the Tashkent State University (TAK), the Tashkent Pedagogic Institute, the Nature Museum of Uzbekistan (RNMUT), the former Samarkand State University, and the Institutes of Botany (TASH), of Microbiology (TASM), and of Chemistry of Plant Materials, belonging to the Academy of Sciences of the Republic Uzbekistan. In 1988 these herbaria were combined as the Central Herbarium of the Academy of Sciences of the Republic Uzbekistan and housed at the Botanical Institute. The acronym T ASH is to be used for the Central Herbarium.

notes: Some specimens have been digitized, especially types, and records available in Virtual Herbaria: http://herbarium.univie.ac.at/database/search.php. Loan requests for type specimens must state exact details about place of publication, synonyms, type-locality, etc. Specimens are not arranged in geographical order, so general requests such as \""all species of genus X from South America\"" cannot be accepted. Part of the phanerogam collection was destroyed by war accidents, corresponding to numbers 1-100, 452-1388, 1855-2828 of Dalla Torre & Harms, Genera Siphonogamarum (see Taxon 1: 29). Orchidaceae of H. G. L. Reichenbach and Juncaceae of F. G. T. Buchenau are not sent on loan. Attached to W are collections of fruits, seeds, and wood samples. About 180 000 botanical drawings and paintings (e.g., those of F. L. Bauer, N. J. and J. F. von Jacquin, C. A. A. Huegel, H. W. Schott, and H. G. Reichenbach) and botanical manuscripts and correspondence (e.g., letters to N. J. von Jacquin, S. L. Endlicher, H. G. L. and H. G. Reichenbach, and H. Lojka) are located in the Archives at the moment.

notes:
Updated May 2016 (correspondent  update).   The Herbarium contains:
 1. Nomenclatural types: 3031 
2. Historical: important collections made by Ducke (8,571 samples), Goeldi, A. (376 samples), Huber (2,500 samples), Snethlage, E. (257 samples),Spruce (396 samples), Tresling (92 samples), Ule (2,788 samples).
3. Fungous and lichens:  3.895  specimens,especially Basidiomycotinae, Ascomycotae, Myxomicotinae, and historical collections 
4. Bryophytes:  7,699 specimens,  96 of which are types.
5. Ferns: 5,311 specimens
6. Seedlings:  179s vouchers specimens.   
10. Fruits and seeds:  3,128 specimens.
11. Pollen:  2245 microscope slides of Amazonian species.
12. Histological: 700 microscope slides of vegetative organs (root, stems and leaves).
13. Wood:  ca.  7814 vouchers and a  collection of histological sections on slides.
14. Essential oils - 900 samples.

notes: Updated Jun 2015. The HUCS Herbarium is a collection located in the northeast region of the Rio Grande do Sul state, Brazil. It includes specimens of different local ecosystems, mostly of Araucaria Forest and Grassland vegetation. Nowadays the herbarium directs its sampling activities in the recognition of the coastal plain vegetation. At the same time, it has developed environmental education actions along with the Botanical Garden of Caxias do Sul.

division: Centre for Australian National Biodiversity Research
notes: Updated Aug 2016 (gecoordinates updated)   The herbarium collections, staff, databases, and research programs of the Australian National Botanic Gardens (CBG) were combined with those of the Australian National Herbarium (CANB) as part of the jointly managed and funded Centre for Australian National Biodiversity Research.  CANB was adopted as the herbarium abbreviation for the combined collections.  Specimens originally from CBG will continue to be cited as CBG. The approximately 250 000 CBG specimens are included in the total for CANB. Information regarding CBG is included with CANB.  Correspondence, including loan requests, should be directed to CANB.  Non-angiosperms are stored in a different building, at -35.278329, 149.108841.

US fungi (except lichens) were transferred to BPI. US has collections from the United States South Pacific Exploring Expedition (1838-1842), the United States North Pacific Exploring Expedition (1853-1856), LaPlata Expedition (1853-1856), Mexican Boundary Survey (1854-1855), California Geological Survey (1860-1867), International Boundary Commission of United States and Mexico (1892-1894), Colombia Cinchona missions (1940-1945), Bureau of Science (Philippines), Harriman Alaskan Expedition, and Regnell Expeditions (Brazil).

importantCollectors: ['J Scouler']
notes:
GGO (13,000 specimens) transferred to GLAM in 1991.
Currently housed by at Glasgow Museums Resource Centre
See http://collections.glasgowmuseums.com/mwebcgi/mweb?request=record;id=533630;type=801

The herbarium started with the collection of Professor John Scouler and his collection formed the basis of the herbarium from his death (1871), where it was worked on by Professor Roger Hennedy (who also collected specimens).

Strathclyde University was previously named the Royal College of Science and Technology (even earlier as the Andersonian Institute founded in 1796)
References:
Lloyd, B (1964). The Herbarium of the Royal College of Science and Technology Glasgow. Glasgow Naturalist Vol 18, Part 7, 363 - 368

Macpherson, P & Watson, K J (1996). Strathclyde University Herbarium - Computerised Database. Glasgow Naturalist Vol 23 Part 1, 7 - 8

organization: Mirpur University of Science and Technology (MUST), Mirpur-10250 (AJK) Pakistan
taxonomicCoverage: Plants (Bryohytes; Pteridophytes; Gymnosperms and Angiosperms), Fungi
importantCollectors: ['Dr. Mehwish Maqbool is In-char com/']
notes: Entered Nov 2016.  MUH is currently set up under the aegis of Department of Botany, Mirpur University of Science & Technology (MUST) Mirpur-10250 (AJK) Pakistan. Botanical Library is available to researchers, students, amateur botanists and horticulturists. Albeit library has enough national and international books, articles, journals and monograph reprints. MUH has 2448 plant Voucher samples (different species) 3000 Seed Germ (SG) plasm (36 families) collection of wild plants of Azad Jammu and Kashmir and Pakistan. MUH has plenty of photographs, botanical art and artifacts on vegetation of the area depicting its conservation status. Currently herbaria specimens has reached 2448 and it is increasing day by day due to continuous efforts of researchers and collectors.

notes: The mission of the Herbarium “IRAN” is to document, preserve, archive and expand the collection to make a thorough representation of Iranian flora, comprising vascular- and non-vascular plants, fungi, lichens, and fungus-like organisms, with particular emphasis on important taxa in plant protection. organization: Kamloops Herbarium at Grassland Applied Technology Centre - AAFC
geography: Rangelands of British Columbia including grasslands and dry, open Douglas Fir and Ponderosa Pine, but also alpine areas that were used for sheep which were once herded over extensive areas ranging from low Sagebrush grassland to the alpine zone
notes: Updated Dec 2014.  ACK is fully integrated in to DAO. ACK Herbarium specimens should be cited as DAO. All correspondence relative to loans and exchanges should be with DAO. The valuable \""Prince George Collection\"" was apparently developed to assist with identification of local flora, and was sent to ACK after closure of the AAFC unit at Prince George. The specimens were collected mostly by J. Sawitski and R.D. Marsh in 1960, 1969, 1970 and 1971. Major collectors along with number of specimens collected include: G. Beke (169) V.C. Brink (123), B. Brooke (200), D. Demarchi (59), J. W. Eastham (41), J. Finstad (88), L. Haupt (198), L. Marchand (95), K. McLaren (45), A. McLean (960), W.L. Pringle (150), B. Storey (39), E. W. Tisdale (658), B. Wikeem (42), and others with 30 or less.
Updated Sep 2017 (status).  PEI in storage. No loans. Original herbarium destroyed by fire in 1951.
As of 2017, this record has not been updated in over 15 years. Formerly listed under REGINA.

The botanical collections at the Swedish Museum of Natural History (S) have been closed for several years due to renovations, but are now open again for loans. For loan requests, donations and any other collections-related queries, please contact us using the herbarium@nrm.se address. We will gradually open for visits to the collections during the second half of 2025.

notes: Entered Mar 2025.  This herbarium is located in Nowshahr Botanical Garden in the north of Iran. It is the main herbarium for the Hyrcanian zone in the Eurosiberian region of Iranian phytogeographical regions. Most of our activities focus on the dendrology study of the Hyrcanian forest and seed plants. Our site is one of the most important bryological research in Iran.

importantCollectors: ['S. Burns', 'J. E. Burrows', 'I. S. Collenette', 'N. R. Crouch', 'H. F. Glen', 'O. Maurin', 'D. M. McMurtry', 'S. M. Muller', 'L. N. Prosser', 'B. C. Turpin']
notes:
Entered Feb 2014. The herbarium moved from Johannesburg to Nelspruit area during 1998. The herbarium building, which  incorporates the  library and an annex for mounting and freezing of specimens at Whyte Thorne, was inaugurated in Feb 2001. The herbarium has been privately owned and funded from inception in 1967. The Herbarium, Library and Garden are open to all bona-fide botanically motivated persons. Whyte Thorne Botanic Garden has been developed on the same property, consisting  of 23 hectares of which six acres comprise the laid –out garden and nursery including a 900sq m shade house & 34sq m propagation house. WTBG is a privately sponsored botanic Garden with 8300 living plant accessions, 6500 living plant orchid accessions and 11990 seed accessions. Accession numbers are cross-referenced to herbarium material where appropriate.
D. McMurtry collecting numbers currently stand at 15200 of which ±7500 pressed specimens are lodged at the Johannesburg Botanic Garden Herbarium, the rest in HSMC. Duplicates in PRE and BNRH. Specimens mostly from the four northern provinces of S.Af. but include Zimbabwe, Mozambique, Namibia, Tanzania, Kenya, St Helena, Reunion, Madagascar and Comores . Carpological Spirit material (mostly Orchidaceae) collections maintained.

notes: Updated Mar 2017 (contact updated).   The Hugh Nicholson and Tony Abbott Herbarium is a collection of flora mainly of the Pondoland Centre of Endemism (PCE), which forms part of the Maputaland-Pondoland-Albany region of endemism, one of only 34 internationally recognised areas of conservation significance. The PCE herbarium is housed in the Umtamvuna Nature Reserve, a formally protected area managed by the provincial nature conservation agency, Ezemvelo KwaZulu-Natal Wildlife, and is staffed by local volunteers. For continuity, the first point of contact is the Ezemvelo KwaZulu-Natal Wildlife District Ecologist for the central and southeastern region of the province.  From there correspondence will be directed to the relevant person(s) to deal with queries.

The Stellenbosch University Herbarium has been downscaled, now only to include historical collections of southern African Pelargonium and Zygophyllum. These collections include many type specimens. In addition there is a regional (Stellenbosch area) collection which is maintained but not expanded. For the rest, the herbarium is dedicated to the research collections of current staff of Department of Botany and Zoology at Stellenbosch University.

There is no curator. Prof. L Dreyer overseas the academic management of the herbarium, and Me. Law-Brown takes care of physical curation of the regional and specialist collections. Each academic staff member curates and maintains their own research collections.
TRV transferred to PRE.

taxonomicCoverage: Andean Flora; Angiosperms, Gimnosperms, Lichens, Ferns, Bryophytes, fungy; Economically important plants and weedy species; Andean plant genetic resources, especially fruits and trees. The following families are the most representatives: Asteraceae (1573), Fabaceae (1484), Poaceae (1044), Rubiaceae (1009), Solanaceae (805), Melastomataceae (624), Orchidaceae (520), Malvaceae (425), Araceae (424) y Euphorbiaceae (423). Also we count specimes of the families: Acanthaceae, Actinidiaceae, Alstroemeriaceae, Amaranthaceae, Anacardiaceae, Annonaceae, Apiaceae, Apocynaceae, Aquifoliaceae, Araceae, Araliaceae, Arthoniaceae, Aspleniaceae, Asteraceae, Athyriaceae, Baeomycetaceae, Balanophoraceae, Bartramiaceae, Begoniaceae, Bixaceae, Blechnaceae, Brassicaceae, Bromeliaceae, Bryaceae, Caliciaceae, Campanulaceae, Candelariaceae, Cannabaceae, Caprifoliaceae, Caricaceae, Chloranthaceae, Cladoniaceae, Clavulinaceae, Clusiaceae, Coccocarpiaceae, Coenogoniaceae, Collemataceae, Columelliaceae, Commelinac
geography: Tropical Andes, Central region of Colombia, focused on the Caldas department. Along its creation the FAUC Herbarium has recieved donation of specimens from Risaralda, Quindío, Tolima, Valle, Cauca, Nariño, Putumayo, Huila, Amazonas, Cundinamarca, Boyacá, Santander, Norte de Santander, Antioquia, Bolivar, Córdoba, Cesar and Sucre. Additionally It counts with specimens from other countries.
importantCollectors: ['J. M. Duque Jaramillo', 'M. Restrepo']
notes:
The herbarium posses the 45 % of the collection systematized. It is the oldest and most complete collection of plants in the central Andean mountain range of Colombia. It is one of the most complete collection of lichen from Colombia. It has an important collection of invasive flora which is associated with the plant germplasm collection of the University of Caldas. One of the main objetives of the collection is consolidate the floristic inventory of the Caldas department. 
For more inforation please consult our recorded file in https://ipt.biodiversidad.co/sib/resource?r=fauc

division: Faculty of Biology and Environmental Protection
department: Department of Geobotany and Plant Ecology
notes:
The vascular plant collections (a total of about 300 000 specimens) are mainly from the territory of Poland (99%), foreign collections (1%) are represented mainly by plants from North Africa and America. The oldest foreign collections are from the 19th century (collectors: T.R.J. Nitschke, E. Bourgeau, R.F. Hohenacker T. Kotschy, A.G. von Schrenk, G. Lorinser and others).The oldest national collections are from 1920s and 1930s  from Lodz and Tatra MTs. (M. Potęga) and from the vicinity of Vilno (now Lithuania, J.Steckiewicz).
The liverworts collections (a total of more than 1626) are mainly from Central Poland. This collection includes also specimens from Hepaticotheca Polonica (J. Szweykowski, T. Wojterska, S. Lisowski), Hepaticae Beskidi Silesis Exiccatae (I. Rejment-Grochowska) and Hepaticae Macroregioni Meridionali Poloniae Exsiccati (K. Jędrzejko, H. Klama, J. Żarnowiec, A. Stebel).
LOD includes also a total of almost 18 000 specimens of mosses from Central Poland and more than 200 specimens from Bryotheca Polonica (S. Lisowski) and Musci Macroregioni Meridionali Poloniae Exiccati (K. Jędrzejko, H. Klama, J. Żarnowiec, A. Stebel).

notes:
Updated 3 Mar 2022, from Sergei Mosyakin, Kyiv: The Karazin University of Kharkiv is located in a complex of huge buildings near the Freedom Square (Ploshcha Svobody), the largest city square in Europe, Bombing of this area has partly destroyed or severly damaged those buildings.

The section with the CWU herbarium was also damaged, but not so badly; there and no windows in the herbarium premises anymore, but herbarium staff people came without hesitation to the place after the airstrikes and tried to cover the frames with cardboard and plywood. As far as I know, at present there is no loss of specimens, but under the current wet weather conditions the specimens are in fact open to the elements.            


Update from Oct 2020.  The name of the University was changed from Kharkiv State University to V. N. Karazin National University. CWU consists of three parts: 1) Kharkiv Botanical Garden (former CWB, now part of CWU); 2) Department of Botany; 3) Department of Mycology and Plant Resistance - CWU (Myc). (curator O.Yu. Akulov)

Information about the Mycological Herbarium
Dr. Olexander Akulov, curator of the Mycological Herbarium CWU-Myc (V.N. Karazin National University of Kharkiv, Ukraine) addresses you. I am very grateful to you for your kind letter of support and suggestions for help. This is very important for us.
 
I apologize for being late in replying to your letter. In the conditions of hostilities, it is difficult for me to answer letters in time. 
 
CWU-Myc – the oldest and second-largest collection of herbarised fungi in Ukraine, that has the status of the National Heritage of Ukraine. It holds about 40,000 specimens, including a large collection of old mycological exsiccates. There are many type specimens and memorial collections of world-famous scientists among them. The oldest specimen in our collection dates back to 1797. In modern times the collection is being intensively replenished with new materials. Some of them represent species that are new to science, including new genera.
 
Our herbarium has already survived several wars of the past. During WW2, part of the collection was not evacuated. It was placed in metal boxes and buried in the ground in the botanical garden, where it lay for several years. After the war, part of the collection that was evacuated never returned to Kharkiv. It was moved to Kyiv, the capital of Ukraine, and still, it is housed in the KW herbarium. That part, which was buried underground, is still stored in CWU. 
 
The current war with Russia has caused enormous damage to the city of Kharkiv and the University in particular. In the large city with about 1.5 million citizens, about 20% of homes were destroyed, including several buildings of the University.
 
Fortunately, the herbarium has survived till now. The blast shattered the windows, but we closed them from rain and wind with plywood and polyethylene. The samples are stored in airtight metal boxes and are reasonably well protected. This will not protect the collection from a cruise missile or air bomb, but we will hope for the best. Now the Ukrainian army has pushed the invaders 40 km away from the city, so the shelling has decreased to some level.
 
None of us could have imagined that the horrors of war would be repeated in central Europe in the 21st century. We were not ready for such a situation. And the current force majeure has very clearly shown what we did right and where we made mistakes. 
 
As never before, we are aware of the importance of digitizing our funds. We were moving in that direction, but not fast enough. The University already has the status of Data publisher in GBIF. In collaboration with the University of Tartu via PlutoF platform, we have digitized about 7,000 samples. Information about 6,000 of them is already available to anyone in the world through the GBIF site. In 2021, we have prepared information for about another 2,000 specimens.
 
From the first days of the war, the main server of the University stopped working, and with it stopped the access to the electronic archive and catalog of the herbarium disappeared. Only due to the fact that Dr. O. Prylutskyi had a backup copy of the data and posted it on a server in Norway, access to the information was restored.
 
In 2021, we also started a revision of valuable specimens from the CWU-Myc herbarium using molecular genetic markers. We already obtained about 200 sequences. As a result of this work we are preparing a series of publications, for example, https://ukrbotj.co.ua/archive/79/2/84  Unfortunately, about 300 amplicons and all reagents for molecular research were lost during the war, and it will not be easy to restore them.

notes: Entered Jul 2010.  The Herbarium of the Universidade Federal do Acre (UFACPZ) was founded in 1979.  Much of the collection is the product of a collaborative research program with The New York Botanical Garden (NY).  UFACPZ exchanges specimens with major Brazilian herbaria and with herbaria in neighboring Peru and Bolivia.  As of 2010 the entire collection is being imaged and data-based using BRAHMS.  The data stored in the Herbarium UFACPZ are of priority use for educational, scientific and public management. No aspect of this collection may be used without proper legal permission for any commercial purpose or one that generates income

Historical herbaria stored separately at P include: P-Ad. (Adanson); P-JJR (Aublet and J.-J. Rousseau); P-Bonpl. (Bonpland and Humboldt); P-Isn. (Danty d'Isnard); P-JU (Jussieu family); P-LA (Lamarck); P-Desf. (Desfontaines Flora Atlantica; main herbarium of Desfontaines at FI); P-Forst. (J. G. A. and J. R. P-CHEV (Chevalier), P-CO (Cosson), P-DU (Durand), and Vaillant herbaria have been incorporated in P. Blanc, coord.-edit., Muséum National d'Histoire Naturelle, Paris 1-154. 1989).

Vickery', 'W. W. Watts', 'T. Whitelegge']
notes:
NSW fungi have been transferred to the New South Wales Plant Pathology Herbarium (DAR);  The Plant Disease Diagnostic Unit contains microfungal and plant pathology collections.

In June 2018, the NSW Government  announced a $60 million investment for a new facility  in Western Sydney at the Australian Botanic Garden Mount Annan. This project has seen a purpose-built, state-of-the-art facility created to protect our nationally and internationally significant collection, recently valued at $300 million. The herbarium collection was moved here in 2022.
 
A mass digitization project was undertaken between 2019 and 2021 and has produced more than one million high resolution images of the botanical collections, most of which are publically available.

Description of the fungarium or fungal specimen:
The BIOTEC Fungal Herbarium was established in 1996 and registered with Index Herbariorum in 2003. The herbarium has resided in a purpose-built, climate- and humidity-controlled facility since 2003. BBH has been ISO9001-certified for quality management since 2004. There are over 100 species of type specimens in the containers. Nearly half of the greater than 49,000 specimens are insect pathogenic fungi. Other significant groups include macrofungi collected in Thailand from diverse Basidiomycota and Ascomycota phyla. In 2019, the repository changed its official name from BIOTEC to National Biobank of Thailand (NBT), but it remains under the National Science and Technology Development Agency (NSTDA). The location has been relocated from the Storage Building to the Innovation Crustor II Tower A, 1st Floor, but remains within the same region of Thailand Science Park in Pathum Thani Province.

Description of the plant herbarium:
The BIOTEC Plant Herbarium is managed by the Ecology and Geo-informatics Lab, and specializes in storing and distributing voucher specimens from the biodiversity research plots established by the Lab. Its main plot is the 30-ha forest dynamics plot in Khao Yai National Park. Voucher specimens from other research projects within BIOTEC and outside collaborators are also stored.

To date collaboration is been reinforced with the Meise Botanical Garden (BR) for training in plant taxonomy, and a team of devoted researchers is being constituted.

notes: The Herbarium Hyderabadensis (HY), being established in the year 1930, is housed at the Department of Botany, Osmania University, Hyderabad, Telangana state, India.  It holds approximately 8000 specimens, collected from all around the world. The Herbarium Hyderabadensis (HY) derives its name from the existing locale called Hyderabad, Deccan. It was recognised as one of Asian and international Herbaria (Index Herbariorum: http://sweetgum.nybg.org/science/ih/herbarium-details/?irn=125627). The collections are maintained under high quality standards for its standing. As it is in vogue for Indian (Commonwealth) herbaria, the specimens are arranged as per the system of classification of Bentham & Hooker (1862‒1883). The re-arrangement of specimens as per LAPG (2009) and APG IV is on the way.  The Accession Register of HY includes the name of the plant, plant collector and the date of collection, habitat (nation, state/region, district, place, etc. HY has successfully documented the flora of the erstwhile state of Andhra Pradesh (now it is segregated into Andhra Pradesh and Telangana in 2014). The specimens at HY enable one for preparing/developing interactive identifications key for the Angiosperms of the two states (habitat-wise) and as per growth forms (trees, shrubs, climbers and herbs). The herbarium collections are added actively at the rate of 500‒1000 specimens per year on the average.

organization: Robert A. Vines Environmental Science Center, Mercer Botanic Gardens
importantCollectors: ['R. A. Vines', 'L.E. Brown']
notes:
Updated September 2022 (general update).  
SBSC is a facility of Spring Branch Independent School District. In October 2016, the SBSC herbarium, botanical library and illustration collections were transferred to the Mercer Botanic Gardens as a long-term loan. Physical transfer of the SBSC collections was completed spring 2017 and the collections are available to researchers. Digitization of the SBSC collections is underway via NSF grant 1902078. Mercer Botanic Gardens provides citizen scientist training programs including the Texas Master Gardener, Texas Master Naturalist, Texas Invaders, Native Plant Society of Texas, and RBG Kew Millennium Seed Bank Training programs. The MERCA and SBSC herbarium collections support these education programs and facilitate training of herbarium volunteers. Mercer Botanic Gardens is a participating institution of The Center for Plant Conservation (headquartered at San Diego Zoo Global); is an affiliate of Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center; and is a member of the American Public Gardens Association and Botanic Gardens Conservation International.

notes:
PSUB primarily houses the legacy collection of Peter A. Smith who lived and worked in and around the Okavango Delta for more than 30 years.
In 2022 we have returned to preparing specimen sheets for digital scanning. We are prioritizing the core, legacy, collection.
During 2021 we focused on preparing specimen sheets of those species used as Traditional Medicinal Plants in Botswana and particularly those used for the treatment of respiratory symptoms as seen in Covid19 infection. These herbarium sheets have been digital scanned and we will enter data from the image into our database (BRAHMS).
Visitors with specialist botanical knowledge would be welcome to assist with determination of specimens from various families. Expertise in Poaceae or Cyperaceae would be of particular benefit to us.

organization: University of  Vale do Taquari - Univates
importantCollectors: ['G. Bruisma', 'E. Freitas', 'A. Kegler', 'E. Musskopf', 'J. Spellmeier', 'M. Teixeira', 'P. Zampol']
notes: Updated Sep 2017 (name of the institution updated).  The Herbarium of Vale do Taquari (HVAT Herbarium) is linked to the Museum of Natural Sciences of Centro Universitário Univates. The Museum has started its activities in 1995 with the formalization of an agreement with the city of Lajeado, when it installed the Botanical Garden of the city, with the objective to record the species existing in that space. With the closing of the agreement, the first name (Herbarium Lajeado Botanical Garden - HJBL) was replaced by HUNIVATES and later by the current name. Since then, the Herbarium has the legacy to support the documentation of regional plant diversity and the availability of this information to the scientific and general community. The herbarium is part of the Brazilian Network Herbarium and the Rio Grande do Sul Herbarium Network, and is connected to SpeciesLink network. The Herbarium of Vale do Taquari has also integrated INCT Virtual Herbarium of Flora and Fungi during the period of the project. The collection, organized according to the Angiosperm Phylogeny Group III system, is fully computerized using the software database Brahms and available online at SpeciesLink. The samplings are originated from 15 Brazilian states, being most of them from the southern of Brazil, representative two of the existing biomes in Rio Grande do Sul (Pampa and Atlantic Forest). Considering the phytoecological formations, the most representative is the species that make up the Deciduous Forest of the Atlantic Forest biome, plant formation where the region of your location is located. The records of the species are distributed in 167 families, being Orchidaceae the most representative, followed by Asteraceae, Poaceae, Fabaceae, among others. It should be noted that the species of the Orchidaceae family are well represented in the Herbarium, constituting one of the largest collections of this family in Rio Grande do Sul.

Funded as a government institution in 1841; Kew herbarium and library founded in 1852. Around 7 million vascular plant specimens (including approximately 330,000 types) and 1.25 million fungi specimens. Digitisation of specimens is underway. Catalogue numbers of Herbarium specimens begin with K; and with K-M for Fungarium specimens, older records may have been cited as K(M).   Specimens of original Wallich Herbarium (K-W) are not sent on loan. K lichens (pre mid 1960s only), bryophytes, and algae transferred to BM in the 1960s. K is a Non-Departmental Public Body (Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs).

notes:
Updated Jan 2023:
In the morning of 10 October 2022, the historical center of the City of Kyiv was hit by several russian missiles. As result, the historical buildings of the M.G. Kholodny Institute of Botany NAS of Ukraine and the National Herbarium of Ukraine (KW) were hit by the shock waves. Both buildings were hit by the shock waves and some fragments of missiles or damaged structures. About 20 windows were destroyed or severely damaged and was discovered several roof leaks (the holes were caused by the missile fragments). In particular, the ceiling in the Lesser Herbarium Hall has been damaged.  Currently, the urgent repair of the buildings has been completed, but the repair of the damage is ongoing.  (Detail report please see: https://ukrbotj.co.ua/archive/79/5/339). 

Updated Nov 2022:
An update from the KW Herbarium and our Institute: We were planning to start tomorrow (Wednesday) the serious repair and replacement of windows (damaged during the 10 October 2022 missile strikes) at the Institute of Botany and KW National Herbarium, but now it is hardly possible because the windows company will not be able to work under unstable power supply. The works will be most probably postponed.

Updated Oct 2022:
Email message received from Dr. Sergei Mosyakin, Director of the M. G. Kholodny Institute of Botany on 10 October 2022, reporting on damage  to KW during the recent Russian airstrikes:  Mostly windows, roofs, some non-critical structures. Anyway, some serious renovation will be needed before the winter. Right now, no irreversible loss of specimens, no harm to our staff. Our people who today worked here, did some basic repair and cleared the mess are fantastic. 

Updated January 2022.
In addition to the main part, which contains materials of vascular plants, the Herbarium KW includes some important parts (subdivisions) that have a unique abbreviation: KW-M (Mycology Herbarium – Herbarium of Fungi and Fungi-like Organisms), KW-L (Lichen Herbarium), KW-B( Bryophyte herbarium), KW-A (Algotheca), KW-P (Palynotheca). 
No specimens are currently available for sending on loan; however, images are provided upon request, if available. The exchange of specimens is temporarily unavailable due to changed governmental regulations.

notes: The herbarium consists of about 150 historic, rare sheets that might have served as the materials for Cooke’s flora (1903-08).  The herbarium also has over 700 sheets that form materials for the campus flora collected chiefly by V. D. Vartak (the rest specimens collected from the Fergusson campus are currently at AHMA). The collections mainly include economic botany, and floristic explorations in hilltop forts around Pune, and several other miscellaneous specimens that form vouchers for many local floras are present.

department: 3rd Floor Research Center for the Natural and Applied Sciences
taxonomicCoverage: 285 families of flowering plants, gymnosperms, ferns, and thallophytes (algae and fungi)
notes: Entered Aug 2016 (new curator).  The UST Museum of Arts and Sciences was founded by a professor of Natural History, Fr. Ramon Martinez Vigil, O.P. in 1870 at Intramuros, Manila. With the efforts of Fr. Casto de Elera O.P.,  the  natural sciences collections were scientifically classified and catalogued. Before World War II, the UST Museum of Arts and Sciences was transferred to its present site, at the UST Main Bldg., Sampaloc, Manila. In 1988, a large part of the plant collection composed of 8 herbarium cases of about 8,200 specimens were transferred to the Research Center for the Natural Sciences at the 4th floor, Clinical Division of the UST Hospital. Since then, the UST Herbarium is continuously being replenished with new specimens through the collections made by the UST RCNS research team, graduate and undergraduate students. With the completion of the Thomas Aquinas Research Complex in November 2001, the plant collections were moved to its new and modern location.  The herbarium is equipped with modern facilities and an adjacent laboratory for herbarium curation.

taxonomicCoverage: Vascular plants, fungi, lichens, bryophytes, algae

notes:
Vascular plants: over 110000 specimens of 1700 species from Magadan, Chukotka, Kamchatka, Yakutia  and other region
of North-East Asia:  East Siberia, Russian South Far East, Commander Islands, etc., including over 47 types.  A. P. Khokhryakov, M.T. Mazurenko, A.T.
Reutt, A.N. Berkutenko, and other collectors since 1940.  
There are over 40 species of vascular plants from Magadan Region (Russia) described mainly by A.P. Khokhryakov deposited in the
collection. 

Since 2020,  the Digital Herbarium MAG is being formed on the platform of the Digiital Herbarium of Moskow State University (https://plant.depo.msu.ru/module/itemsearchpublic) and at GBIF (https://www.gbif.org/dataset/search?publishing_org=8eae4f57-6fb4-4504-8f76-a949b8e9e4d4). Since 2022, the Virtual Herbarium MAG is also located in its own site (https://herbarium.ibpn.ru/ ;  https://en.herbarium.ibpn.ru/).

Fungi: over 10000 specimens of 780 species of Agaricales and Aphyllophorales, main collection from  Magadan, Chukotka, and a small
collection from Russian south  Far East and European part (Kostroma and Leningrad Regions). 
Lichens: 5000 specimens of 320 species from Magadan Region. 
Bryophytes:  over 4700 specimens  of 470 species (common species from Magadan, Chukotka, Taymir). 
Seed collection: over 3600 samples of 2000 species of vascular plants from Magadan Region, Russian South Far
East, Ural and Siberia.

Kooperberg', 'T. Martin', 'H. Nessia', 'P. J. de Lange', 'R. Lücking', 'J. Margetts', 'A.J. Marshall', 'B. Moncado', 'L. Moyle', 'J. Nicholson (nee MacDuff)', 'C. L. Reynolds', 'L.M.H. Schmid', 'V. Sergeant', 'N. Solomon', 'S. Wake', 'J. Weaver', 'C.J. West']
notes:
Types: Buellia insularicola (Holotype), Cladia blanchonii (Isotype), Lecanora kohu (Isotype), Leptospermum repo (Isotype), Ocellularia jacinda-arderniae (Isotype)

Scope: The Flora and Lichenized Mycobiota of New Zealand. UNITEC has an emphasis on the northern part of New Zealand particularly the lichens of the Kermadec Islands, Northland, Kaipara (Mataia), Waitakere Ranges, urban Auckland, Auckland Regional Parks, Hauraki Gulf Islands (notable collections from Rangitoto, Motukaikoura and Tiritirimatangi), Waikato and Chatham Islands. Herbarium collections also reflect participation in Auckland Bioblitz (Auckland Domain, Auckland Botanical Gardens, Dingle Dell, Kepa Bush/Pourewa, Miranda, Smiths Bush, and Twin Streams (Opanuku Stream Catchment)). Invasive plants are also well represented reflecting staff research interests e.g., Taraxacum, and the courses taught by the facility.

The herbarium also holds DNA vouchers linked to the Applied Molecular Solutions Research Group (www.unitec.ac.nz/ams) and associated laboratory, and international lichen research consortia (PhyloRamalina, Lecanomics, Parsys).

The earliest collections are those donated collections from 1965 (Judy Nicholson, mainly South Island), with other later donations from the 1980s and 1990s, before active collecting began in 2001.

History: UNITEC was founded by Carol Elliott (nee Lockett) and Dan Blanchon in 2001. It is a teaching and research herbarium, with a major strength in New Zealand lichens, and which supports the research of an active lichen research group, as well as research on invasive and indigenous species.  Students learn herbarium specimen collection and preparation in three different courses in the Bachelor and Masters of Applied Science, and students volunteer in the herbarium to assist with accessioning and curation. The herbarium supports taxonomy education, particularly in lichenology, mycology, botany and biosecurity.

The main lichen collections of New Zealand Lichenologists Dan Blanchon, Andrew Marshall and Peter de Lange are held at UNITEC (including important lichen collections from the Kermadec and Chatham Islands, and northern New Zealand).

Curator: Professor P.J. de Lange

Key staff: Dr Mark Large, Andrew Marshall, Tamara Takimoana-Everiss

Honorary Research Staff: Dr Dan J. Blanchon

Specimens from Traub Herbarium, transferred to MO in 1984, should be cited
as TRA. MO library contains more than 200 000 volumes, about 800 current
botanical periodicals and approximately 250 000 items in the archives,
including letters, manuscripts, paintings, drawings, photographs, and maps.
MO maintains a computerized database, TROPICOS, containing information on
names and nomenclature, specimens and literature references for vascular
plants and mosses worldwide, including images, synonymy, acceptance and
authority files at http://www.tropicos.org. Records since 1975 from <Index to Plant Chromosome
Numbers>, now published by MO, are part of database. Flora projects
include: <Flora of China>, <Flora de Nicaragua> in conjunction with HNMN,
<Flora of Peru> in conjunction with F, <Flora Mesoamericana> in conjunction
with BM and MEXU, <Flora of the Venezuelan Guayana>, <Flora of North
America>, <Catalog of the Flowering Plants and Gymnosperms of Peru>, and
<Catalog of the Vascular Plants of Ecuador> and <Catálogo de las plantas vasculares de Bolivia>

organization: Iranian Research Organization for Science and Technology (IROST)
importantCollectors: ['M. Sohrabi', 'M. Ghobad-Nejhad']
notes:
Entered May 2016.  The Iranian Cryptogamic Herbarium currently contains mostly lichenized, lichenicolous fungi as well as wood inhabiting macrofungi. This collection has an estimated number of 2000 specimens from Iran, and some duplicates from around the world. ICH contains specimens mainly from Caspian Hyrcanian forests, oak forests in Zagros Mountains, and arid to semiarid ecosystems. It aims to be a resource for biological systematics and classification, diversity and conservation, biotechnological applications, biological monitoring, biodeterioration, bioremediation, climate change, ecology, and pharmaceutical bio-prospecting. The collection is a resource for academics, students, government, private organizations, and the public.
The Biotechnology department was established in 1980, and has 22 scientific members from different disciplines of biotechnology, microbiology, mycology and lichenology. The Iranian Research Organization for Science and Technology (IROST) is a governmental organization, founded in 1980, with the aim of providing support to Iranian researchers, inventors and industrialists across the country. This organization provides valuable services in fulfilling the country\'s scientific, technical and engineering requirements through supporting applied and developmental research as well as developing new technologies by exploiting qualified experts and modern equipment and facilities.

department: Environmental Dynamics and Global Climate Change
geography: Khanty-Mansi Autonomous region; Northern part of Western Siberia; other regions of Russia
notes:
The YSU BC currently stores about 15000 specimens of fungi, mosses, hepatics and vascular plants. It was initially based on private collections of several researchers working on biodiversity assessment in Yugra State University. In 2017 YSU BC is registered as a data publisher in GBIF (https://www.gbif.org/publisher/fa46e267-4d25-41f5-bbbe-1cd75860b943).
The main goal of the YSU BC is to develop reference library of regional biodiversity, support research in systematics, ecology, phylogeny and applied disciplines, and manage associated biodiversity information in the Northern West Siberia. For that purpose, we are developing conditions for physical storage of samples, facilitating their scientific analysis, and applying modern computer technologies for storage, analysis and distribution of collection data.
The database of YSU BC is developed using Specify software. The Specify Web Portal (http://bioportal.ugrasu.ru/) available for the database search, browsing the map and images, and download. The database is shared through GBIF by IPT software using MySQL queries to each individual collection, including images of specimens.
Published papers about the collection:
Filippova N, Ganasevich G, Filippov I, Meshcheryakova A, Lapshina E, Karpov D (2022) Yugra State University Biological Collection (Khanty-Mansiysk, Russia): general and digitisation overview. Biodiversity Data Journal 10: e77669. https://doi.org/10.3897/BDJ.10.e77669
Filippova NV, Filippov IV, Lapshina ED (2020) Establishing the regional center on biodiversity data mobilization in the Northwestern Siberia (Russia). ARPHA Proceedings 2: 27-35. https://doi.org/10.3897/ap.2.e58693

notes:
1928  FU established as a herbarium of Department of Forestry, Faculty of Agriculture at Hakozaki Campus,
1947-2002 almost semi-closed, because of postwar turmoil and absence of botanical taxonomist.
2002  The Kyushu University Museum (established in 2000) started to support FU.
2003-2015 A lot of specimens left outside the storage were salvaged by The Kyushu University Museum. The salvaged specimens and FU specimens deposited after 1950 were moved to the university museum building at Hakozaki Campus.
2015  Yahara's collection partially moved to the university museum building at Hakozaki Campus.
2017  The Kyushu University Museum test-released a few partial database of the botanical specimens.
2018  FU specimens deposited before 1949 move to the new building of Faculty of Agriculture at new Ito Campus.
2018  All Kanehira's specimens were gathered at a new room. Open storage exhibition was made by Dr. Mishima and volunteer students.
2022  The Kyushu University Museum prepared a new herbarium room in Ito Campus for FU specimens deposited after 1950
2024  FU specimens deposited after 1950 in Hakozaki Campus will move to Ito Campus
The data updated in July 2023.

notes: NY diatoms transferred to CAS in 2002. The Brooklyn Botanic Garden Herbarium (BKL, ca. 350,000 specimens) is maintained separately, but is available for consultation and loans.  Botanical library available to all researchers. Library includes over 260 400 volumes (105 000 book and monograph titles and nearly 11 000 serial titles), 125 000 reprints, collections of archives and manuscripts, seed catalogs and index semina, photographs, botanical art, and artifacts. The Library on-line catalog, is accessible  at: http://library.nybg.org. Services include interlibrary loan, photocopying, photography, CD-ROM database searches, and literature searches. Most services are for a fee. The Library is the repository for the Taxonomic Literature II (Stafleu and Cowan) data files and for the archives of the American Society of Plant Taxonomists, Council on Botanical and Horticultural Libraries, Mycological Society of America, Organization for Flora Neotropica, Society for Economic Botany, Torrey Botanical Society, and others.

department: Center for Biodiversity Conservation, Restoration Ecology, & Environmental Concerns - CBCREEC (formerly EMDO)
taxonomicCoverage: General Flora of the Northwestern Luzon, Philippines (Chromista, Rhodophyta, Chlorophyta, Lycophytes, Pteridophytes, Gymnosperms, Angiosperms)
importantCollectors: ['M. A. Calaramo', 'H. Nuytemans', 'G. Alejandro', 'A. Arriola', 'M. Subac', 'R. Pungtilan', 'B. Acoba', 'J. Cootes', 'K. Naïve', 'V. Palting', 'K. Gaspar.']
notes:
The Northwestern University in the Philippines is a pioneering academic institution in the Northern Luzon geared in conserving the natural heritage of the country. The northwestern Luzon is home to numerous endemic plants species and cannot be found elsewhere in the world, despite is harsh climatic condition, natural calamities and human exploitation that aggravated the degradation of natural plant habitats. The Philippines is among the Megadiversity countries in the world yet among the most critically endangered, placing it as a hotspot for conservation. The university established its botanic gardens to perform the international agenda of botanic gardens in conservation and to halt the loss of species in our region.

The herbarium Includes 2,200 species of living plant collections at the Systematic Gardens with 226 Families and 124 subfamilies of the kingdom Plantae. The living plant collection and herbarium collections are extensively used for plant taxonomy (APG III). Top universities in Manila (University of the Philippines Diliman, University of the Philippines Manila, University of Santo Tomas and the De La Salle University Dasmarinas Cavite) annually conduct taxonomy courses in the botanic gardens which is arranged according to family and in their latest phylogenetic treatment

The specimens are also sent to the different botanical institutions around the world for DNA barcoding and genomics.

All specimens are newly acquired and collected in the wild to represent Flora of the Island Luzon, Philippines.

Dr Shah Khalid

notes: Hazara University is located on the crossroads of the ancient civilization of Gandhara and Ashoka and is on one of the Silk Routes connecting the Indian sub-continent with China and Central Asia. The University was founded in 2001 and has had a strong floristic program since that time. Today, its herbarium includes about 18,000 species and includes all plant groups other than algae. Its primary geographic focus is Northern Pakistan, a mountainous area that includes three major mountain ranges, the Hindu Kush, Karakorum, and Western Himalaya. It started sharing its specimen data via OpenHerbarium and GBIF in 2021.

geography: Eastern Morocco (especially from the Oujda-Figuig-Midelt-Guercif area) and Saharan Morocco (especially from Foum zguid-Tata-Foum El Hissn area)
notes: Updated Oct 2023. ECWP herbarium is open to any researcher and amateur, by appointment, on request. However validation by the ECWP Operation Director is mandatory. The ECWP herbarium is located at ECWP headquarters in Missour, Morocco, in a building dedicated to botanical studies. Specimens are mounted on acid-free, archival paper (48 x 28 cm) and are stored in cardboard boxes, that are themselves in cabinets. 2450 Moroccan taxa are currently in the collection, including some types specimens.  Many vouchers have been verified by Mohammed Ibn Tattou (Institut Scientifique de Rabat), one of the authors of the Flore pratique du Maroc. There is an Excel file list of identified specimens vouchers. A software dedicated to sample collection management is planned for 2024. ECWP also has a botanical bibliographical collection, specializing in south-west Mediterranean flora and habitats, that includes 400 books and monographs and >10000 pdf files (books, monographs, papers). There is a flora/fauna database in the production for over fifteen years, including over 1500 recent phytosociological relevés.

notes: Updated March 10 2022:  Our collection LWS has over 118K herbarium vouchers collected during the last 200 years. This collection has crucial importance because it hosts many specimens from the Carpathian region. We evacuated type specimens from our herbarium. But, unfortunately, we were unable to relocate the whole herbarium collection due to lack of space and finances. Our herbarium is deposited in metallic boxes that can resist mechanical damage and more or less to the water and humidity. However, these boxes are not temperature-resistant and therefore there is a high risk of smoldering of herbarium specimens inside these boxes in case of fire and high temperatures. It would be great to cover these boxes by fire-resistant thermo-isolation (e.g., by Rockwool RockSlab) to prevent the thermal damage of specimens for the period of war, but we have no such financial possibilities.The collection includes the former Herbarium of Shevchenko's Scientific Society

Update from William Cinea, Les Cayes Botanical Garden, Dec 2023: "T he herbarium in Port-au-Prince suffered a fire that destroyed the specimens collected from 1930 to 2020. Unfortunately, only the specimens collected by Ekman remain, and their condition is deteriorating. We last assessed the Ekman specimens in 2020, There is no recent updated assessment that was done to determine their current state and potential conservation measures."

 Updated Jan 2009. First report on status of the herbarium after the earthquake: At least the plant collection appears salvageable, if not the herbarium building itself, once the situation in Port au Prince has stabilized.  The director, Prof. Robers Pierre Tescar, survived the eathquake.   Refer to the herbarium website for future updates..

importantCollectors: ['E.K. Rose']
notes: Entered Jun 2017.  In the early 1980s, a group of botanists, horticulturists, and civic leaders got together to plan a new botanical garden, Lewis Ginter Botanical Garden.  One of their priorities was to create an herbarium to collect plants local to the area, and once the garden’s collection was established, plants cultivated in our garden.  We are proud that a small number of dedicated volunteers believe in the value of preserving plants for future botanists and scientists.

taxonomicCoverage: Vascular plants, wild and cultivated cereals and other crops, emphasis on families of economic importance, weeds; useful wild plants; collection used for identification of archaeological plant remains.
importantCollectors: ['G ordon Charles Hillman, David Henry French, Robert Mark Nesbi']
notes: In addition to the Herbarium Collection, there is also a Wood Collection, Charcoal Collection, and Archaeobotanical Seed Reference Collection. The Herbarium Collection, Wood Collection, and Charcoal Collection were digitised in 2020. For further information about Archaeobotanical Seed Reference Collection please contact library@biaa.ac.uk. Currently, the Herbarium Collection has 4200 specimens and is available on the BIAA’s website (https://digitalrepository.biaa.ac.uk/botanical-reference-collection).

geography: Yukon Territory; Beringian and Circumboreal; Alaska, British Columbia, Manitoba, Ontario, Nunavut,  and Northwest Territories
importantCollectors: ['B. A. Bennett', 'P. P. Caswell', 'A. Ceska', 'M. J. Oldham', 'R. Rosie', 'S. Withers']
notes: B.A. Bennett Herbarium contains only Vascular Plants. With more than 5800 Yukon specimens it is one of the largest and most comprehensive collections of vascular plants from Yukon. Visiting researchers and students are encouraged to use the herbaria. The library includes all significant northern floras including floras of Russian, Scandinavia, Europe, Canada, and the Pacific Northwest. Additional resources include over 4000 reprints primarily of literature relevant to the Yukon flora, including many historical accounts. Significant exchanges are currently made with UBC, ALA, CAN, DAO and to a lesser extent ALTA, ETST, UAAH, V, and WTU.

CCT-Córdoba-CONICET
Instituto Multidisciplinario de Biología Vegetal 
Herbario CORD-Museo Botánico
Av. Vélez Sarsfield 299, 2 Piso.
5000. Córdoba 
Argentina

 - do not add the name of the director or curators. We need you to send parcels ONLY through the regular post office and not through a private courier (Fedex, DHL, etc.). 
Types are not sent on loan, but images with good resolution can be provided. Images of specimen types also are available in: www.plants.jstor.org .

organization: Consiglio Nazionale delle Ricerche, Istituto di Scienze Marine
taxonomicCoverage: Algae and seagrasses; Gracilariales, Bangiales and Ulvales
geography: Venice Lagoon and the Adriatic Sea
importantCollectors: ['M. Minio', 'N. Spada']
notes:
Updated Aug 2016 (important collections, specialties updated).

The herbarium includes the algal historical collection of M. Minio and N. Spada, containing more than a thousand samples of Gracilaria, collected between 1942 and 1950 in the Venice lagoon. Also, the collection includes a miscellaneous section, containing members of different algal taxa, such Ulvales, Ceramiales and Bangiales. The herbarium is expanding on algae and seagrasses from the Venice Lagoon and the Adriatic Sea.

organization: University of the West Indies, Mona
importantCollectors: ['W. Harris', 'C. D. Adams', 'P. Sintensis', 'G. Proctor.']
notes: Updated Feb 2024.  Herbarium is divided into (i) Specimens from outside Jamaica (mainly Caribbean), (ii)Monocots from Jamaica, (iii)Dicots from Jamaica ,(iv)Gymnosperms,Ferns and Algae from Jamaica.(v)Bryophytes and Lichen from Jamaica.  Specimens are in folders arranged alphabetically, in family, genus and species.  About 95% of cabinets are modern steel type with the rest wooden.  The relatively small virtual component (see Website URL above) was the work of Dr. Philip Rose for his doctoral thesis. Currently the Herbarium supports the teaching of Botany courses in the Department of Life Science, however, our aim is to expand educational outreach to schools, and local and international researchers through tours of the Herbarium on The UWI Campus. Additionally, we are directing our efforts toward the infrastructure upgrades (A/C, electrical repairs, windows etc.), barcoding and digitization of the collection.

M. Moçiño', 'R. Morison', 'J. A. Pavón y Jiménez', 'J. D. Prescott', 'L. Riedel', 'H. Ruiz Lopez', 'C. Sandeman', 'M. de Sessé y Lacasta', 'W. Sherard', 'J. Sibthorp', 'R. Spruce', 'E. G. von Steudel']
notes: Updated Jan 2014. Pre-Linnaean collections in OXF are primarily associated with the personal herbaria of Jacob Bobart the Elder and the Younger, Robert Morison, William Sherard, Charles Dubois, Johann Dillenius and Thomas Shaw. The Fielding Herbarium contains all non-British material collected by former Department of Botany staff since 1769, and since it was largely obtained through purchase of material at auctions in the early 19th century, it is particularly rich in type material. The Druce Herbarium contains all British phanerogams that were collected later than 1769.  The history of OXF has been comprehensively studied by H. M. Clokie (1964;  An account of the herbaria of the Department of Botany in the University of Oxford,"" Oxford University Press).

notes: The HERBARIO UNIVERSITARIO PORT  (INBIO-UNELLEZ) has a collection of about 150,000 botanical specimens of vascular plants. The collection is organized in alphabetical order by three main collections: Pteridophytes, Gymnosperms and Angiosperms (PPG and APG system). Herbarium PORT also contains the most modern and representative national vascular plants of the Guayana, Amazon and lowland forests and savannas of Western Llanos of Venezuela. Also, it holds the most comprehensive collection of Pteridophytes of Venezuela, as well as, important collections from the Andean foothills and Guaramacal National Park in the Venezuelan Andes. Herbarium PORT also has a collection of types of Neotropical vascular plants of approximately 500 specimens. The types specimens held by PORT are 70 Holotypes, 110 Isotypes, 280 Paratypes among other ca. 40 type specimens non-specified yet. These type specimens represent ca. 250 species, belonging to 138 genera and 64 families of vascular plants.

taxonomicCoverage: Algae, Bryophytes, Pteridophytes, Gymnosperms and Angiosperms
notes: The Herbarium of the department of Botany, Sri Krishnadevaraya University, Ananthapuramu (formerly Anantapur) with an acronym ‘SKU’ is the largest herbarium in Andhra Pradesh and the second largest in South Indian Universities. It was started in 1983 by Prof. T. Pullaiah and later from 1996 onwards Dr. B. Ravi Prasad Rao is the in-charge  for SKU. SKU houses about 41,000+ specimens collected during 1983-2023 from different parts of states of Andhra Pradesh and  Telangana and other states of Southern Peninsular India and Andaman Islands. These specimens represent different plant groups: algae, bryophytes, pteridophytes, gymnosperms and angiosperms. There are 17 type specimens in SKU. All the specimens are preserved by dry and wet method using rectified spirit and mercuric chloride and guaranteed to exist without any damage for about a century. Duplicates of these specimens as well field notes are being maintained separately in the herbarium store room. Chief contributors are  Prof. T. Pullaiah team (about 11,000 specimens)  Prof. R.R. Venkata Raju (3000) and Prof. B. Ravi Prasad Rao team (about 26,000). Most of the collections are made with the support of national funding agency supported research projects like UGC, DST, CSIR and DBT. About 20,000 specimens are collected from Eastern Ghats and 3500 from Andaman Islands. Specimens are arranged in specially designed cupboards following Bentham and Hookers classification with modifications after Angiosperm Phylogeny Group classification (APG IV, 2016) . Prof. B. Ravi Prasad Rao is the Director of the herbarium and can be contacted at biodiversityravi@gmail.com for more information.

taxonomicCoverage: Primarily vascular plants; ectomycorrhizal fungi; historic native plant collections from now urbanised Perth suburbs, Southwest Western Australia Eucalyptus collection; Marine algae
geography: Primarily Western Australia with some from south-eastern Australia, especially Tasmania; Marine specimens from Great Barrier Reef and Port Jackson
notes:
Updated March 2023 (new correspondents, staff, organisational arrangements, updated collections information). 
The herbarium was established from 1974 when Murdoch University opened, principally to support ecological research and teaching. Situated on the lands of the Whadjuk people, the boodjar (country) of the Murdoch campus has, for thousands of years, been a place of learning. We at Murdoch University are proud to continue this long tradition. Most specimens in the herbarium are from the Southwest, Darling Plateau, Eneabba, Fitzgerald River National Park, and Pilbara regions of Western Australia. Significant sets are from the Murdoch University campus (which retains several areas of native vegetation), bushland remnants around the City of Melville, riverine habitats along the Swan and Canning Rivers, and an area of Queens Park that is now covered with houses. Biosecurity restrictions apply for herbarium material sent to Australia. Please contact the institution before sending any material.

importantCollectors: ['A. Kmet, V. Vrany, J. Petrikov Skovirova']
notes: The museum is located in the first building of the Slovak National Museum (SNM) dating from 1908, where its founder Andrej Kmet layed the foundation for the national botanical collection with approx. 80 000 herbarium specimens. This fundamental collection was transferred into later established specialized Natural History Museum (BRA herbarium) of SNM in Bratislava in 1960-ies. In 1964 the regional natural history museum named Turiec Museum of Andrej Kmeť was founded with its regional herbarium collection.

Due to the reorganisation and digitization of the natural history collections at Gotlands Museum, herbarium VI has ceased and been merged with the other scientific collections at the museum. The herbarium is now addressed as herbarium GNH (as a unit of Gotland Natural History Collections). Updated April 2024.

Entered Dec 2011.  A digital version of the collection is stored at ATRIUM website including photographs of the specimens (http://atrium.andesamazon.org/research_project_display_info.php?id=21). The living collection that includes the arboretum and several permanent plots on different forest types is ideal for collecting leaf material for molecular studies. Individuals with diameter 10 cm are tagged and located in a map. The Jenaro Herrera Research Centre where the herbarium and living collections are located has infrastructure for research (http://www.iiap.org.pe/web/ci-jenaro-herrera.aspx).
Since 2023, the Herrerense herbarium has part of its collection in the City of Iquitos and work is being done to provide all the facilities to visiting researchers.

taxonomicCoverage: Phanerogams and cryptogams of different Protected Areas of India
importantCollectors: ['Since its inception, the colle']
notes:
WII Herbarium: A National Repository - represents flora of a number of Protected Areas of India
The scientific value of herbaria as a botanical repository of Earth's current and past diversity is globally acknowledged. The Wildlife Institute of India Herbarium, recognized by the ""Index Herbariorum,"" is listed among the 3567 network of herbaria worldwide cited using the acronym ""WII"" in the scientific and botanical publications.

WII Herbarium was established in 1986 with a twofold purpose: (i) to create a repository of plant collections representing flora of different Protected Areas (PAs) of India and (ii) to develop a basic facility for aiding plant identification, floral inventory and access to plant databases for officer trainees, researchers, and students of WII.

One of unique features of WII herbarium is that it represents flora of a number of protected areas of India. Based on the floristic surveys and inventory of species, the database on the flora of protected areas namely Asola Bhatti Wildlife Sanctuary, Bandhavgarh National Park, Grasslands in and around Pachmarhi Wildlife Sanctuary, Bodhghat submergence area, Madhya Pradesh, Great Himalayan National Park, Pin Valley National Park, Kedarnath Wildlife Sanctuary, Valley of Flowers National Park, Cold­arid region of Nanda Devi BR, Rajaji National Park, Eravikulam National Park, Protected areas of Andhra Pradesh, Jaldapara Wildlife Sanctuary, Gorumara National Park, Hemis National Park, Dachigam National Park, Rann of Kutch, Pakhui Wildlife Sanctuary, Arunachal Pradesh etc. has been prepared.

importantCollectors: ['B. Baker', 'B. Shepherd', 'T. Witsell']
notes: Updated Feb 2023.  The Herbarium of the Arkansas Natural Heritage Commission consists primarily of specimens collected in the course of statewide ecological and biological inventory work conducted by the Arkansas Natural Heritage Program.  Many of the specimens represent species that are rare in the state or were collected from rare or unusual habitats.  The goals of the collection are 1) to provide a reference collection for work performed by Natural Heritage Commission staff and their conservation partners, 2) to house voucher specimens for rare plant records in the database of the Arkansas Natural Heritage Program, and 3) to voucher plants of ecologically sensitive or otherwise significant lands, including those contained within the State's System of Natural Areas.  While most specimens are from Arkansas, special care is being made to assemble a collection of plants from surrounding states that are not presently known in Arkansas but are likely to be found there.  The herbarium has new custom-built housing, with accompanying lab and research rooms,  Compactor units were installed in late 2016.

notes: Updated Aug  2013. The ERDB Botany Laboratory and Herbarium was established to serve as a depository facility of plant specimens collected during the implementation of R&D projects, such as  vegetation analysis by ERDB researchers.  Also the laboratory received duplicates of plant specimens submitted and referred to by researchers from academe and other research institutions which eventually became a property of the laboratory as they bear permanent herbarium number and is recorded in the laboratory's accession book.  The herbarium also comprises valuable data on plant habit, phenology and associations of a particular collection site and the collector.
