importantCollectors: ['J. L. Carter', 'E. F. Castetter', 'Y. Chauvin', 'O. M. Clark', 'D. Dunn', 'R. Fletcher', 'C. R. Hutchins', 'R. C. Jackson', 'P. J. Knight', 'W. C. Martin', 'O. B. Metcalfe', 'R. C. Sivinski', 'P. C. Standley', 'W. L. Wagner', 'E. O. Wooton']
notes: We are pleased to announce the donation of the College of Santa Fe Herbarium to the UNM Herbarium in the Museum of Southwestern Biology, University of New Mexico.    The collection includes over 1800 specimens of vascular plants and several hundred bryophytes, hepatics, and lichens, largely collected by Brother Arsène Brouard in the 1920's and 30's in New Mexico. Brother Arsène was the first collector to work extensively in northern New Mexico since the early botanical explorations in the 1840s by Gambel, Wislizenus, Emory, and Fendler.  Wooten and Standley collected east of Santa Fe briefly in 1908.  Arsène’s notes indicate that he collected at least 5,000 specimens in northern New Mexico, several thousand of which are at the Smithsonian and nearly 1800 are in the donated herbarium from The College of Santa Fe.  There are also a number of specimens collected in Mexico by Brother Arsène.  The specimens will not be available for study until they are curated and databased.

organization: Universidade Federal dos Vales do Jequitinhonha e Mucuri
taxonomicCoverage: Economic plants and medicinal plants. Germplasm collection
geography: Brazil, especially Minas Gerais; Cerrado (savanna); campos rupestres (rocky grasslands); Atlantic Forest (tropical rain forest and dry forest)
importantCollectors: ['J. E. Q. Faria']
notes: O herbário foi idealizado em 2006 pelos estudantes e docentes do Departamento de Engenharia Florestal da Universidade Federal dos Vales do Jequitinhonha e Mucuri com finalidade de subsidiar as disciplinas deste curso, oferecer suporte aos estudos de vegetação e consequentemente congregar coleções científicas da flora regional. Em 2011 o acervo tomou proporções consideráveis sendo necessárias melhorias na forma de armazenamento e novas estruturas e equipamentos foram adquiridos. Nesta época o herbário recebeu a denominação Herbário Dendrológico Jeanine Felfili, com a sigla oficial HDJF, bem como o reconhecimento oficial junto à Rede Brasileira de Herbários e ao Index Herbariorum. O acervo HDJF está dividido em três partes, a saber: material herborizado; xiloteca e carpoteca. Todo o acervo está condicionado em uma área física de 66 m², com projeto de expansão aguardando recursos financeiros para tanto. O acervo do HDJF está compilado em bando de dados e as suas exsicatas estão sendo digitalizadas a fim de serem disponibilizadas online. O HDJF está inserido na porção Meridional da Serra do Espinhaço, fitogeograficamente a região que apresenta um complexo mosaico de florestas estacionais e savana, com diversas fitofisonomias relativamente bem preservadas, sendo considerada área prioritária para conservação e investigação científica. Assim no acervo tem destaque para a flora regional com exemplares dos biomas Mata Atlântica e Cerrado, contudo há também representação de outros biomas como Amazônia e Caatinga, oriundos do programa de permutas de duplicatas e intercâmbio com outros herbários.

Murta', 'J. Paiva', 'J. Pedrógão', 'F. J. D. Quintas', 'F. R. R. Schlechter', 'M. Silva', 'F. de Sousa', 'C. Tisserant', 'A. R. da Torre', 'F. M. J. Welwitsch', 'H. M. Willkomm', 'G. A. Zenker']
notes: Updated Jan 2010.  Since 1879 the Herbarium of the Department of Botany of the University of Coimbra, Portugal (COI), has owned the Herbarium of the german (Saxonian) Henrich Moritz Willkomm, Professor at Prague University and a specialist on the flora of the Iberian Peninsula. This collection was bought to Willkomm and contains vascular and non-vascular plants of the Mediterranean area and the Macaronesian Islands and includes c. 10.000 species and over 30.000 specimens. The specimens were collected by Willkomm himself and other relevant botanical collectors of the time e.g., Bourgeau, Orphanides, Sieber, Lange, Loscos, Boissier, Reuter, Lagasca, Cavanilles. It was the basis for Willkomm & Lange's Prodromus Florae Hispanicae (1861-1880), the first comprehensive Flora of most of the Iberian Peninsula - only now being superseded by the Flora iberica (Castroviejo et al., 1986-, Madrid) - and contains many type specimens of Iberian taxa. Not all Willkomm specimens are at COI and some are scattered in other institutes. But this is by far the largest assemblage of his material and he regarded it as his core collection which, as a whole he sold to Júlio Henriques, the founder of COI.  Specimens in Willkomm Herbarium not sent on loan.
Updated Mar 2017 (general update).

notes:
The National Herbarium (NH) was established in 1998 
with financial support from the Danish International 
Development Agency (DANIDA) and became operational 
in 2003. It is the only herbarium in the country 
(Herbarium code THIM) listed in the Index Herbariorum 
 (https://sweetgum.nybg.org/science/ih/) - a guide to the 
world’s herbaria and where only those collections that 
are permanent scientific repositories are included.
The main functions of the National Herbarium are to 
serve as the national repository of “Type” (A preserved 
specimen designated as a permanent reference for a 
new species, new genus or some other taxon) and 
voucher specimens of botanical collections; lead and 
coordinate plant systematics and taxonomy-related 
studies, including national floristic works; and identify 
conservation priority species in the country. The ancillary 
functions include providing taxonomic services to other 
agencies and stakeholders. and programs of the centres.
Over the past 20 years, the National Herbarium focussed 
on building its collections through routine collections 
programs, international collaborations and national 
thematic projects, including the (i) Bhutan fern project, 
(ii) Pilot project on invasive plant species of Bhutan, 
(iii) 
Comprehensive assessment of climate change impacts 
on endemic plant diversity, (iv) Impact assessment of 
invasive plants in Bhutan, (v) Red listing of Bhutan’s 
endemic plant species, and 
(vi) Biodiversity conservation 
and sustainable use in High Altitude Northern Areas of 
Bhutan (HANAs). Currently, the NH houses 
approximately 19,309 accessions of Angiosperms, 
Gymnosperms, Pteridophytes, and Bryophytes 
specimens.

geography: Bertioga's restinga (Parque Estadual da Restinga de Bertioga, Portuguese for Bertioga's Restinga State Park); São Paulo; Minas Gerais, in the forest type: Savanna, Seasonal Forest Montana and Campo Rupestre
importantCollectors: ['A. Faccini', 'M. Magenta', 'Z. R. Mello', 'P.S.P. Sampaio']
notes: Our mission is to study the coastal ecosystems of the State of São Paulo that are part of the Atlantic Forest Biome; mainly the Restinga, the Mangrove and the Dense Ombrophilous Forest. Our goal is also to serve as a basis and assist in the research and scientific initiation of undergraduate students in the Biology, Pharmacy, Nutrition courses; and postgraduate studies in Ecology offered within the Postgraduate Program in Sustainability of Coastal and Marine Ecosystems at Unisanta (ECOMAR).  Among the most collected locations, the Flora of the Restinga de Bertioga State Park (PERB) emerges as the most relevant collection in our collection, followed by other locations in Baixada Santista; but we also have the largest collection in the country of the Flora of São Thomé das Letras – MG; thanks to a technical cooperation between the city hall of that municipality and the HUSC and includes the plant formations of Cerrado and Campo Rupestre.

NGBB Herbarium is the central hub for Turkish floristic studies. Illustrated Flora of Turkey which is our main project is implemented in cooperation with ANG Foundation and Flora Research Association. This project will consist of 33 volumes. Within the framework of this project, following studies have been published: Checklist of vascular plants (2012); New Illustrated Flora of Turkey Volume 1, 2, 3a and 4b(respectively; 2014, 2018, 2022, 2023); Checklist of Bryophytes (2017), Checklist of Lichens (2017), Checklist of Algae (2019) and Checklist of Fungi (2020). The Illustrated Flora of Turkey website is https://www.turkiyeflorasi.org.tr/

Exsiccati of historical Northwest collectors including Suksdorf, Piper, & others are available, as well as original sets of Fungi Columbiani (E. & E., Bartholomew) and North American Fungi (Ellis & Everhart). Collections from the whole USA, Canada, the UK, Austria, Germany, Finland, Romania & E. Europe, Mexico, Brazil, Taiwan & SE Asia, Russia, and New Zealand are also well represented.

importantCollectors: ['P. Anxionnaz', 'L. Baqué', 'J. Beaurepaire', 'V. Boullet', 'A. Chauvrat', 'C. Danger', 'G. Dicque', 'B. Dufour', 'B. Dumeau', 'J. Dupont', 'J. Férard', 'C. Fontaine', 'L. D. B. Gigord', 'E. Grangaud', 'V. Grondin', 'J. Hivert', 'M. Hoareau', 'M. Lacoste', 'C. Lavergne', 'B. Mallet', 'R. Marteau', 'J.-M. Pausé', 'F. Picot', 'A. Rhumeur', 'T. Rochier', 'J.-M. Tamon', 'A. Valéry', 'E. Vallez']
notes:
Updated Dec 2024 (specimen total).  Herbaria of Reunion island and of the Scattered Islands are hosted within the CBNM based in Reunion island. They contain samples of terrestrial vascular plants collected in different islands of the western Indian Ocean: Reunion, Europa, Juan de Nova, Glorioso and Tromelin. Among these are 5 834 specimens from Reunion Island and 2 909 from the Scattered Islands. These herbaria are completed by samples preserved in alcohol, by seed banks and by a collection in silica gel. 
Formal partnerships were established since 2014 with the National Museum of Natural History (P, Paris, France) and with the Missouri Botanical Garden (MO, Saint Louis, USA). In 2019, new partnerships have been created with the herbaria of Mayotte (MAO), Geneve (G) and Madagascar (TAN).
Since July 2016, data from the herbarium of the Scattered Islands are available online on Tropicos® (search by typing \'CBNM\' in the name of Senior Collector).
At the beginning of 2023, the project \\\'Establishment of a protocol for digitization and online sharing of parts of the Scattered Islands herbarium\\\' was accepted thanks to the call for projects \\\'Contribution to naturalist knowledge\\\' of the INPN. The phase of digitization of herbarium parts was thus able to be initiated thanks to the acquisition of equipment and the training of CBNM\\\'s agents. A digitization protocol is being drafted and will subsequently be applied to all of the CBNM\\\'s herbaria. The diffusion of very high resolution images and associated information will be done through a network of partners with online consultation platforms (e-ReColNat network, UMR PVBMT, Muséum National d\\\'Histoire Naturelle de Paris, IRD, Missouri Botanical Garden ).

Entered Dec 2017. Our herbarium contains species that are found within tall grass prairie habitat in southern Manitoba. It also includes specimens from local forested areas. The herbarium is intended to provide evidence of occurrence for prairie species, which is of great importance for an endangered ecosystem. It is also a teaching collection, with specimens available to the public for viewing in a protected exhibit.

organization: Universidade Federal do Oeste da Bahia
importantCollectors: ['G. O. Almeida', 'J. A. S. Costa']
notes:
Entered Dec 2017. The herbarium BRBA is young, however is the unique collection located in the west of Bahia state. The west of Bahia is covered by a great extension of Cerrado vegation. The BRBA herbarium has almost 90% of its collection from closest areas in distinct physiognomies of this vegetation.  Informatization and digitalization of all especimens are avaliable. We are in collaboration and we have a support of Jardim Botânico do Rio de Janeiro (JBRJ). Our system of curatorship is associated with JABOT. More information about BRBA is listed: Angiosperms correspond to 93.9% of all collection; Around 42% are determinated until species level; The more representative family is Leguminosae (1207 specimens), the second Malpighiaceae (171 specimens); In addition to Bahia there are plants from 19 others Brazilian states. 

We don’t have a specific and specialized staff beyond the curator, the activities of the herbarium are working with students and volunteers.

importantCollectors: ['F. H. Muniz', 'F. Norberto', 'A. Fernandes', 'R. Nina']
notes: Entered Dec 2017. The Herbarium SLUI has a collection of plants that have been collected since 1988 in the State of Maranhão. Since 2009, the Herbarium has been registered in the Brazilian Herbarium Network of the Brazilian Botanic Society (SBB) as Herbarium Rosa Mochel (SLUI), and in 2010 it joined the INCT - Virtual Herbarium Institute of Flora and Fungi of Brazil. With the support of INCT - Virtual Herbarium of Flora and Fungi of Brazil and FAPEMA, SLUI began the process of computerizing the data of the collection, and its inclusion in the speciesLink network, of the Reference Center on Environmental Information. In 2017 the scanning of the collection with image capture began. Currently 131 exsicatas (about 2% of the collection) are available online on the speciesLink network. The SLUI collection has about 5,500 samples of botanical material, mainly exsicates, predominating the angiosperms, with 117 families represented. The collection also has 50 pteridophytes, 26 bryophytes, 24 macroscopic algae and two gymnosperms. In addition to the collection of exsicatas, a xiloteca (174 specimens), a carpoteca (50 specimens), a collection of seeds (35 samples) and a small collection of macroscopic fungi (10 samples) are available. The collections represent mainly the vegetation of the state: Amazonian forest; Thick; The majority of samples come from the State of Maranhão (70%), although there is a collection of flora from 15 states in Brazil, mainly from donations. The main families represented are Fabaceae (616 records), Malvaceae (420), Cyperaceae (340), Malpighiaceae (290) and Asteraceae (270).

notes: Entered Dec 2017. The Herbarium of Vietnamese Academy of Forest Sciences (VAFS) is one of the largest herbaria in North of Vietnam, with over 10.000 sheets of vascular plants from around Vietnam (major main wood trees and bamboos). Graduate and undergraduate students use herbarium material to identify plants and determine plant locations. Tours are conducted for numerous school groups, and other organizations. In addition, the collection grows steadily through local field work and donated material; and researchers at VAFS, especially those involved with floristic work, deposit their voucher sets for their projects at the Herbarium.

Entered Feb 2018.  The herbarium is engaged in extensive explorations and research studies that are highlighted on the TrEE lab website: http://treelab.wixsite.com/tree
A shade-house is attached along with the TrEE lab and the herbarium where live collection are maintained for genomic and ecological studies. Each collection is linked to the herbarium voucher and collection meta data. The herbarium facilitates research projects for both masters and PhD students.
The herbarium is attached to the institutional library which hosts relevant text books and literature related to plant systematics, ecology and botanical collections. This herbarium posses herbarium material of local flora (Kerala) especially of the Western Ghats area and special attention is given to the aquatic angiosperms, local Bryophytes and Pteridophytes. The authentic specimens of the books 'Eriocaulaceae in India' (R. Ansari), 'Nymphaeceae in India' (R. Ansari), 'Ferns and Fern allies of Kerala' (P.V. Madhusoodanan) etc. are deposited in this herbarium. Type specimens of few new species published by scientists in this institute and from other institutions in Kerala are also deposited. This is the only herbarium in south India where specimens of lower groups of plants are preserved.

organization: Universidade Federal do Estado do Rio de Janeiro
taxonomicCoverage: Marine Algae, Inselberg Flora, Sandbank Vegetation
importantCollectors: ['C P Bove']
notes:
The Herbarium Jorge Pedro Pereira Carauta (HUNI) of the Federal University of Rio de Janeiro State (UNIRIO) was founded in 1998 by Profa. Dr. Claudia Petean Bove. 
It is accredited at the Brazilian Herbarium Network (RBH), the Index Herbariorum (IH), the Ministry of the Environment (MMA) and the Genetic Heritage Management Council (CGEN) as the Depository Institution of Genetic Heritage components.
Its collection has, mainly, samples of the ficological flora and Atlantic Forest vegetation of the State of Rio de Janeiro and associated ecosystems, such as restingas and Sugar Loaf Complex.
In the algae collection, the highlight is over 1000 Dictyotaceae samples collected along the Brazilian coast. HUNI still has about 800 samples that mark the foundation of the herbarium and that make up the Claudia Bove Vascular Aquatic Plant Collection.

organization: Medicinal Plant and Traditional Medicinal Medicine Research and Development Center
division: National Institute of Health Research and Development
notes: Herbarium Tawangmanguensis is a specific herbarium for medicinal plant specimen collection, especially specimen collection from RISTOJA (Research of Indonesian Medicinal Plant). RISTOJA was held in 2012, 2015, and 2017, covering 405 ethnic groups in 34 provinces over the Indonesian country and collected ± 28,000 medicinal plant specimen herbarium. The collection also includes of ca. 200 spirit collections and ca. 300 simplicias (herb dried material) that are maintained and stored in Museum of Jamu (Indonesian Traditional Medicine) alongside Herbarium Tawangmanguensis.

department: Chemical, Biological, Pharmaceutical and Environmental Sciences
geography: Mediterranean Sea, mainly Italian coasts. Occasional samples from other areas.
notes: The herbarium includes exsiccata of macroalgae, mainly seaweeds collected in the Mediterranean. A few seagrasses from are present. Most specimens are linked with formalin and/or silica preserved and DNA subsamples. Related information, including collection data (georeferenced), taxonomy, sequence accessions submitted in public databases, are filed and available on request. The main purpose of the herbarium is to create a referenced collection linked to the research activity of the Phylogenetic Laboratory of the Department. DNA data are submitted to the BOLD Systems.

notes:
Somaliland is considered by the United Nations to be part of Somalia but it declared its independence in 1991 and has functioned separately since that time. HARG was started in 2016 to be a primary resource for research and education about Somaliland’s plants, fungi and plants. At present it houses only vascular plants.
There is NO regular mail service in Somaliland; one can send items via DHL but it is expensive. Neither the herbarium nor the university can pay for DHL service. The herbarium does not as yet have an accumulation of specimens for exchange.

geography: Flora of St. Lawrence County, NY
notes: Entered June 2018.  The SUNY Potsdam Herbarium is a small regional collection mostly centered in St. Lawrence County, NY.  There are some subcollections from CO, FL, CT, and NJ.  Our 1900 specimen collection dates back to the 1930s and contains mostly seed plants.  Our main purpose is to serve as a teaching resource and and a source of local flora data.  We are in the very beginning stages of accessioning and digitizing our collection.

geography: Plants of central and western Canada
importantCollectors: ['I. D. Madonald']
notes:
St. Mary’s University is a small liberal arts and science institution with an established science program. This is a teaching and research herbarium based on 50 years of collections by I. D. Macdonald and more recently Dr. Mason Kulbaba. The herbarium also is the official repository for collections from the adjacent Fish Creek Provincial Park. As well, the collection houses many voucher specimens for Dr. McLean’s research into Thesium ramosum Hayne (Thesiaceae), and Macdonald’s research on the vascular plant floras of 1) the LaCloche Mountains (Ontario); 2) the City of Terre Haute (Indiana); 3) the Rattray’s Marsh Conservation Area (Ontario). 

    The herbarium collection currently represents157 Families, 742 Genera and 2493 Species.

    The current accessioned collections are from the following jurisdictions: Ontario (1050 specimens), Alberta (1005), Indiana (431), Saskatchewan (372), British Columbia (332), Montana (212), Manitoba (156), and the remainder are from across the continent.

    As well, there are well over 1,000 additional collections representing an additional over 200 species waiting for processing and official accessioning into the herbarium.

notes: Entered 2018.  We are a non-governmental organization with research, diffusion, ambiental education and conservation proposal. We have recently created our fungarium to continuing doing research, and to publicate our studies on journals and in a free access web page, to contribute to Chilean fungal knowledge. Then, we will send collections replicates to National Natural History Museum (SGO). We have above of 900 fungal collections, that they are been being incorporated into the collection continuously. Every year we are visiting native Chilean forests to collect fungi, and then do taxonomic and ecological studies.

taxonomicCoverage: Angiosperm (exclusively medicinal plants with tradicional/cientifical uses registered)
importantCollectors: ['M. N. Galvão', 'M. Machado', "C.Y'G. Manão", 'S. Monteiro', 'P. N. Teles']
notes:
Entered Jan 2019.  The Botanical Collection of Medicinal Plants, CBPM, was established with the support from the Institute of Pharmaceutical Technology (Farmanguinhos) / Fiocruz. It aims to ensure the botanical identification and traceability of plant species of medical interest in order to facilitate secure access and rational use of medicinal plants and herbal medicines, promoting the sustainable use of biodiversity and the development of Science, Techonology & Inovation projects related to drugs from plant origin, in accordance with the precepts of the National Policy of Medical Plants and Herbal Medicines (Política Nacional de Plantas Medicinais e Fitoterápicos - PNPMF).
The herbarium is registered in the Brazilian Herbaria Network formed from the "Herbaria Comission" of Brazil Botanical Society (Sociedade Botânica do Brasil - SBB) and is part of the Agroecological Platform of Phytomedicine (Plataforma Agroecológica de Fitomedicamentos -PAF) from the Management Center for Biodiversity and Health (Núcleo de Gestão em Biodiversidade e Saúde - NGBS) - Farmanguinhos / Fiocruz. The CBPM is dedicated to collecting, georeferencing, storage, exchange, preservation and botanical identification of medicinal plants, as well as providing advisory services in the areas of botany, ethnobotany and pharmacobotany to meet the institutions whose projects are registered in the PAF.

importantCollectors: ['T. Kemper', 'S. E. Verlinde']
notes:
The UW Bothell Herbarium provides a critical authoritative record of plants occurring in the University of Washington Bothell and Cascadia College co-located campus wetland and the greater North Creek Basin. As the vegetation changes through time in the wetland it will form a reliable record to help us and future researchers understand biological and habitat change in one of our regions’ preeminent floodplain restoration projects. Collections focus on Snohomish and north King Counties, Washington, USA. It functions primarily as a teaching collection for undergraduate students, faculty, and researchers. It is open to the public by appointment.

The herbarium was founded in 2009 by Tyson Kemper, and 150 collections were added over the course of 7 years. In 2015, Sarah Verlinde started collecting as a student researcher. While collecting, she started a small volunteer team, and in the first year added another 100 specimens. In 2016, Sarah was hired full-time by the Office of Research (the herbarium sponsor), and continued to run the herbarium on a part-time basis. In three years, her team has added 750 more specimens. They joined an online consortium through the University of Washington herbarium at the Burke Museum (WTU) and now photograph and publish the specimens online at www.pnwherbaria.org.

notes: BANNU was established to promote scientific study of the flora of the area traditionally known as Waziristan and now included in four districts ( Bannu, North Waziristan, Upper South Waziristan, Lower South Waziristan) and adjacent parts of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Province. This area has been poorly explored so little is known about the species present and their use by people in the area. Establishing the herbarium has assisted in engaging local students in learning about the flora. A long term goal is to develop a flora for the four districts. BANNU started sharing its records via OpenHerbarium (http://www.openherbarium.org) in the summer of 2019. It will be using tools in OpenHerbarium to develop a regional flora.

incorporatedHerbaria: ['BIF-CEYL (Herbier de Ceylan collected by Hermann; Ms 973 Res, 213 specimens on 171 pages)', 'BIF-LAPP (Herbier de Laponie collected by Linnaeus; Ms 3912 Res, 379 specimens on 155 pages)']
importantCollectors: ['P. Hermann', 'C. Linnæus']
notes: The library of the Institut de France in Paris holds two important herbaria bound in separate folio volumes. They were originally part of the collection of Johannes Burman (1706-1779) and his son Nicolaas Laurens Burman (1734-1793) which was acquired by Benjamin Delessert (1773-1847) in 1801 (see Wijnands et al., 2017). Delessert’s herbarium came to the City of Geneva in 1869 while his library went to the Institut de France. The main Burman herbarium is now incorporated in the Pre-Linnaean herbarium in Geneva (now G-PREL). However, two bound herbarium volumes were treated as part of the Delessert manuscripts and given to the Institut de France. The first of these contains material from Ceylon collected by Paul Hermann (1646-1695) which was the main basis of Johannes Burman’s Thesaurus Zeylanicus. Lourteig (1966) has provided a detailed catalogue of this herbarium (now BIF-CEYL). The second herbarium volume contains material collected by Carl Linnæus (1707-1778) during his Lapland journey in 1732. The specimens in this volume were annotated by Linnæus with the corresponding number of each species in his Flora Lapponica (1737) (see Jarvis, 2007). Jarvis & Jonsell (2003) have provided a detailed catalogue of this herbarium (now BIF-LAPP). [Compiled by M.W. Callmander and C. Jarvis, Apr. 2019]

importantCollectors: ['R. Abbassi', 'S. Ahmad', 'M. Ajaib', 'P. Akhter', 'R. Akhtar', 'Attaullah', 'R. Bukhari', 'D. Dyal', 'N. Habib', 'S. Haqani', 'A.C. Joshi', 'S. Kashmiri', 'Z. Khan', 'S. Muhammad', 'R. Parshad', 'D. Ram', 'Saadullah', 'R. Sahai', 'K.H. Sheikh', 'M. Sultan']
notes:
The Department of Botany is one of the oldest departments in the University, being established in 1912.  Prof. Shiv Ram Kashyap, who was the department head from 1912 to 1934, established a museum and herbarium. The herbarium’s holdings included plants from many regions, including China, Indonesia and Philippines, and its collection of liverworts and mosses was considered the largest in the subcontinent at that time. The collection grew to include several hundred specimens of algae, fungi, bryophytes, pteridophytes, gymnosperms and angiosperms but, when the University of the Punjab was established as a separate institution, most of the specimens were transferred there. The present museum and herbarium are named the Prof. Kashyap Museum and Dr. Sultan Ahmed Herbarium. Both are being actively developed. 

The Department also has a botanic garden, Botanic Garden GCU, which was founded in 1912 and extends over 7 acres. It has long been recognized for the diversity of its holdings. It is home to Pakistan’s Botanic Gardens Network Secretariat.

Schenck (Charophyta, Chlorophyta, Rhodophyta, and Pheophyta, Nord Sea and Brazil, XIX century)', 'T. Daleszyńska (Charophyta, Poland and Litva, XX century)', 'D. Fijałkowski (Charophyta, Poland, XX century)', 'C. F. O. Nordstedt and L. J. Wahlstedt (Charophyta, Scandinavia,XIX century)', 'C. Lützow (Charophyta', 'Poland, XIX century)', 'W. Torka (Bacillariophyceae', 'Poland and Germany, XIX - XX century)', 'J. Pantoschek (Bacillarophyceae, Poland, 1889-1935)', 'I. Dąmbska ((Charophyta, Europe, XX century)']
importantCollectors: ['M. Gabka', 'M. Pelechaty', 'A. S. Rybak']
notes:
Entered Jun 2019.  The Collections of Macro and Microalgae:

(1) The collection of Charophytes – stoneworts (The collection gathered under the guidance of Professor Isabelle Dąmbska): The collection includes ca. 1 400 herbarium sheets of more than 60 taxa from the Europe. It holds the largest collection of duplicates and materials from publishing herbarium, known as ‘Charotheca Polonica’. The Charotheca Polonica collections comprise ca. 3 000 herbarium sheets. The Herbarium of Isabelle Dąmbska holds the largest collection of Polish stoneworts, and has large collections from France, Denmark, Czech Republic, Slovakia, the former Yugoslavia, and from the Mediterranean Sea. The Collection containing many of allegates of rare stoneworts, some dating back to 1900 (mostly from the Europe), and currently includes almost 1 000 sheets. The Herbarium contains over a dozen of type specimens (the stonewort specimen to which the scientific name of that species is attached). The herbarium sheets of stoneworts are catalogued in 80 %.

(2) The Herbarium-related publications from XIX century: The collection includes ca. 1 500 herbarium sheets. The most important exsiccata are a part of the series such as: Die Algen Sachsens, and Die Characeen Europa’s. In the collection there are around several of types specimens. In addition the collection contains over several hundred specimens of microalgae (including the blue algae) on microscope slides. The most valuable exsiccata from the 19th and early 20th century are associated in the collections of L. Rabenhorst (collected in the years 1848-1877). For more details please see the “Rabenhorst’s algae in Polish collections” by Burchardt et al. 1999.

notes:
The Dian Fossey Gorilla Fund International Herbarium is a unit of the Karisoke Research Center, a research institute and program of the Dian Fossey Gorilla Fund in Rwanda's Volcanoes National Park. It was founded by Dian Fossey on 24 September 1967 to study endangered mountain gorillas. Fossey located the camp in Rwanda's Virunga volcanic mountain range, between Mount Karisimbi and Mount Bisoke, and named it by combining the names of the two mountains.

Today, Karisoke continues to upgrade its capacity for scientific research through new technology and new partnerships with local authorities and other conservation organizations. Recently, comedian Ellen DeGeneres plans to help build a permanent home in Rwanda for the work of the Fossey Fund to protect critically endangered mountain gorillas. The Ellen DeGeneres Campus of the Fossey Gorilla Fund is to be a permanent, specially designed facility for scientists who are helping to save mountain gorillas.

taxonomicCoverage: Seed plants, gymnosperms, ferns, lycophytes, bryophytes, lichens, macrofungi
geography: South America, Colombia, Departments Boyacá, Cundinamarca, Distrito Capital, Norte de Santander, Santander, Colombian Cordillera Oriental, 300-3850 masl
notes:
The J.J. Triana Herbarium (HJJT) promotes the floristic knowledge of the mountainous regions of Colombia and northern South America, contributing to the sustainable appropriation of natural resources, the ecological restoration of mountain ecosystems, and their conservation over time, in a joint effort among academia, civil society and rural communities.

The HJJT Herbarium is a repository of dried botanical specimens of angiosperms, gymnosperms, ferns and lycophytes, bryophytes, lichens and macro fungi. It also considers the preservation of ancillary samples of seeds and fruits, material in liquid preservative, tissues in silica gel, and prepared microscope slides. The collection also houses a Spore and Tissue Bank of Isoetes and Pteridophyta, dried and preserved in Eppendorf tubes.

Its mission is to encourage research and knowledge construction on Colombian and Neotropical flora, with emphasis on high and middle mountain ecosystems, providing strategic floristic and environmental data as supplies for accurate environmental decisions, as well as to plan and implement strategic actions towards the conservation and sustainable use of renewable natural resources at local, national and regional scales.

['P.B.McKenna Ufer']
notes:
The CMLR herbarium is located at The University of Queensland, Brisbane, Australia and is a dedicated room with a large collection of plant specimens and plant identification resources such as powerful microscopes and a library of identification books. The herbarium contains up to 5,000 specimens as well an online digital herbarium which is a database containing high resolution scans of over 1,200 plant specimens. 
The herbarium is the only dedicated herbarium at The University of Brisbane and is a unique resource for researchers and students to confirm the identification of plant species related to land rehabilitation in Queensland, New South Wales and the Northern Territory. The herbarium also has one of the most comprehensive collections of species that are found in the endangered swamps of the Newnes Plateau (Western Blue Mountains region, New South Wales). The room contains an imaging microscope (Leica M205A) capable of high resolution magnification (160x), digital display, image capture, live measurements and multi-focus image stacking. The room is set at constant temperature (20°C) and humidity (45%) to maintain the preservation of plant samples.
Accurate plant identification is fundamental aspect of environmental surveys, particularly when studying the impacts of mining and the success of land rehabilitation. The herbarium is a place that researchers and students from around the university can work on plant identification, mount specimens for storage, or capture high resolution imagery of plant samples. 
Access to the digital herbarium is available through the CMLR home page and includes high resolution images of scanned specimens, maps of collections and links to online resources.  This digital herbarium is highly valuable to the mining industry, land managers, environmental scientists and plant enthusiasts, with a particular focus around the theme of land rehabilitation.

In 1981, the Government of the Province of San Juan ceded the botanical collection in custody to the National University of San Juan. The collection was increasing year by year thanks to the different research projects of the Institute and Museum of Natural Sciences.
In 2017 the collection adopted the name of ""Herbario Provincial Saile Echegaray"". Currently, the herbarium has approximately 10,000 sheets that represent a large part of the flora of San Juan.  Besides, the Herbarium is directly linked to the Microhistological Collection, reference patterns are made of the herbalized species, especially of the plants belonging to protected areas of the province.

notes:
Entered Oct 2019.  Herbarium Malangensis is now a member of the Global Registry of Biodiversity Repositories

At present, Monday, September 27, 2016; Herbarium Malangensis has been a member of the Global Registry of Biodiversity Repositories (GRBio).
GRBio is the first-ever consolidated, comprehensive clearinghouse of information about biological collections in natural history museums, herbaria, and other biorepositories.  This online-registry is a source for authoritative information about collections as well as validated, standardized data such as addresses, contacts, and values for the Darwin Core identifiers for institutions (institution code) and collections (collection code).  Personal collections can also be registered here, whether they belong to private collectors or are research collections that haven’t yet been accessioned into an institutional collection.
Link: http://grbio.org/institution/herbarium-malangensis

notes: The objective of HECASA Herbarium is to contribute to the taxonomic inventory from Colombian Northeastern flora, to know the taxa distribution and to actualize the botanical nomenclature through the consolidation of a referential specimens collection to strengthen the principles of knowledge, conservation and sustainable use in the local, regional and national context. HECASA Herbarium wants to become in the principal botanical collection and the most important information source about taxonomy, morphology, anatomy, phytogeography and conservation of vegetal species from the region. Also, the herbarium looks for support undergraduate and postgraduate research projects especially from University of Pamplona, social diffusion and cooperation between public and private actors interested in environmental issues.

notes: Entered December 2019.  The Micoteca of Diversity and Fungal Interactions (MICODIF), began in 2003 with the own funds of researchers and the financing of the Science and Technology Secretary of the Faculty of Chemistry, Biochemistry and Pharmacy of the National University of San Luis (FQByF-UNSL) , as one of the objectives of Projects developed and in execution. The collected specimens, the slide collection of Mushrooms native to the region and arid areas of the country and the permanent preparations made by the group of teachers-researchers of these Projects, constitute this Micoteca that obtained in 2014 its legal framework and institutional belonging and in 2015 joined to the National Biological Data System (SNDB) as Unit 266-360. It has more than 1800 specimens that include Fungi s. l. (Ascomycota; Basidiomycota; Mucoromycota, Glomeromycotina; Amebozoa, Myxomycota), adding Plantae with symbiotic (mycorrhizal and endophytic) fungal hosts, and Lichens. The Group of work of MICODIF is composed of: D  r. M. A. Lugo (Responsible), Biól. EM Crespo (Curator), Mic. Hebe Iriarte (Technical Assistant), and the Advisory Council that represents teachers and / or researchers in the subject and other disciplines of the UNSL (Dr. E. Menoyo, Ing. Agr. S. Ballesteros, Lic. A. Ochoa, Dr A. Mangione, RA Paez) and other Universities and Collections of the SNDB (Dr. LS Dominguez, Curator of Cryptogams-Herbarium CORD; Dr. E. Nouhra, IMBIV-UNC).

notes:
Entered Jan 2020.
Qarshi Botanical Garden,  is located on the premises of Qarshi Industries (Pvt.) Ltd, Industrial Estate Hattar, District Haripur, KPK, Pakistan on Taxila - Haripur road. It is 60 km from zero-point Islamabad. The geographical significance of Haripur district lies in the fact that its boundaries touch Abbotabad in north-east, Margalla hills of Islamabad in the South-east, Swat valley in the north-west and Sawabi district in the west. Besides, two districts of Punjab province i.e. Attock &Rawalpindi lie on the south-west & south-east respectively. Hattar Industrial Estate, Haripur falls under sub-tropical climatic zone and is situated in the foothills of Himalayas at the latitude 33º 44' to 34º 22' and longitude 72 º 35' to 73º 15' and 610 m above sea level. The mean minimum & maximum annual rainfall ranges from 800 - 1300 mm respectively & average winter temperature is 12oC and summer temperature is around 29oC. However, maximum temperature rises to >40ºC in summer and the lowest temperature in the winter fall below - 4ºC. Depending upon the weather conditions, sometime severe frost is observed during the month of December & January.
Medicinal plant species are those that provide people with medicines to prevent diseases, maintain health or cure ailment. Therefore, medicinal plants are important in the wellbeing of people yet most people are not aware about these species or their medicinal value. Examples of these plants include Aloe vera, Azadirachta indica and many others.
Medicinal plant species are of great value to mankind and other animals but not much emphasis is laid on their conservation, especially ex-situ conservation, given their ever dwindling natural habitats. Conservation of medicinal plants involves the sustainable utilization of medicinal plant resources that is in such a way that they satisfy the needs of today’s generation without hindering the ability of tomorrow’s generations to satisfy their own needs. This can easily be simplified as: “when you are eating today, remember to leave some for those who will be there tomorrow.”
Some of the plant species have already been extinct, other are declared threatened, endangered or rare mainly due to improper harvesting practices incompatible with their survival or habitat degradation due to landuse changes in favor of the development paradigm. The ever-dwindling natural habitats of these medicinal plants have left ex-situ conservation as the most preferable choice. This ex-situ conservation falls under the programs of institutions such as botanic gardens/herbal gardens that are encouraged by the Convention on Biological Diversity framework.
Therefore, Qarshi Industries (Pvt) Ltd. under its environmental policy and biodiversity conservation agenda has committed itself to protect, conserve and propagate endangered plant species in general and medicinal plant species in particular. To achieve the objectives, Qarshi Botanical Garden (QBG) was established in 2001 to conserve and propagate commercially important indigenous plant species.

organization: Centre for Implementation and Research of Plant Health Clinic
taxonomicCoverage: Plant pathogenic fungi, oomycetes and bacteria
importantCollectors: ['M. Kara', 'S. Kurt', 'S. Soylu', 'E.M. Soylu', 'A. Uysal']
notes:
Entered Jan 2020.  Mustafa Kemal University Plant Protection Department (MKUBK) was established in 1993. Department is giving both academic education and research activities with 15 full-time Professors, Associate Professor and Research assistant. Especially Plant Mycology and Bacteriology labs are collecting several disease samples not only from the region but also from different parts of Turkey. 
In 2017, Centre for Implementation and Research of Plant Health Clinic (MKU-BISAK) was established officially as part of the Plant Protection Department to help producers (farmers) for identification and giving advice to farmers from all around from Turkey. 
Each year, Bsc, Msc and PhD students working on plant pathogenic fungi and bacteria collect several infected plant samples, isolate  and identify causal disease agents from diseased samples. In centre, all disease agents are either kept as herbaria on its host plants or isolated microbial culture on nutrient media. 
BİSAK maintains several plant pathogenic fungi and bacterial culture collections (published or unpublished) in its centre. This center also giving services to anyone who wants to identify their fungal and bacterial agents. Center has more than 500 samples

Casa da Floresta is a Brazilian company focused in biodiversity studies and environmental services. The CASA herbarium was created to house the collections made by the company’s team during field work. Despite being a private herbarium, CASA is open for researchers and students interested in its collections. The subscription in Index Herbariorum system is intended to give the herbarium more visibility and to formally occupy the chosen acronym.

importantCollectors: ['A. B. Czhobadze', 'S. A. Kutenkov', 'D. A. Philippov', 'A. A. Prokin', 'A. A. Przhiboro']
notes: Entered Feb 2020.  Founded in 2015, Herbarium of the Mire Research Group, Papanin Institute for Biology of Inland Waters Russian Academy of Sciences, aims to study the phytodiversity of mires and peatlands. Plant collection, started by D.A. Philippov in 2005, formed the basis for the Herbarium. To date, the Herbarium contains over 7500 plant specimens, including Seed Plants and Pteridophytes – 3110, Bryophytes (mosses and liverworts) – 4150, Algae (incl. Charophytes) – 140, Lichens – 190. Special attention is paid to Sphagnum mosses. The main collection areas are Northern and Central parts of European Russia and Northern Caucasus. Also, collections from mires of Georgia and Chile are present.

taxonomicCoverage: The focal point of the Tebiwa Herbarium is to establish a comprehensive collection of vascular plants, lichens, bryophytes, and fungi utilized and appreciated by the Davis Newe family and ancestors. The Newe are the Indigenous peoples whose ancestral homeland spanned portions of the Snake, Yellowstone, Bear, and Salmon River watersheds (USA) and beyond.
importantCollectors: ['C Davis']
notes: Entered March 2020. At the Tebiwa Herbarium we strive to include Panakwate (Bannock) and Sosoni (Shoshone) language names and uses on specimen labels. The Herbarium also houses collections of vascular plant associates of the peyote cactus (Lophophora williamsii), as well as vascular plants and biological soil crusts from the Palouse Prairie in northern Idaho and southeastern Washington. Access and use of the Tebiwa Herbarium is by appointment only.

notes: Entered Май 2020. Founded in 1912, Herbarium of the Vologda State University aims to study the phytodiversity of the Vologda Region. During its existence, the herbarium was located in the city of Vologda; still, it repeatedly changed its formal affiliations: Vologda Teachers Training Institute (1912–1918), Vologda Pedagogical Institute (1918–1923), Severnyi Krai Pedagogical Institute (1930–1932), Vologda State Pedagogical Institute (1932–1995), Vologda State Pedagogical University (1995–2014), and Vologda State University (2014–to date). For the last thirty years, the herbarium has a dual purpose and is used for educational and scientific purposes. For ease of use, it is divided into three sections: main, geographic, and demonstration sections. The main section includes collections of higher vascular plants and cryptogams (bryophytes and lichens). These collections mainly cover the Vologda Region, yet with high density. The main section comprises samples from at least 250 local floras. Herbarium possesses one isotype and two paratypes of Potamogeton × vepsicus. A number of specimens were reviewed by specialists in complex taxonomic groups: P. Uotila (Chenopodiaceae), A.N. Sennikov (Cotoneaster), A.A. Bobrov (Potamogetonaceae, Batrachium, Myriophyllum), V.G. Papchenkov (Salix, Typha). The collection of bryophytes was partially reviewed by E.A. Ignatova. The geographic section of the herbarium contains specimens from the herbaria of botanical gardens (BAK, CHIS, VBGI, Batumi, Sukhumi), universities (LECB, AR, PSK, RV, SIMF, URP, Samarkand State University, Turkmen State Pedagogical Institut

notes: Entered August 2020.  The Herbarium of the State University of Western Paraná was created in August 1996, by Dr. Bartolomeu Tavares, aiming to contribute to the knowledge of undergraduate students. It is one of the few herbaria in the western region of the state whose main role is to maintain a representative collection of regional flora. The Herbarium Unop-Algae was separated from the Herbarium Unop in March 2013, with the purpose of including species of algae, fungi, lichens and bryophytes. The algae samples are collected using plankton nets and after the sample registration in the herbarium these are stored in liquid medium

organization: Somali Region Pastoral and Agro-pastoral Research Institute
notes: Entered August 2020. The Somali Region Pastoral and Agro-pastoral Research Institute is located in the Somali Region [=Province] of Ethiopia. Its herbarium was established in 1995 to provide the comparative material that is essential for studies in taxonomy, ecology, anatomy, conservation biology, biodiversity and many others disciplines. In 2020, the Regions indigenous flora is known to include 58 families, 351 genera, and 1231 species. The focus of the SoR herbarium is regional, with collections being made to document the distribution and use of the indigenous flora and the occurrence and spread of introduced species.

notes:
Entered Nov 2020.  This herbarium is didecated to  support designers work, mainly in landscape architecture, but also architecture and industrial design work. Tthe herbarium fruit collection was obtained through transdisciplinary work and is the basis of  a clolaborative publication “Envolventes” that relates the fruit function with diverse needs in the design professions to achieve efficient wrapped layers. To achieve this goal the team observed and extrapolate the shape, fisiology and functions of different fruits.

An activity carried out at the HEFA is the presentation of exhibitions in which they excel; Paradeisos Herbariorum (2001, José Luis Benllure Gallery, FA); Envolventes (2006, Mexico City METRO System) Envolventes, a object book (2007 3D Museum, Atzcapotalco CDMX); Envolventes book obtained the first place for editorial art in science and technology (2006, CANIEM); Mailkara zapota in archeology (2019, Museum of Sciences and Arts, lobby, UNAM); monthly a showcase is presented with some taxonomic theme the last one, Pteridophytes)

notes: Entered Jan 2021.  The creation of the KMF herbarium was started in 2005 by teachers of the Department of Biology and Chemistry of the Ferenc Rákóczi II Trancarpathian Hungarian College of Higher Education (E. Kohut) and researchers of the Istvan Fodor Scientific-Research center (T. Ljubka; E. Andrik; M. Shevera). In the collection of the KMF Herbarium contain materials that present the flora of Transcarpathian region, mainly the Transcarpathian lowland, but also the Ukrainian Carpathians. Today the herbarium has more than 6000 collected herbarium specimens of vascular plants. The herbarium is organized according to  the system of Dalla Torre & Harms.

organization: Fort Worth Nature Center and Refuge
importantCollectors: ['C. Daugirda,', 'J. Snowden', 'D. Sylvester']
notes: Entered Febf. 2020.  At 3,621 acres, the Fort Worth Nature Center and Refuge is one of the largest city-owned nature centers in the United States.  Created in the 1960s with the help of local citizens’ groups, the Center’s development built on earlier efforts to protect the watershed feeding the Lake Worth reservoir in the western portion of the Dallas-Fort Worth metroplex.  Dora Sylvester, a science educator and naturalist who was a major force in the Center’s creation, understood the importance of herbaria in documenting past and present plant diversity at managed nature preserves, and established the FWNC herbarium.  The herbarium started mainly with her own collections from the property and has been supplemented with vouchers from more recent vegetation studies, as well as those made by other volunteers, staff, and students from local universities.  The herbarium additionally serves a role in the training of staff and volunteers, and also in the Center’s education programs for adults and school children.

The herbarium includes collections mainly from the territory of the Tyumen region; a significant part of the samples was collected in other areas within Western Siberia (Khanty-Mansi Autonomous Okrug-Yugra, Yamalo-Nenets Autonomous Okrug, Altai). Also presented are materials from the European part of Russia - the Cis-Urals, the Upper and Lower Volga. Particularly valuable in the collection are specimens of plant and fungi species included in the Red Data Books of the Tyumen Region and the Russian Federation.

['A. W. Lievens, D. Lynch']
notes: Entered May 2021.  The St. Edward’s University Herbarium, which was established in the late 1950s, is a fruit of the work of Brother Daniel Lynch, CSC, and his dedicated students. Br. Daniel (1921–1997) was beloved throughout Central Texas, and many university benefactors contributed to funds that supported his scholarship and his service to marginalized communities. He used some of those funds to buy herbarium cabinets and supplies as he built the collection. He relied heavily on the herbarium as he worked with the illustrator, Nancy McGowan, to complete ""Native and Naturalized Woody Plants of Austin and the Hill Country."" This reference was originally published in 1981 and is still widely used by botanists around the state. In addition to his high level of scholarship, Br. Daniel was a stellar teacher at St. Edward’s for more than 40 years. His students not only learned from the herbarium collection, but they also helped him to build it. Today, the collection is used primarily to support teaching in the natural sciences, but also serves as a repository for voucher specimens documenting the plant diversity of the associated Wild Basin Wilderness Preserve and Creative Research Center.

organization: Oblastní muzeum a galerie v Mostě
geography: Czech Republic, especially Northwestern Bohemia (marginally also other parts of Central Europe)
importantCollectors: ['B. Hulán', 'V. Joza', 'A. Nowák', 'A. Roth', 'J. Sládek', 'P. Zdvořák']
notes:
Entered May 2021. The main part of the herbarium of The Regional Museum and Gallery in Most town is the collection of 1352 specimens created by Jaromír Sládek. It is dated since 1981 to 1992, and it mainly contains records of halophilous and thermophilous taxa from the Northwestern Bohemia (Czech Republic). 
Another part of the collection was created by Bedřich Hulán. It contains about 850 herbarium specimens recording vascular plants flora of northern part of the Most county (i.e. Litvínov town and its vicinity) in years 1950–1961. Another two historical collections created by Anton Roth and Anton Nowák originated in 19th century. Both are of great regional importance owing to including many specimens from totally destroyed localities due to long-term coal mining and another large landscape changes in the region of Northwestern Bohemia.
Current herbarium accessories are focused on document of vascular plant taxa including woody plants and also taxonomically problematic species in the northwestern Bohemia and adjacent regions. The herbarium is currently systematically enriched with vascular plant taxa which has not been included in the collection yet.

geography: Chaco Argentino region and to a lesser extent from other areas of the country (Center), with some specimens from the rest of South America (Peru, Paraguay)
importantCollectors: ['C. Chifa']
notes:
Our collection of plants constitutes a Medicinal Ethnobotanical Herbarium, since the North of Argentina is a privileged area, not only due to the tradition of use of plant species in vernacular medicine, but also due to the extensive existing documentation regarding the use of plants by the aborigines in natural medicine, among which are the tribes (MOCOVÍ, WICHÍ, TOBA). That is why the systematization of the practices that revolve around the recovery of the use of medicinal plants began, where botanical, ecological and anthropological knowledge converge with a scientific basis of the connections that exist between cultural groups and their plant environment.
The main functions of the \""Carlos Chifa\"" herbarium are:
Entered June 2021.
 
This Herbarium, which the “Universidad nacional del Chaco Austral” proudly owns, was the imprint of the Agronomist Carlos Chifa back in 1994, being at that time the Facultad de Agroindustria belonging to UNNE (Universidad Nacional del Nordeste), who making use of his knowledge in the Botanical field and creating strong ties with the original peoples of the region, he knew how to create a large collection of medicinal plants, with more than 5,000 specimens. Serving not only as a source of information for the careers of Medicine, Pharmacy, Veterinary Medicine and Zootechnical Engineering, but also for scientific studies that have been carried out in our house of higher studies.
This information resulted in the Publication of 4 books, which are:
_ Chifa, C. y Ricciardi, A. I. A. (2001). Plantas de uso en medicina vernácula del centro del Chaco argentino. Fundación Miguel Lillo.
_ Chifa, C. (2005). Plantas medicinales usadas por las comunidades aborígenes del Chaco argentino. Editorial Universitaria de la Universidad Nacional del Nordeste.
_ Chifa, C. y Ricciardi A. I. A. (2011). Plantas medicinales usadas por las comunidades aborígenes del Chaco argentino (2 ed.) Ediciones Elemento.
_ Chifa, C. y Ricciardi A. I. A. (2014). Las plantas medicinales del nordeste argentino en las crónicas de la época de la Colonia. Ediciones Elemento.

L’herbier LRVZ est un outil de développement rural sur divers domaines :
-	Diagnostic des ressources pastorales,
-	Caractérisation et classification des pâturages naturels,
-	Cartographie et étude dynamique de la végétation,
-	Effets sur le milieu : suivi des impacts,
-	Diagnostic sur environnemental.
Sur le plan pédagogique, il sert d’outil à la formation et action pour l’amélioration de la gestion des terroirs et à l’enseignement de la Botanique systématique.

department: National Centre for Plant Genetic Resources
importantCollectors: ['W. Kulpa']
notes: Entered Oct. 2021.   Herbarium of National Centre for Plant Genetic Resources: Polish Genebank has an extensive collection of seeds, inflorescences and herbarium sheets, containing over 20 000 samples. Seed collection is the biggest one in Herbarium. It was initiated by dr hab. Władysław Kulpa in the ‘70s. It includes weeds (collected from fields, fallow-lands, ruderal habitats) and crop plants’ seeds. There is a separate collection of seeds collected in the 19th century.  There is a  inflorescence collection as a reference material for the accessions kept under long-term storage. The herbarium sheet collection contains crop plants, their wild relatives and cultivation-accompanying weed species.

division: Office of State Parks/Louisiana State Arboretum
department: Department of Culture, Recreation and Tourism
geography: Evangeline Parish, Chicot State Park, Louisiana State Arboretum SPA
importantCollectors: ['C. M. Allen', 'J. Boos', 'J. P. Robinson', 'N. A. Tuzzolino']
notes:
Entered Feb 2022.  Established in 1961, the Louisiana State Arboretum was the first such area in the South and the first state-supported arboretum in the United States. The 600 acre site is the only Louisiana state-owned  preservation area open to the public, providing a little over 5.5 miles of hiking trails along a Cypress-Tupelo Swamp, through a Bottomland Hardwood Forest and along ridges of a Beech-Magnolia Forest. 
In 1967, Horticulturist Nick A. Tuzzalino collected some of the first plants to be preserved for the arboretum’s herbarium.  In the early 1980’s, Charles A. Allen, at that time a Botany graduate student, was hired to collect and preserve as many plant specimens as he could find and identify in the initial 300 acres open to the public.  There are now about 600 specimens in the herbarium collection.

taxonomicCoverage: Fungi (non-lichenized and lichenized), Algae, Bryophyta, Vascular plants
geography: Poland (predominantly northeast part; Białowieża Primeval Forest)
importantCollectors: ['M. Wołkowycki']
notes:
Entered March 2022.  There are sections in the herbarium with independent specimen numbering, denoted by suffixes added to the main acronym: BLS M – theleomorphic fungi with macroscopic fructifications; BLS F – fungi with microscopic fructifications; BLS L – lichenized fungi; BLS A – algae, BLS B – bryophytes. Vascular plants are documented under acronym BLS without a suffix.
The herbarium includes one of the most representative collection of higher fungi (Ascomycota and Basidiomycota) from Białowieża Primeval Forest. The data about fungi with macroscopic fructifications are included in GBIF system.

notes: Includes the operations of the Herbarium museum and maintaining collected dried specimens and card files, records of acquisitions, loans, exchanges of specimens, and preparing, mounting, repairing, and accessioning herbarium specimens. Organizes educational programs to create environmental awareness among students and trains teachers in environmental education. It coordinates with various programs in the conduct of service-learning on environmental science, biology, and other related sciences. It provides a suitable environment for relaxation and rejuvenation as part of the health and wellness program of the University. Serves as a fundamental resource for all kinds of plant taxonomic studies and botanical pedagogy. It is a repository and conservatory of voucher specimens on which varieties of botanical studies are done. It also facilitates the generation of quantitative baseline data on the distribution and abundance of keystone species; and aids in the assessment and cataloging of all species of economic potential. As commercial species, medicinal herbs, food plants, and others. The Herbarium helps in using the spores and seeds specimens of the herbarium to revive extinct wild species using modern technology. It maintains active links to the international network of systematic resources. This procedure establishes the steps in the operation of the Herbarium. It serves as a guide for the herbarium staff, faculty, students, and stakeholders in ensuring the efficiency and effectiveness of the University Herbarium.

organization: National Council for Scientific and Technical Research (CONICET)
division: Center for Scientific Research and technology transfer to production (CICYTTP)
geography: Entre Ríos Province (Argentina) for the moment
importantCollectors: ['M. di Pasquo', 'E. Rodriguez']
notes:
Entered Jun 2022.  Our herbarium started in 2011 belonging to the Laboratory of Palynostratigraphy and Paleobotany (di Pasquo and Silvestri, 2014), in the Center for Scientific Research and technology transfer to production CICYTTP (CONICET-ER-UADER), sited in Diamante, Entre Ríos province, Argentina.
It is composed of plants collected mainly in the El Palmar National Park located in the eastern Entre Ríos Province where the palm Butia yatay is the main protected tree of a savanna environment along with Poaceae and Asteraceae (see Batista et al. 2014; Rodriguez et al. 2017). di Pasquo et al. (2016) published for the first time, in situ spores using the Herbarium Lorentz (code DTE), which belongs to the CICYTTP. A new herbarium collection is registered herein with the acronym LPPH to include spores and pollen in situ mostly from Entre Ríos but also, from other regions of Argentina. The LPP is also registered as colaborator group of the RCPol - Red de Catálogos Polínicos online (http://rcpol.org.br/es/quem-somos/labs-grupos-pesquisa/laboratorio-de-palinoestratigrafia-y-paleobotanica/) since 2016.
The specimens are not digitalized yet, although they are given a number in a spreadsheet.
Entered Jun 2022.

notes: Entered Jun 2022.  St. Joseph's College Herbarium, Irinjalakuda started with the establishment of Botany Department in the college. During theses years, the herbarium enriched with its number of herbarium sheets and spirit collection. Presently, it accommodates more than 3000 herbarium sheets and 100 spirit collections of Algae, Fungi, Bryophytes, Pteridophytes, Gymnosperms and Angiosperms. It also consists of  seven type specimens. Now a days the herbarium is equipped digitalization of whole specimens.

Entered Aug 2022.  The National Herbarium of Türkiye was established in 2020 within the National Botanical Garden of Türkiye, which is a Governmental Institute. The material capacity is more than 3 million. However, because it is newly established, the current number of material is so below its capacity. The herbarium is the first as a Governmental Herbarium and has the biggest capacity in the country. As it is a Governmental Herbarium, we would like to get the code TC which is the abbreviation of Türkiye Cumhuriyeti (Republic of Türkiye). 
We will be really glad, if we can get the code TC for our National Herbarium. 
Sincerely.

geography: Perak phytogeographical province and its subprovince
incorporatedHerbaria: ['Typical herbarium', 'more than 150 families', 'more than 200 genera collected since 2008']
importantCollectors: ['A.A. Aminudin & M.Y. Ahmad Sahar', 'M. Fatimah']
notes: Entered Sep 2022.  Our herbarium houses all ranks of plants families ranging from Bryophytes, Lycophytes, Ferns and Fern allies, Gymnosperms, Basal Angiosperms, Magnoliids, Eudicot and Monocots of Perak phytogeographical province and its sub province. This area actually rich in endemic plants due to the overlapping of three different forests i.e. the Asiatic seasonal intrusion, limestone hills and the main range forests. The Perak phytogeographical areas is known as special pocket of endemic plants. On top of that, Perak also has a coastal hill dipterocarp forest, that is unique to our world. The Royal Belum of the northern of Perak is known as the oldest forest that still not fully surveyed. Our voucher specimen collections covers all areas of Perak phytogeographical region.

The most important collections are coprinoid fungi (ca. 3 000 specimens), Tulostoma (ca. 450 specimens), and Lepiota s.l. (ca. 1 500 specimens).

importantCollectors: ['T.H.R. Belgica', 'R.V. Dumilag']
notes: Entered October 2022

Entered Oct 2022.  The Terrestrial Ecosystem Research Network (TERN) is Australia’s land ecosystem observatory and is enabled by the Australian Government’s National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy (NCRIS). 

TERN measures key terrestrial ecosystem attributes over time from continental scale to fields sites at hundreds of representative locations across Australia’s major biomes and openly provide model ready data that enable researchers to detect and interpret changes in land ecosystems. 

TERN’s Ecosystem Surveillance platform conducts field surveys and sampling across a national network of plots and transects to provide the data, samples and advice required for improved monitoring and assessment of Australia’s major ecosystem. The platform helps scientists and land managers better detect and quantify change in vegetation structure and composition, land cover and soil characteristics. 
The platform collects representative plant specimens within the 1ha plots and associated leaf tissue samples stored in Silica Gel. The specimens are thus part of a long-term continental scale ecological monitoring program with rich temporal data. Plant specimens are collected on each revisit; therefore, the collection differs to that of a traditional herbarium. The plant specimen collection represents 5,804 vascular plant species, equating to 24.18% of the Australian flora. As well as plant specimens and leaf tissue samples, soil samples are collected, including bulk density samples and soil metagenomic samples.

The plant specimens are stored in Adelaide, South Australia and are available to loan for downstream research. The TERN Australia Soil and Herbarium Collection does not accept exchanges; however, we are in partnership with the State Herbarium of South Australia (AD) that do accept exchanges.

organization: Government Post Graduate College No. 1 Abbottabad
notes:
Entered Dec 2022.  Abbottabad is an important gateway to northern Pakistan and three mountain ranges, the Himalaya, Hindukush, and Karakuram. It is famous for its scenic beauty, moderate climate and educational institutions. 
The Herbarium was established by the Department of Botany in 1990. At that time, it was the only herbarium in the region. By 2005, the collection had grown to 10,000 specimens, but in October of that year, the area experienced devastating earthquake. The earthquake left many people dead or homeless and damaged much of the area’s infrastructure, including the herbarium. 
Fortunately, all involved decided that re-establishing and continuing to develop the area’s oldest and only herbarium was important. Consequently, space was set aside for the herbarium in the new BS building funded by the Saudi Government and the staff and students reorganized the surviving specimens in the new facility and began adding to them. By 2022, the collection had grown to 15,000 specimens and the decision was made to register it with Index herbariorum and to start sharing its holdings with the world via OpenHerbarium.

organization: Museo Provincial de Ciencias Naturales “Dr. Ángel Gallardo”.
notes: Entered Feb 2023.  The botanical department of “Dr. Ángel Gallardo” museum carries out vegetation surveys throughout the south Santa Fe province and surroundings, an area which has been profoundly modified by agricultural activities, with the consequent loss of biodiversity.

The Department of Botany started in 1958 with inception of degree courses under Kerala University under the leadership of Late Prof. K.V. George. In 1984, Post Graduate course was commenced and the department was elevated to the status of an approved research department affiliated to M.G. University in 2002.  This department is a pioneer department of St. Thomas College to  receive the DST-FIST grant in 2009.

The Department offers undergraduate programme in Botany based on CBCS syllabus and the sanctioned strength is 32. The post graduate programmes offered is based on CSS syllabus with Biotechnology  as specialization. Interdisciplinary/Open course is on Agri-based Microenterprises which is  good opportunity for other students to fulfill their passion towards botany, agriculture & horticulture. Botany Students study the Open Courses offered by other Departments.  Botany Complementary courses are offered for First and Second Year B. Sc Zoology students.   Short term courses offered by the department include Tissue culture for PG students and  Mushroom spawn production for UG students.

notes: Entered Mar 2023 This herbarium of nearly 1000 specimens is maintained at The Edna Lawrence Nature Lab at Rhode Island School of Design. The Nature Lab is a resource for artists and designers and is not primarily a scientific research collection, though our herbarium collection is maintained with museum standards. The bulk of our herbarium collection was donated to the Lab from the Westerly Public Library in 1979 but did not receive significant curation until circa 2000. We are now initiating the process of digitizing our specimens with the help of the Brown University Herbarium resources.

The Herbarium of the National University of Jaén is located near four types of biomes: seasonally dry tropical forests, humid montane forests, lowland Amazonian forests and paramos. Northern Peru is highly diverse and because of anthropogenic activities, many species are currently threatened, the herbarium will play an important role in the conservation of Peru's forest heritage.

department: Zonal Center for Biodiversity Conservation and Habitat Restoration
importantCollectors: ['C OMPENDIO']
notes: Entered Apr 2023.  The Visayas State University Botanic Garden Herbarium (VSUBGH) was formally recognized as one of the core parts of the Zonal Center for Biodiversity Conservation and Habitat Restoration last February 2023. Although it's new, several collections were kept in the past years of continuous research on the native flora of the Visayas region in the Philippines, despite the global pandemic. With the institutionalization of the herbarium through Index Herbariorum, the project staff of the center would like to present its collections to a broader array of people in the region and globally. Through this, our access to the scientific world will be possible, and we hope to give proper identification to those species and give names to the unnamed species which are highly threatened by illegal poaching and primary forest destruction.

geography: Montserrat is an island in the Caribbean Sea, in the Leeward Islands. Its nearest neighbours in the island chain include Guadeloupe to the southeast, Antigua to the north-east and Nevis to the northwest. Montserrat is 11 miles (18 km) long and 7 miles (11 km) wide. The island's rugged volcanic landscape is molded by three mountainous areas—the Silver Hills, the Centre Hills, and the Soufrière Hills—which are in turn cut by narrow valleys and gorges known locally as ghauts.

Zubareva', 'V. N. Zueva']
notes: Entered May 2023.  The herbarium (Part 1 – 2650 specimens; Part 2 – 626 specimens) presents mainly wild forest, steppe plants, weed species and species in culture. The collection of vascular plants includes collections from the territories of the Chelyabinsk, Kurgan, Sverdlovsk, Tyumen regions and a number of other regions of the Russian Federation. Some species are collected in specially protected natural areas. The herbarium was collected in different years by researchers from the Ural Forest Experimental Station of the All-Russian Research Institute of Forestry and Forestry Mechanization, the Institute of Plant and Animal Ecology of the Ural Branch of the Russian Academy of Sciences and the Botanical Garden of the Ural Branch of the Russian Academy of Sciences. The herbarium contains samples identified or verified by taxonomists – M.S. Knyazev, I.V. Belyaeva, E.G. Filippov and other specialists. The herbarium also includes some doublets from the SVER herbarium of the Institute of Plant and Animal Ecology. Fern species make up a small part of the herbarium. The Latin names are given in accordance with the systematic database of the Russian Federation of the PLANTARIUM website. Species names were checked against the international nomenclature database IPNI (INTERNATIONAL PLANT NAMES INDEX).

notes:
Entered Jul 2023.  The herbaria come from the Arles Natural History Museum, created in 1825 by Baron de
Chartrouse, botanist, ornithologist and mayor of Arles. The Artaud Herbarium was the first of these collection, with those of the Baron de Chartrouse, then those of other Arles botanists. This museum disappeared after the 2nd world war. The collections were kept in the reserves of the Réattu Museum in Arles. In 2019, they were entrusted to the Arles Media Library.

Chartrouse, botaniste, ornithologue et maire d'Arles. L';herbier d'Artaud est le premier à constituer
les collections, avec celles du baron de Chartrouse, puis celles des autres botanistes arlésiens. Ce
musée a disparu après la 2ème guerre mondiale. Les collections ont été conservées dans les
réserves du Musée Réattu d'Arles. En 2019, elles ont été confiées à la Médiathèque d'Arles.

notes: Entered Dec 2023.  The collection consists of specimens from the Southern Brazilian flora, especially from the Central-Southern region of the State of Paraná, whose flora has been underexplored until now. The herbarium includes more than 3000 collected and properly cataloged specimens, encompassing holotypes, endangered species, and first occurrences in the region, in the state of Paraná, and in the Southern Region of Brazil. The establishment of this herbarium aimed to fill the information gap regarding the flora of this region of Brazil and, more broadly, contribute to the understanding and conservation of regional biodiversity.

importantCollectors: ['Abdullah Dalar: Ethnobotany, E']
notes:
Entered Jan 2024.  Mardin Artuklu University Herbarium aims to detect, document, and collect all plant samples, including common, rare, endemic, food, ornamental, medicinal, and poisonous plant taxa, to preserve the plant diversity database of Mardin province.
Mardin province has a rich biodiversity due to the presence of Mediterranean, continental, and desert climates and the altitude between the mountain and the plain parts. Mardin province and its surroundings are among the ancient locations that have been adopted by humanity since the earliest periods of history. The fossil records show the use of plants dates to the Middle Palaeolithic period, approximately 60 000 years ago. Eight different plant species were identified on a human corpse found in 1960 in the Shanidar cave, which is very close to the province of Mardin. However, the historically rich plant biodiversity of Mardin province is under threat due to various reasons, such as the unconscious use of pesticides, the construction of dams and ponds, excessive and uncontrolled grazing, concretion and destruction of green areas, and industrial facilities. Therefore, documentation of floristic composition and preserving dried plant samples grown in Mardin province have significant importance in terms of biodiversity and plant conservation.

importantCollectors: ['D. D. Basargin', 'E. V. Boyko', 'R. V. Dudkin', 'I. G. Gavrilenko', 'P. G. Gorovoy', 'E. V. Novozhilova', 'N. S. Pavlova', 'G. I. Ponomarchuk', 'I. I. Shapoval', 'V. M. Starchenko', 'K. P. Ulanova', 'C. A. Volkova', 'E. N. Zdorov’eva', 'E. N. Zdorov’eva']
notes: Entered Mar 2024.  Herbarium of plant chemotaxonomy laboratory , created at the Institute of Biologically Active Substances, newly formed in 1964, Far Eastern Branch of the Siberian Branch of the USSR Academy of Sciences, renamed in 1972 into the Pacific Institute of Bioorganic Chemistry. The biography of the founder and head of the laboratory, Academician of the Russian Academy of Sciences Petr Grigorievich Gorovoy. The herbarium has more than 107 thousand specimens of vascular plants collected in the Russian Far East, Siberia and in foreign countries (Japan, the Republic of Korea, China, the USA). Herbarium collectors are specialists in studying the taxonomy of plants of the Asteraceae, Apiaceae, and Ranunculaceae families. Therefore, there are many plant samples of these families in the herbarium. In addition to the herbarium, a collection of Asteraceae achenes has been created, numbering more than 3,600 Asteraceae specimens.

Entered Mar 2024.  The Herbarium works as a repository for plants of the pacific coast of Mexico, and is a reference to all biologists working at the Biological Station to quickly identify their plants.
