importantCollectors: ['M.A. Aitzhan']
notes: Entered Apr 2024.  The herbarium has been collected since the establishment of the branch, since 1951. In 1979, the Herbarium was founded on the basis of scattered field collections. The herbarium was collected by entire generations of collectors; more than 120 collectors took part in the collection. The Herbarium collection contains rare herbarium sheets that are over 40 years old. At the end of the 90s, the areas of geobotanical surveys were reduced and the number of Herbarium collections correspondingly decreased. But, starting in 2017, with the adoption of the Agroindustrial Complex Programs, the survey area increased again and, accordingly, the Herbarium Fund became necessary again as a reference material for young specialists. At the moment, in our Herbarium Fund we have 3,000 plant species and over 10,000 herbarium sheets. In recent years, Aitzhan M.A., Saibulatova V.B., Sharipov E.K., Baiseitov N.K. have been greatly involved in collecting the Herbarium and updating destroyed copies of Herbarium sheets. We work in the branch of the RSE ""Giprozem"" in Almaty,

taxonomicCoverage: Broad taxonomic coverage with focus on the living tree collections within the Atlanta BeltLine Arboretum as well as in other installations within the Atlanta Metropolitan Area. Prominent families represented include Fagaceae, Oleaceae, and Rosaceae.
geography: Worldwide temperate tree species. Many local Southeast and Piedmont native and invasive species, ornamental cultivars, and street trees.
notes: Entered Apr 2024.  The Trees Atlanta Herbarium is administered as an educational tool and reference library. The primary focus is to verify and document species installed within the Atlanta BeltLine Arboretum, with a secondary focus on trees planted by Trees Atlanta and species found in greenspaces throughout the metropolitan area. The goal is to utilize these specimens as a reference for employees and volunteers, as well as a teaching opportunity for youth and adult educational programs.  Herbarium specimens will be used to help teach identification and leaf or tree anatomy. Hands on programs will focus around creating herbarium specimens including collection, pressing, mounting, scanning, databasing, and digitizing.

importantCollectors: ['Inactive but soon available on']
notes:
Entered Jul 2024. Inactive but soon available on line. Herbarium of the French artist Jean Hugo, 1894-1984.
The plants were collected mainly in 1948, during regular walks in France (Gard and Hérault regions) and often close to his home, the Mas de Fourques, just outside the town of Lunel.  Most of the plants are herbaceous and perennial (very few bushes and trees) and were collected in 1948, at a time when Jean Hugo was close to Louise de Vilmorin and her brothers, especially Roger de Vilmorin who encouraged him in the creation of this herbarium.  Ref : Louise de Vilmorin, Jean Hugo. Correspondance croisée – 1935 – 1954.  Honoré Champion, Paris 2019

notes: Entered Sep 2024.  The PLM Herbarium (PLMH) is a university-based herbarium located at Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM), Intramuros, Philippines, dedicated to preserving plant and fungal specimens primarily gathered from undergraduate research projects and course requirements since 1983. The collection includes approximately 500-600 specimens housed in the university’s biology laboratory, representing various taxa such as algae, bryophytes, pteridophytes, gymnosperms, angiosperms, fungi, and lichens. The primary objective of PLMH is to serve as a repository for specimens collected by student researchers and faculty members, supporting education, research, and citizen science initiatives with a focus on benefiting the academic community and the residents of Manila.

notes:
Entered Oct 2024.

IDFHU is located near Székesfehérvár, Fejér County in the Amádé-Bajzáth-Pappenhein mansion in the village of Iszkaszentgyörgy. It is surrounded by a 5 ha park and parkforest.
The herbarium and corresponding botanical exhibit and library occupy 430 m2 in 13 rooms and contains around 250 ,000 plant samples from 89800 different accessions, with particular emphasis on conifers and woody elements of the coniferous forests of Earth’s
temperate climate zones. 
 
History: goes back to 1971 when the Dendrological Documentation Project (DDP) was launched by Dr. Zsolt Debreczy at the Botanical Department of the Natural History
Museum in Budapest. Soon after when he and botanical illustrator Dr. Vera Csapody
published the applied-botanical book, “Gardens Green in Winter Too” in 1971, 
they realized the importance of the parallel study and documentation of wild- collected, and authentic cultivated specimens for morphological comparison. A research team with Dr. István Rácz and Dr. Gyöngyvér Biró was organized for photo documentation and library research, respectively, and several botanical illustrators contributed to the work.

From 1988-1991 the team continued its work at the Arnold Arboretum of Harvard University
and subsequently at the Massachusetts- based International Dendrological Research Institute, Inc. (I.D.R.I.), with the close collaboration of the non-profit organization Earthwatch, Inc. (EW). In 1995 Zsolt Debreczy left the Natural History Museum (BP) and has started to develop I.D.R.I.’s herbarium, which became the foundation of IDFHU’s current extensive collection.
 
Expeditions: in collaboration with EW (1991-1997) a worldwide documentation project
started with the assistance of 165 EW volunteers, and the subsequent research and documentation eventually covered the entire temperate zones in both Hemispheres.

Location: In 1999, for logistical reasons, IDRI’s rapidly growing herbarium moved into a 650 m2 building in Budakeszi, next to Budapest, and then, in 2023 to its current, even more ideal location. 

Complementary collections: fruit, seed and extensive cone (2800 pieces); wood collections (ca. 1000 samples); photograph collection (350 000 negatives and transparencies, partially scanned); original drawings (botanical artwork) created for ‘Conifers around the World I-II’ and the Dendrological Atlas (Conifers and other gymnosperms of the temperate climate zones and adjacent regions, in preparation). 

Contact: 
Dr. István Rácz, Curator: 
Dr. Zsolt Debreczy, Curator and Research Director, founder of the International Dendrological Foundation
Timea Kleszken, Asst. Herb. Curator

notes:
The herbarium has three areas for its operation: Salix Mounting and Identification Area, Typha Collection Area and Laelia Exhibition Area

The herbarium has its database on a website (www.semahn.chiapas.gob.mx/orquidiario/index.php), which can be consulted for anyone, and has an image bank of the plants collected more than 3,000 photographs.

Each six months, is mounted an exhibition in the Laelia Area about herbarium collection and the flora of Chiapas. These exhibition are open all the public.

The collection is mainly made up of plants of coniferous forests, Quercus forests, and wetland; the interest taxonomic groups are orchids, bromeliads, epiphytes, ferns and sedges.

notes: Entered Dec 2025.  Herbarium at Captain Srinivasa Murthy Central Ayurveda Research Centre (CSMCARI) Chennai has accessions dating back to 1960. It mainly contains plants used in Indian traditional medicine systems (Ayurveda and Siddha), and ethno-medicinal practices/ traditional folk medicines in Southern India, especially Tamil Nadu and Andhra Pradesh states of India. The herbarium also houses voucher specimens deposited by researchers/ students from Tamil Nadu, India. CSMCARI-Chennai is also a Drug-Testing Laboratory (DTL) approved by Tamil Nadu State Drug Licensing Authority for providing taxonomic authentication with voucher number, and an NABL accredited laboratory for pharmacognostic testing of ASU(H) drugs.

The herbarium includes plant species recorded from South India, especially the Kerala region and adjacent Tamil Nadu as well as Karnataka regions, with ethno-medicinal values and Ayurvedic importance. The institute is constantly engaging in Medico-Ethno Botanical surveys in different parts of Kerala for documenting the traditional folk claims and plant species used for treatments in ethnic communities of Kerala. And also includes the plant species recorded during the exploration trips to parts of Western Ghats of India. So, the herbarium constitutes an important collection of medicinal plants of Southern India, especially Kerala state.

notes: Updated September 2022 (general update).  Mercer’s herbarium specimen data and living. collections are linked and managed using current BG-BASE software. Mercer’s vouchered herbarium specimens and/or living collections will support the Plant Collections Network, formerly, the North American Plant Collections Consortium of the American Public Gardens Association and currently support Botanic Gardens Conservation International (BGCI) database.   In April 2014, the herbarium joined Mercer’s reference library, archives, laboratories and seed bank within Mercer’s newly-renovated research facility (~ 3,100 sf), the Mercer Botanical Center (MBC). The MBC provides additional dedicated space to accommodate expansion of the herbarium collections. In October 2016, the SBSC herbarium, botanical library and illustration collections were transferred to the Mercer Botanic Gardens as a long-term loan. Physical transfer of the SBSC collections was completed spring 2017 and the collections are available to researchers. Digitization of the SBSC collections is underway via NSF Grant 1902078. Mercer Botanic Gardens provides citizen scientist training programs for the Texas Master Gardener, Texas Master Naturalist, Texas Invaders, Native Plant Society of Texas, RBG Kew Millennium Seed Bank Training programs. The MERCA and SBSC herbarium collections support these education programs and facilitate training of herbarium volunteers. Mercer Botanic Gardens is a participating institution of The Center for Plant Conservation (headquartered at San Diego Zoo Global); is an affiliate of Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center; and is a member of the American Public Gardens Association and Botanic Gardens Conservation International.

importantCollectors: ['L. Poldini', 'S. Pignatti', 'D. Lausi', 'L. Chiapella', 'E. Wikus', 'P. Nimis', 'M. Tretiach', 'L. Muggia', 'G. Bressan', 'A. Falace']
notes: Updated January 2025. The specimens of the phanerogamic herbarium comes mainly from Italy (particularly from the South-Eastern Alps and the classical Karst regions) and the Mediterranean basin. Numerous samples also come from Europe, North America (Canada, United States), Japan, Canary Islands. There are also specimens used for the ""descriptio Florae Italiae"" of Pignatti (1982) and a rich collection of Genisteae, which was the subject of numerous systematic, chorological and palynological studies. The lichen samples come mostly from Italy and Europe as well as from non-European countries, particularly Asia: Armenia; Turkey (265 specimens); Russia, Altai mountains (390) and Lake Baikal (586); Japan (381), Alaska-Yukon (325), Northern Ontario (284), Svalbard Archipelago (102), Canary Islands (745), SW USA (1023), Mexico (512), Tierra del Fuego (452) and Antarctica (710). The lichenological herbarium is fully computerized and can be consulted at the link: https://italic.units.it/, dichotomic identification keys are also available. Algae specimens were collected mainly in the Mediterranean Basin (Adriatic Sea, Aegean Sea, Tyrrhenian Sea, Ligurian Sea, coasts around Sicily and Sardinia), but there are also samples coming from the Atlantic (North Sea and English and French coasts), Central-Southern Americas, African-Asian and Australian areas. The dichotomous identification keys of the Adriatic Sea algae can be found at the link: https://dryades.units.it/home/index.php?procedure=keys&organism%5B%5D=alg

division: Plant Systematics and Genetic Resources Division
department: Plant Systematics and Genetic Resources Division
taxonomicCoverage: Rare, medicinal plants, as well as red-listed and endemic plants
geography: Western Ghats, Eastern Ghats & Andaman and Nicobar Islands
importantCollectors: ['K M Prabhukumar']
notes:
Entered Apr 2011. 
 The herbarium is currently arranged according to Bentham & Hooker's system, although a rearrangement based on APG-III has been initiated.  Arya Vaidya Sala, Kottakkal has been maintaining a demonstration Garden of 8 acres with a live collection of more than thousand species of medicinal plants. These plants are collected from different parts of India, Andaman and Nicobar Islands, Malaysia, Nepal and other neighbouring countries. Rare species like <Utleria salicifolia>, <Janakiya arayalpatra>, <Decalepis hamiltonii>, <Rauvolfia serpentina>, <Embelia ribes>, <Coscinium fenestratum> etc. are conserved here. The main objective of this garden is to create awareness among the public on our medicinal plant wealth and the need for conserving the floristic diversity.

importantCollectors: ['M. Asif', 'K. Venkatesan']
notes: Entered Jan 2025 The Survey  of Medicinal Plant unit has been awarded a project entitled “Regional Raw Drugs Repository (RRDR)” -Southern plateau Region by Nation Medicinal Plants Board, M/O of AYUSH, for collecting the raw drugs with the aim of ethnobotanical survey for collection of ASU Raw Drugs from Southern Plateau region (Tamil Nadu, Karnataka, Andhra Pradesh & Telangana, Puducherry & Andaman). Additionally, the unit of the Institute is having Raw drug museum and Herbal Garden for the Conservation of the Medicinal Plants collected through ethnobotanical surveys.

geography: Hardwood shrub swamp, wet meadow, marsh, upland meadow, upland hardwood forest, upland mixed forest, upland shrubland, mixed forest swamp
importantCollectors: ['K. Garnier', 'C. Graham', 'B. Shevlin', 'M. Sorano']
notes:
Entered 2025.  We are a site specific herbarium established in 2021 by Kristen Garnier, estate gardener who earned an NYBG Certificate in Botany in 2018.  Our collection focuses on the native, naturalized and invasive plants growing on our foundation's 66 acre property that includes streams, meadows, marshes and upland woods.  We ID, collect, press, mount, and label 15-30 plants per year.  

We are located 7.5 miles west of  the Hudson River. 
Additionally we are an small organic farm and innovative soil science hub.

notes: The Komarov Botanical Institute collection consists of the following parts: 1) herbarium collections (about 6 million specimens), including the herbarium of vascular plants (about 6 million specimens); mycological herbarium (about 300 thousand specimens); lichenological herbarium (about 300 thousand specimens); bryological herbarium (about 305 thousand specimens); herbarium and collections of algae (70 thousand specimens). 2) Paleobotanical collection (about 120 thousand specimens). 3) Stock collections of the Botanical Museum: carpological (about 35 thousand specimens); dendrological (about 12 thousand specimens); collection of economic botany (about 17 thousand specimens). 4) Basidiomycetes culture collection (about 3.4 thousand specimens). 5) Collections of open (about 6 thousand specimens) and closed (about 13 thousand specimens) grounds of the Botanical Garden of Peter the Great.

importantCollectors: ['G. D. Moore']
notes:
We use basic science to document the engineering characteristics of our tidal marsh. The Tidal Marsh Program exists to assist the City of Atlantic Beach, Florida to mitigate shoreline hazards from sea level rise and storm surge. We collect local tidal marsh and ecosystem data to better understand how our marsh functions, enabling an enhanced understanding of its importance to shoreline hazard mitigation engineering (marsh location: 30.329147, -81.425325). This site is used to openly communicate results and encourage community feedback and engagement. The Tidal Marsh Program provides defendable science-based data in the following four Focus Areas:
tidal marsh characteristics and dynamics
systematic flora identification and herbarium development
ecosystem mapping
ecological engineering analysis
Future focus areas may include species interaction assessment; restoration or str

notes: The UNG Gainesville Herbarium was formally established in 2018 by a University of North Georgia Presidential Innovation Award, an internal grant which funded our ability to archive and document plant species in north Georgia, USA.  The collection is being developed from several decades of legacy specimens which had not been adequately mounted, labeled, or documented, as well as research specimens collected since 2014.  This collection is being actively developed and managed by James Diggs, Ph.D. (PI) and his research students.  It is being used for teaching and research, and is available to scientists.

importantCollectors: ['I. Beaton', 'G. Bidie', 'T. Cooke', 'K. Cross', 'J. F. Easmon', 'D. Hanbury', 'T. Hanbury', 'A. Henry', 'E. M. Holmes', 'W. Roxburgh', 'H. H. Rusby', 'H. Trimen', 'J. von Warszewicz', 'G. Watt']
notes:
Entered Nov 2018.   A database of the plants in an Excel spreadsheet and the associated high resolution photographs of all the specimens is being prepared. It is hoped to make it available on the web by about 2025-2026.

Founded and used by Pharmaceutical Society of Great Britain [Herbarium code PSGB] to teach Materia Medica to pharmacy students from 1872 to 1968. Then given to University of  Bradford [Code BRAD] for a similar purpose until transferred to Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew [Code K]  in 1995 and then to Royal College of Physicians of London in 2014, except for Daniel Hanbury's specimens, which were retained at K.

Used now to illustrate history of plants in medicine and for other uses.
Particularly strong on plants of medical and economic  importance collected in former British colonies in India and nearby areas of Far East,  SE Asia  and Africa, as well as other specimens  illustrating economically important plants mainly from Britain, Europe and South and Central America.
Many entries include name in local dialect and information about local uses.

incorporatedHerbaria: ['ARBH Mostly Angus plus other locations collected by members (1955)', 'Robert & Margaret Corstorphine Herbarium, Flora of Angus, 4500 (1944)']
importantCollectors: ['W. Gardiner', 'R. Corstorphine', 'M. Corstorphine', 'H. Ingram', 'J. Colville', 'E. Crapper', 'R.A. Taylor', 'P. Jaffrey']
notes:
Updated January 2025 (general update).

The University of Dundee’s Herbarium contains over 15,000 plant specimens, including a large public collection of Angus flora, as well as comparative specimens from other parts of Scotland. It also has some more exotic plants from further afield, such as a fascinating 19th century collection of Darjeeling Ferns.
The Herbarium was begun by D'Arcy Thompson, Professor of Biology  at what was then University College Dundee, then developed by Patrick Geddes, the first Professor of Botany. Lack of resources forced Geddes to abandon his work on the collection, and only a few of the specimens that came to the University during his time survive today. The Herbarium does, however, contain many plant specimens from the 19th century, though these were acquired at a later date.
Following the gift of the Corstorphine Collection to the University in 1944, a later Botany lecturer, Dr Hugh Ingram, recommenced the active collection of herbarium specimens during the latter half of the 20th century. Various other researchers added to the collection until the decline of Botany teaching in the 1980s and 90s.

importantCollectors: ['F. Z. Du', 'R. S. Tian']
notes: Entered Apr 2017.  Hupingshan National Nature Reserve herbarium was founded at the same time  as the reserve,  in 1982. With the hard work of the reserve staff, we have collect almost all the species of the reserve flora (3080 species) and  capture  color photos as well.  It is very hard to find such complete information for any reserve in China. Also Hupingshan is  representative of Wuling Moutains in China, whicn includes most flora of the Wuling Moutain.  We hope this rich flora resource can be of some use to plant researchers around the world.
Entered Aug 2014. The reserve has 3080 species of  plants, and every species has got pictures and had published the book < Flora of Hupingshan>.

notes: Updated Feb 2016 (general update).  BJFC was developed on the basis of the original Forest Herbarium, which has a history of over 90 years starting from 1923 and has witnessed the whole process of the construction and development of the university. The main collections of BJFC include specimens of rare and endangered wild fauna and frola from forest, wetland and desert ecosystems, i.e. vascular plant, insets, animals, wood, fungi, soils and rocks. BJFC has got  a collection of about 200,000 plant,110,000 insets, 2,000 fungi, 10,000 wood, and 400 soil & rocks specimens.

importantCollectors: ['Y u-Ke Bi']
notes:
Updated February 2023 (general update).
CSH founded in 2005, opened in April 2010, the herabrium covered 1,560 square metres at the basement in Shanghai Chenshan Botanical Garden, and can ultimately hold about 1,000,000 dried specimens. 
Up to 2022, CSH totally holds 190,000 specimens, 75% of them had been digitized. CSH mainly collects vascular plants in East Asia, and now collected plentiful of specimens from East China Sea islands, Shanghai and East China region (including Anhui, Fujian, Jiangsu, Jiangxi, Shandong and Zhejiang), and also collected invasive plants in China. For some groups, like Polypodiaceae, Lepisorus, Dennstaedtiaceae, Microlepia and Tectariaceae in ferns, Aristolochiaceae, Begoniaceae, Celastraceae, Fagaceae, Machilus (Lauraceae), Salvia (Lamiaceae), CSH extended the range to East Asia and East Africa.

notes:
Eastern Anatolia is the largest (approximately 170 000 km2) of seven geographical divisions of Turkey with 14 provinces, bordering Iraq, Iran, Nakhichevan, Armenia, and Georgia. It is included in the Irano-Turanian phytogeographical region, covered with deciduous-mixed forests and deciduous tree steppes. The area is surrounded by coastal mountain ranges, which protects it from the moderating effect of sea breezes. Subsequently, the winters are cold and long, with snow lasting for several months. They are followed by very short and rainy springs, and hot and dry summers. The mountainous and strongly fragmentised area offers numerous microclimatic and ecological zones, which provided suitable conditions for the development of diverse flora.
      The local population has a comprehensive knowledge of traditional herbal medicines which are commonly used to prevent or to treat disease. This knowledge was developed over centuries, when Eastern Anatolia served as a passageway between the continents of Europe, Asia and Africa. A variety of flora, fauna and cultures owe their geographical spread to this passageway. Over many centuries a number of races and tribes originated from distant lands settled in Eastern Anatolia, bringing knowledge of plants and their various uses. This heritage, combined with the local flora, has contributed to an extensive use of plants in daily life as a medicine. The knowledge of herbal medicines in this region is still mostly passed on orally (with the exception of a few codices) from one generation of religious healers (referred to as‘seyh’) and local healers (‘hekim’) to the next.

notes: Registered in 2022. These specimens provide baseline information about the natural environment of Hawaiʻi Volcanoes National Park. These collections display the remarkable diversity of the Big Island of Hawaiʻi. The scope of the collection encompasses: specimens from within the boundaries of the park and immediately adjacent to the park; specimens from the island of Hawaiʻi which, because of the dynamic nature of the plants, may become species of concern to resource management in the future; specimens from other islands in the Hawaiian chain of interest for genetic/evolutionary research and/or of interest due to future possible migration to the park; and specimens from the greater Pacific region of interest for their historic or evolutionary ties to the flora of Hawaiʻi.

organization: Italian National Antarctic Museum (MNA) (Section of Genoa)
notes: Entered Mar 2022.  The herbarium is part of the biological collections of the MNA curated at the University of Genoa. The general web site of the Museum is: www.mna.it. The biological collections database can be accessed here: https://steu.shinyapps.io/MNA-generale/. All the materials have been collected in Antarctica in the framework of the expeditions of our National Antarctic Program (PNRA) or in collaboration with other countries operating in Antarctica. The MNA has a complex structure, i.e. there are collections that are curated in different tows as these need specific conservation requirements (e.g. bacteria and fungi strains).

Entered Apr 2009.  The Associazione Micologica Bresadola was founded in Trento, 7 December 1957.  It was originally called  ""Gruppo Micologico G. Bresadola"". This name derives from the Abbot Giacomo Bresadola, one of the most important mycologists. In 1987 the name was changed to ""Associazione Micologica Bresadola"". The aim of the Association is to bring together people who are interested in mycology and conservation of fungi. The Association carries on intense editorial, scientific, legislative and local activities. It cooperates with State, regions, and institutes on mycological subjects. The Association's   Mycological Study Center  administrates of the Bresadola Mycological Library; creation of a scientific data bank on census and indexing of fungal speciesand maintenance of a mycological  herbarium and data bank for toxicological problems.  The Association's Library  contains about 2,200 books and 100 periodicals. The list of the books and the periodicals of the library is avaiable for download at the webiste.  file  The library contains also older literature including  ""Nova Plantarum Genera"

notes:
Entered 'Feb 2025.  The Walter Sisulu National Botanical Garden manages an associated 300ha Nature Reserve as part of the Botanical Garden. The Nature Reserve portion is used by garden visitors for hiking and nature appreciation as well as study and research by students and academics. 

The Walter Sisulu National Botanical Garden comprises a 25ha cultivated garden (plus the 300ha nature reserve), the garden is landscaped exclusively with indigenous South African Plants. The garden is open to the public for an entrance fee 7 days a week. 

The nature reserve is home to over 600 plant species which are backed up by specimens in the herbarium, constant exploration in the nature reserve by staff and students result in new species being added and fresh specimens being added to the collection.

importantCollectors: ['Daniel B. Montesinos-Tubée']
notes:
Entered Feb 2025.  The Herbarium HCSP is a significant botanical collection that serves as a vital resource for research, conservation, and education. Established with the contributions of renowned botanist Dr. Daniel Montesinos, the herbarium currently houses over 1,500 species meticulously collected by him throughout Peru. Additionally, it contains more than 1,000 specimens gathered by students, reflecting a collaborative effort to document the country’s rich biodiversity.

One of the most valuable aspects of the HCSP collection is the presence of isotypes, paratypes, and neotypes, particularly within the Caryophyllaceae and Asteraceae families. Dr. Montesinos' collections are highly regarded due to their broad geographic range and scientific accuracy, making them critical references for taxonomic and ecological studies. These specimens not only contribute to the understanding of Peru’s flora but also serve as an essential repository for researchers working on plant systematics and conservation.

The HCSP Herbarium continues to expand, fostering botanical research and providing an invaluable resource for students, scientists, and conservationists dedicated to the study of plant diversity in Peru.

The vertical filing is upplied to arrange paper envelopes in cardboard trays, which have labels and separators to devide different taxa. The cabinets and trays have individual numbers with corresponding ‘Storage tree’ in the database to track the exact place of storage. The labels have QR-codes and could be easily retrieved by catalog number. The collection is organized in systematic (grouping in orders, classes, families, genera and species) and alphabetical (within a taxon) orders.

notes: Entered Mar 2025.   Because of ongoing construction and renovation of Barnard's science building, the collectdion is currently stored with the Barnard Archives, part of Columbia University Libraries.. From Barnard's founding, it aimed to offer students training in botany as part of an overall degree-earning curriculum at Columbia or as a special subject of study that did not lead to a degree. This woman''s college was founded one year earlier than the New York Botanical Garden. None of the holdings are directly from Columbia's herbarium, which was transferred to NYBG. Rather, it appears that many active botanists of the day donated specimens to ensure that young women studying botany at the time could study in "a herbarium of her own."

notes: Entered Mar 2025.  In 2025, 1,533 macroalgae specimens from the UAMIZ herbarium will be transferred to the PHYCOP herbarium, establishing the first herbarium/collection in Mexico dedicated exclusively to algae and protists. Additionally, the microalgae collection from the Marine and Brackish Phytoplankton Laboratory, comprising 142,596 specimens preserved on slides and in liquid, will be integrated with the macroalgae collection to form the FitoProt Herbarium / PhycoProt Herbarium. Subsequently, Universidad del Mar, Puerto Ángel campus, will join this initiative by contributing its microalgae culture collection, which will be incorporated into the herbarium following a thorough review and formal inclusion through an institutional agreement.

taxonomicCoverage: The herbarium focuses primarily on vascular plants native to northeastern Somalia, particularly dryland and semi-arid species. Key taxonomic groups include:  Burseraceae – Boswellia species (frankincense)  Asphodelaceae – Aloe species  Fabaceae – Acacia and related genera  Euphorbiaceae, Lamiaceae, and other drought-adapted families of the Horn of Africa flora   The collection emphasizes ecologically and economically important taxa, many of which are used in traditional medicine, pastoral livelihoods, and regional t
geography: The herbarium primarily covers the flora of northeastern Somalia, with a focus on the Bari region, including areas around Qardho, Calmadow Mountains, and adjacent dryland plains. Specimens are collected from a range of habitats including semi-arid savannas, rocky escarpments, seasonal riverbeds, and frankincense woodlands. The collection aims to represent both widespread and endemic species characteristic of the Horn of Africa’s arid and semi-arid ecosystems.
incorporatedHerbaria: ['Part of EAUQ', 'regional flora of northeastern Somalia with a focus on ecologically and economically important native species, including Boswellia (frankincense), Aloe, Acacia, and associated dryland flora (2,000 specimens) collected between late 2022 and 2025']
importantCollectors: ['A. Mohamed', 'F. Abdullah', 'M. Shire']
notes: The EAUQ Herbarium was established in late 2022 as part of East Africa University – Qardho Campus. It focuses on documenting the dryland flora of northeastern Somalia, with special emphasis on economically and ecologically significant taxa such as Boswellia, Aloe, and Acacia species. The herbarium research in taxonomy, ethnobotany, and conservation. Field collections are made in collaboration with the Puntland Ministry of Environment and Climate Change. The herbarium aims to contribute to regional biodiversity knowledge, sustainable resource management, and education.

notes:
Entered june 2025.  In May 2024, authorities from the Autonomous University of Campeche finalized the proposal to integrate the collection of the UCAM Herbarium of the Center for Historical and Social Research (CIHS) and the Mayan Biodiversity Museum Herbarium (MBM) of the Center for Studies on Sustainable Development and Use of Wildlife (CEDESU) with the aim of grouping both collections and forming a single institutional herbarium, which has been named the UACAM-CEDESU Herbarium.
The UACAM-CEDESU Herbarium's mission and vision is to safeguard and expand the herb collection of flora from the state of Campeche and the region, conduct scientific research, promote human resource development, and increase knowledge of local flora for the development of activities that foster the sustainable use and conservation of plant diversity in the region.

organization: Instituto Federal de Educação, Ciência e Tecnologia Goiano
importantCollectors: ['V. S. Santos-Diniz']
notes:
Entered Aug 2025.  The Herbarium of the Instituto Federal Goiano, Iporá Campus, features collections from the western Goiás region, where biodiversity knowledge gaps still exist.
The Herbarium has been operating as a teaching herbarium since 2018 and now also aims to serve as a storage and conservation site for local native species (Cerrado biome) and unconventional food and medicinal species cultivated in the region.
